div.p: ACTON. Walter, son of Richard de Lulham, grants to John, son of Wygot Hake, for 43s. in hand paid, three acres of arable land in the village of Haketon, for an annual rent of 5d. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 249.

John, son of Joan, daughter of the late Joanle Thek [entirely effaced, see ch. 250] of Aketon, remits and quit-claims to Thomas Fraunce and others all right in a piece of a meadow ... [A large part effaced.] Dated Sunday next after the feast of St. Hilary, . . Ed. [III? II?]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 251.

James Thurgore of Aketon, William Sheldrake of Sudbury, Gilbert Wareyne, John Bryan, Robert Longe, and Robert Parteryche of Aketon, demise to Ann Freman, late wife of John Freman of Hertest, James Ward, James Sped, JohnWard of Shymplyng, and William Cokshed of Hertest, one messuage, 7 acres of land, one rood of wood, and 6d. rent in the village of Aketon. Dated at Aketon, 31 July, 8 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 253.
Duplicate charter of MS. Ch. Suffolk 253, omitting the date of day! MS. Ch. Suffolk 254.

Joan Permeter of Aketon, widow, grants to Robert Person of Aketon, chaplain, one messuage in Aketon, between the land of the prior of Hatfield Peverell of the one part, and the way leading from the well called 'Ladywell' on the other, abutting on the land of Thomas Ormond, knt., lord Ormond, called Gottesmersshe. Dated at Aketon, 29 April, 16 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 255.

Indenture made 12 May, 10 Hen. VIII, by which the lady Anne Arundel, widow, leases to Robert Bryon a messuage and all that belongs to it in Aketon, for 10 years, at an annual rent of £8 13s. 4d. [English] [much rubbed] MS. Ch. Suffolk 256.

Andrew Halys of Neuton and John Belleard grant to Gilbert Warein of Aketon and others a cottage wall a garden called Laggardys in Aketon. Dated on the day of the feast of the Holy Innocents in Christmas week, [16?] Hen. [VII?]. [Partly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 258.

Indenture dated 30 June, 37 Hen. VIII, by which Robert Crane , esq., demises to Robert Man of Aketon, husbandman, his mease in Aketon called Gybbes att Bearne, with lands &c. thereto belonging, for 12 years, at an annual rent of £9. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 257.
Agreement between Joan Clerbek and Robert de Rocwode, dated at Aketon ... after feast of ..., 1 Edw. III. [Almost entirely effaced.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1229.

ACTON, WALDINGPIELD (Great), and SUDBURY. Wilhelm de Grangia of Great Waldyngfeld remits and quit-claims to sir John Carbonel, kt., and his heirs, all his right in the marriage of Simon, son and heir of Robert de Bertone of Subery,
[by reason] of ... tenement which the said Simon holds of him in the villages of Akctone, Great Waldingfeld, and Subery. Dated at Suber' the Saturday on the morrow of the conversion of St. Paul, 31 Ed. I. [Mutilated.] [With seal.]
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1228.

Laurence Porterose of Melford, .... Sextayn of Aketon, chaplain, John Ormelewe, cutter, of Lound, and Peter Webbe of Aketon quit-claim to Roger le Reve of ..., William Bertellor and Roger Pecke of Melford, all their right in all lands and tenements, rents and services in Aketon, Great Waldingfield, and Sudbury. Dated at Aketon the Monday next after the feast of St. Dionisius, 10 Rich. II. [With 4 small seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 252.

ALINGTON, COMBES, MENDELESHAM, &c. Laurence Cheyne , esq., Robert Smyth , clerk, and Walter Taylard appoint William Smith their attorney to receive for them and in their name of John Gray and others seisin of the manor of Alington and all other lands and tenements in Combes, Mendelesham, &c. Dated 4 April, 8 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1231.

ALVESBOURN. John Salemann of Alnesbrunne and Matilda his wife grant to William de Estoke, for his homage and service and 4s. of silver, one piece of his land in Alnesbrunn, paying annually to him and his heirs one penny at the feast of St. Michael. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1233.

William, son of William Sproth of Ipswich, grants to John .... of Alnesbourne, for his homage and service and for 4 marks of silver, certain land in Alnesbourne called ' Chrullesslade.' [Temp. Ed. I or II.] [c. 1300] [Mutilated, and date lost.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1232.

ALVESBOURN (Priory of). Robert, the prior, and canons of Alvesbrunne remit and quit-claim to William de Kirkeby, the prior, and convent of the Holy Trinity, Norwich, all action, right, and claim in 20s. annual rent, assigned to the former by Albert de Nevyle and his heirs out of the half of a certain water-mill in Kesewyk, formerly called 'le Oldemylne,' but now destroyed and the arrears of which for 28 years they had claimed; for this remission and quit- claim the said prior and convent of Norwich gave 16 marks of silver. Dated at Norwich the Tuesday next after the feast of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist, 14 Ed. I. [With fine seal, perfect, of the pirory of Alvesbrunne.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 187.

ASHBY. Geoffrey de Raveningham grants to Alice Bonde, for her homage and service and 40s. of silver, 3½ roods and 5½ perches of his land, and 1½ acres of brushwood in Askebi; also 12d. of annual rent, viz. from William Wascelin and Jordan his brother 4d., from Nicholas de Beletun 2½d., from Augustine Storm 1d., from Henry de Steingate 2d., from Geoffrey de Bure 1d., from Robert le Neue 1d., and from Nicholas de Bela[un]t ½d.; paying annually to the said Geoffrey one clove. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 664.

Margaret, daughter of William de Raveningham, grants to John de Askeby, son of Geoffrey de St. Sano, for his homage and service and 40s. of silver, a piece of land in Askeby. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 665.

Ralph, son of Alured the Little ("Aluredri Petit"), and Alice, daughter of William de Raveningham, grant to John de Askeby, son of Geoffrey de St. Sano, for his homage and service and for 15s., three cartloads (bigatas) of peat which they were accustomed to receive annually from the turbary of the said John, in Askeby. (c. 1240.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 666.

Hugh de ... grants to John de Askeby, son of Geoffrey de St. Sano, one piece of his land which lies in Askeby near 'Gunnildes mere,' paying annually to him and his heirs one halfpenny. (c. 1250?.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 679b.

John, son of Geoffrey de St. Sano, grants to Thomas, son of William de Broxtuns, for his homage and service and 5 marks of silver, 4½ acres and half a rood of his land in Askeby, lying together in one culture called 'Brom,' paving annually for the same 18d. (c. 1250.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 667.

Geoffrey, and Joan his wife, relict of William, son of Alexander de Askeby, grant to John de Nanethorp, and Emma and Margery daughters of Bartholomew de Nanethorp, all their right in the whole of a certain turbary which the said William sold to John and Bartholomew. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 668.

Indenture of an agreement respecting land in Askeby, dated 53? Hen. III, between John .... and Nicholas and Alice ....; endorsed "... smart et Alicia mater sua". [In most part illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 669.
Final concord, Hen. III, between John de Askeby and Alice ... [Mutiated and illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 670.
Final concord, endorsed as being dated 53 Hen. III. [Illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 671.

Final concord, dated 53 Hen. III, by which Robert del Bure of Askeby remits and quit-claims to John de Askeby all his right in all the messuages of the said John in Askeby, also in certain lands in Askeby, upon certain conditions. MS. Ch. Suffolk 672.

Final concord made 15 days from the feast of the Holy Trinity, 53 Hen. III, by which Robert de Fretun, Catherine his wife, and Lecia de H... and Stephen her son, of Askeby, remit and quit-claim to John de Askeby all their right in certain messuages of John de Askeby, in Askeby. MS. Ch. Suffolk 673.

Agnes de .... of Manethorp grants to Gilbert, son of sir John de Askeby, all her right in one half acre of land in the village of Askeby, for which he gives one comb. of barley. [Chiefly illegible.] (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 674a.

William, son of Alexander, and Thomas, son of Robert, grant to John, son of Geoffrey, and his heirs, all right in 14 acres of turbary and 14 acres of brushwood in Brendelinges in Askeby. (c. 1250.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 674b.
William, son of Robert de Askeby, grants to John ... half an acre of land in Askeby. (c. 1280.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 675.

William, son of Robert de Askeby, grants to Philip, son of Geoffrey de Askeby, for 3s. 3½d. annual rent in the village of Askeby, viz. 1½d. and the homage and service of the said John, for his tenement in Askeby, and 2d. from Adam, son of Henry Bolle. (c. 1280.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 676.

Geoffrey, son of John de Askeby, grants to John de Ingelose his nephew, the whole of his messuage, lands, and a mill in Askeby, Somerleton, Belton, Lound, Leystoft, &c. (c. 1280-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 677.

Robert Delayps[?] of Somerleyton grants to Geoffrey, son of John de Askeby, one rood of turbary lying in the parish of Askeby, in exchange for one rood of brushwood. Dated at Askeby the Sunday next before the feast of St. Luke the evangelist, ... [Henry III.] (c. 1260-70) MS. Ch. Suffolk 678.
Geoffrey, son of John de Askeby, grants to William Davy of Broxton and Alice his wife one rood of land in Askeby. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 679a.

Convention between Geoffrey, son of sir John de Askeby, on the one part, and Robert .... of the other, made the Wednesday next before the feast of St. Barnabas, ... Ed. I, by which the said Geoffrey grants to the said Robert a certain free fold with free entrance and exit in Askeby, for half a mark. (1273-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 680a.
Geoffrey, son of sir John de Askeby, grants to John, son of Thomas Bathelerde (?), one rood of land in the fields of Askeby. (c. 1270-80.) [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 680b.

Edward Bee of Ludham, Richard Crystmes of Somerleyton, Thomas Colyn of Lound, and Thomas Bryd grant to Margaret, formerly the wife of John Langton of Borough-Castell, and William Sygoo alias Fytte of the same place, certain messuages, lands, and tenements in Askeby which they had by the gift of the said John Langton. Dated at Askeby, 4 January, 9 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 681.
Charter by which ... grant to ... Ingelose ... in Askeby. [Mutilated. Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 682a.
Charter by which ... grants to William, son of John de ... a piece of land in Askeby. (c. 1250-60.) [In most part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 682b.
Geoffrey de Askeby, son of the late sir John de Askeby, grants to Emma his daughter .. acres of land lying in the fields of Askeby. (c. 1270-80.) [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 683.

Robert, son of Henry Thurge of Askeby, grants to John, son of John del Hil, one piece of underwood in Askeby, at an annual rent of one halfpenny. Dated ... next before the feast of St. Michael, .. Ed. I. (c. 1280) MS. Ch. Suffolk 684.
Charter by which ... de Askeby grants to Robert, son of John Ingelose, all his lands, rents, &c. in Askeby. (c. 1280-90.) [For most part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 685.

Robert de Ingelose, lord of Askeby, grants to Simon de Beltone a free common of communication and feeding for all his beasts of Lound, in Askeby, as the freemen of the said village have. (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 686.
Nicholas, son of John del Hil of Askeby, remits and quit-claims to John ... all his right in one piece of land in Askeby. (c. 1270.) [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 687.
William, son of Robert de Askeby, grants to John del Hil and his heirs, for his homage and service and 5 marks of silver, one acre of land in Askeby. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 688.

Stephen, son of William de Askeby , clerk, grants to John, son of Robert de Manetorp, and Thomas his son, for their homage and service and 36 marks sterling, one messuage and the half of a wood and five acres of land in Manthorp, also one acre in Askeby; paying annually to him and his heirs one penny, and to Thomas Grey and his assigns the service due and accustomed. (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 689.

Thomas, son of [Robert?] de Monte, grants to John, son of Osbert de Askeby, for his homage and service and 2s. of silver, the whole gift (totum donum) which Walter de Blundeston, clerk, granted and gave to the same John, viz. one piece of land in Askeby; paying annually for the same three halfpence. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 690.
Nicholas, son of .... grants to William ... in Askeby and Heringflete. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 691.

William, son of Alexander de Askeby, grants to John, son of Geoffrey de Askeby, for his homage and 40s., 2½ acres of land and turbary in Askeby, paying annually for the same 3d. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 692.
William ... de Askeby, for his homage and service ... in Askeby. (c. 1270-80.) [The greater part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 693.

John, son of Jurdan de Askeby, remits and quit-claims to John, son of Geoffrey de St. Sano, and his heirs, all his right in turbaries, brushwoods, and in his demesnes lying in Askeby, saving the pasture of Askeby; for this quit-claim the said John gave to John three acres of his turbary and 3½ acres of brushwood in Askeby at Langhowe. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 694.

John, son of Jordan de Askeby, grants to John, son of Geoffrey de Askeby, for his homage and service and l0s. 6d., three acres of land in Askeby, lying in 'Langhouwe;' at an annual rent of one penny. (c. 1270.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 695.

Alice, relict of John, son of Jordan de Askeby, grants to Geoffrey, son of sir John de Askeby, kt., all her right in a piece of turbary in the village of Askeby; for this grant the said Geoffrey shall give annually to the said Alice for her life 22 hundred of turves. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 696.
Charter by which .... remits and quit-claims to John, son of Geoffrey de Askeby, all right to 14 loads of furse in .... of Askeby. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 697.

Thomas atte .... grants to William .... Geld of Kessinglond and Alice, daughter of the said Thomas, one acre and a half of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Thursday before feast of St. [Luke?] evang., 2 Ed. II. [Mutilated and partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 698.
Illegible charter ... grant to Stephen .... Dated at Askeby the Thursday on the feast of St. Martin, [16?] Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 699.

Charter by which ... grants to sir Robert de ... a piece of arable land lying in the fields of Askeby. Dated at Askeby after the feast of St. Luke, evang., 16? Ed. II. [Almost entirely illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 700.

William ae.... of Craneworthe grants to Alan de W... of Heryngflete a piece of land containing 3 acres lying in the village of Askeby. Dated at Askeby Sunday after feast of Annunciation B.V.M. Ed. [III]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 701.

Emma, wife of Robert Bolle of Askeby, remits and quit-claims to Henry de la Hil of Gorlestone all her right in a piece of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Sunday next after St. Luke, evang., 10 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 702.
Joan, daughter of Thomas del Hil of Askeby, is bound to Walter, son of Thomas de Manthorp Dated at Askeby, 2 July, [18?] Ed. III. (illegible) MS. Ch. Suffolk 703.
Grant of land in Askeby. [Illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 704.

Sir Robert de Ingelose, kt., grants to Robert de Mundeford, parson of the church of Askeby, one piece of land lying in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Wednesday next after the feast of St. John ante port. Lat., 4(?) Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 705.
Joan, formerly the wife of sir Robert de Ingelose, kt., grants to ... of Heryngfleth one piece of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Thursday ... 37 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 706.

William Roger, Robert Brig ..., John atte Mersh, senior, and John atte Mersh, junior, grant to John de Boyton one messuage, and also all lands and tenements, together with mores(?), underwood, and appurtenances which they lately had by feoffment of Peter de Burgh and Isabella his wife in the village of Askeby, and which was formerly John Chapeleyn's. Dated at Askeby the Saturday next after the feast of St. George the Martyr, 41 Ed. III. (endorsement) MS. Ch. Suffolk 707.

Henry del Hil of Askeby grants to Thomas Rust and Alice his wife, of the same place, the whole of his messuage, with one acre of arable land, in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Sunday next after the feast of ..., 42? Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 708.

Henry Botyld of Brandon, rector of the church of Somerleton, John Jeckys of Erpyngham, chaplain, and Edmund de Cagleton (?), chaplain, recite a feoffment of John atte Hyl of Askeby of lands &c. in the villages of Askeby, Somerleton, Harryngflete, and elsewhere in the hundred of Londyngland, to Edmund atte Hil, paying to the said Henry and others by two instalments 200s.; by this present writing
they acknowledge to have received the said sum of Edmund atte Hil. Dated at Askeby the Monday next after the feast of the Exaltation of the Cross, 48(?) Ed. III. [Partially legible] MS. Ch. Suffolk 709.

John de Merche of Heringflete and Robert le Neve of Askeby grant to Roger .... a messuage in Askeby, together with a croft and a piece of land at Donnacre. Dated at Askeby on the vigil of St Andrew the apostle, 1 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 710.

Simon, parson of the church of Askeby, and others, grant to Edmund atte Hel of Askeby a messuage and two pieces of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Friday next after the feast of the Conversion of St. Paul, 1 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 711
Edmund de .... of Askeby grants to Simon, parson of Askeby, and others, his lands and tenements in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Sunday before ..., 1 Rich. II. [Chiefly illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 712.

Simon, parson of Haskeby, Edmund Pechare of Great Gernemut, William Ropere of Catefeld, and John de "Maresco" of Herlyngflete, grant to William Cok of Askeby one inclosure with houses erected thereon, and one piece of land beyond the gate of the said inclosure. Dated at Askeby the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Barnabas, 1 Rich. II. [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 713.
John Herk of Somerleton grants to Adam Bocmonger of Askeby one piece of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Sunday next after the feast of St. Andrew, 4 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 714.

John Herdhald (?) of Bradwell grants to Edmund Bende of Askeby one messuage with crofts adjoining, together with all lauds &c. to the said messuage belonging in the village of Askeby. Dated at Askeby on the feast of St. Peter ad vine., 8 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 715

William Cook of Filby grants to Andrew Borston of Askeby two pieces of arable land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Monday next after the feast of St. Gregory the pope, 20 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 716.

Nicholas Wychingham grants to John atte Gene of Somarleton the manor of Askeby with the church lands and appurtenances for 6 years after the date of these presents, paying annually 7 marks sterling. Dated 1 October, 20 Rich. II. [With seal.] [Partially effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1234.
Elizabeth ... grants to Thomas ... three pieces of land in Askeby. Dated at Lound the Saturday next after the feast of the Conversion of St. Paul, 21 Rich. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 717.

Roger Skarlet, chaplain, grants to John Thurberne, chaplain, Will Dareys
of Lound, and Roger Primour of the same, all his messuages, lauds, and tenements in the villages of Askeby and Lound. Dated at Askeby the Monday next after the feast of SS. Simon and Jude, 3 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 718.

Alice, formerly wife of John Grene of Somerleton, remits to Thomas Torald of Heringflete all her right in certain messuages &c. in Askeby which were formerly John Grene's her husband. Dated at Askeby the Monday next after the feast of St. Michael, 3 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 719.

William Dale, prior of the priory of St. Olave, Heringflete, grants to ...Owden of Somerleyton, son and heir of Thomas Owden, a certain annual rent from two cottages in Askeby. Dated .... December, 5 Hen. VIII. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 203.

John Bakere, parson of Somerleyton, Richard Paylewyk of Freton, and John Douce of Heringflete, grant to William Craneworth, parson of Askeby, one tenement and three pieces of arable land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Friday next before the feast of palms, 9 Hen. IV. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 720.

Charter by which grants to Henry .... of Somerleyton two pieces of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Sunday next after the feast of St. Michael, [10?] Hen. IV. [Mutilated, and in most part illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 721.

Margaret, daughter of Thomas Rust of Askeby, grants to William Craneworth, rector of Askeby, all her messuages and lands in Askeby which were Thomas Rust's. Dated at Askeby the Thursday after the feast of St. Kenelm, .. Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 724.
Henry Boyton of .... grants to Roger Prymowr of Lound one piece of land lying in the village of Askeby. Dated at Lound on the vigil of the Epiphany, 13 Hen. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 725.

Adam Bukmonger of Askeby grants to Richard Eleyne, rector of Askeby, Robert Eleyne and John Cale of the same village, one piece of land of half an acre in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 2 October, 10 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 722.

Nicholas Ludham of .... quit-claims to .... all his right in two pieces of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Sunday next after the feast of St. James the apostle, .. Hen. V. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 723.

John Beketone, burgess of Great Jernemouthe, grants to John Dustgate of Askeby one piece of underwood in Askeby. Dated there the Monday next after the feast of St. Hilary, 4 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 726.
Thomas Torald of Askeby grants to John his son his tenement in Askeby. Dated there, 4 Dec., 3 Hen. VI. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 727.
Thomas Torald of Askeby grants to John his son one messuage and lands in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 4 Dec., 3 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1235.

Thomas Torald of Askeby grants to John Torald his son a messuage and land in Askeby; being the conditions of his grant, viz. the provision of maintenance for himself and his wife Isabella during their lives. Dated at Askeby, 4 December, 3 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 728.

Richard Dole of Askeby grants to Gregory Draper, citizen of Norwich, Robert Bukmongere of Askeby, and John Nabbys of Burgh, 2 pieces of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 2 January, 12 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 729.

Charter by which ... Me[dhop?] and Robert le Premoure confirm to John Torald of Barneby a messuage and rents in the villages of Askeby and Heryngflete. Dated at Askeby the Thursday next before the feast of Palm Sunday, 13 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 730.

John Toorald of Barneby grants to Robert Primour of Lound and Henry his brother two pieces of land lying in the fields of Askeby. Dated at Askeby on the feast of St. James, 13 Hen. VI. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 731.

John Dustgate of Askeby remits and quit-claims to John Gernegan, esq. John Fastolf , esq., Nicholas Bokkyng and others, all his right in one piece of land in Askeby. Dated 4 January, .. Hen. VI. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 732.
Henry Dole of Askeby and Agnes his wife grant to Robert Prymour of Lound two pieces of underwood in Askeby. Dated at Askeby 30 March, 14 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 733.
John Gernegan esq. and Thomas Kempster of Somerleton grant to Robert Waryn of the same place two pieces of underwood in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 12 May, 21 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 734.

John Chapeleyn of Blundeston, Edmund Be of Hopton, and others demise to William Bukmonger of Askeby a messuage in the village of Askeby, late John Dustgates. Dated at Askeby, 12 March, 31(?) Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 735.
Roger .... and others grant to William ... of Askeby one piece of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 20 Feb., 37 Hen. VI. [With 4 seals.] [Almost wholly illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 736.
John Jerningham and Nicholas Bockyng grant to John Ive , clerk, one piece of land containing four acres in Askeby. Dated at Askeby .. May(?) 38 Henry VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 737.

John Berney, sen., William Paston, John Wodehouse, and William Rokewock, esqs. grant to Robert Inglose , esq., their manor of Askeby with the advowson of the church. Dated at Askeby, 15 April, 38 Hen. VI MS. Ch. Suffolk 738.

Robert Bukmonger of Askebi grants to Edmund Waryn of Somyrleton and two others one piece of land in the fields of Askeby, called le Longelond. Dated at Askeby, 16 July, 1 Ed. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 739.

Richard Doole of Askeby and Henry Doole his son grant to Thomas(?) ... of Somerleton, John Booff, John Todenham, and another, a
tenement with a croft adjoining, one piece of land, and five pieces of underwood in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 16 January, 49 Hen. VI, and 1st year of his restoration. MS. Ch. Suffolk 740.
Henry Doole of Askeby and others grant to JohnTodenham of Somerleton a piece of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 1 July, (11?) Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 741.

Edmund Waryn of Somerleyton and Henry Dole demise and confirm to William Bukmonger of Askeby one piece of land containing five acres in the fields of Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 4 May, 3 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 742.
William Bukkemongere of Askeby, son and heir of Robert Bukkemongere grants to Geoffrey Bukkemongere one piece of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 13 May, 3 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 743.
William, son and heir of Robert Bukmonger of Askebi, grants to Richard Applbi and Peter Goos one piece of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 28 May, 3 Ed. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 744.
William Bukmonger of Askeby grants to Thomas Oweyn of Somerleton and others certain tenements and lands in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 10 January, 3 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 745.
Edmund .... grants to Thomas Colyn' of Lound and Margaret his wife one piece of land in Askeby lately sir Henry Inglose's, kt. Dated at Askeby, 24 Oct., 4 Ed. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 746.

Grant of three pieces of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Monday next before the feast of St. Peter ad vinc., 4 Ed. IV (?). [With seal.] [Nearly illegible. Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 747.

Thomas Collyn alias ....chapsman, of Lund grants to Henry Doole of Askeby and others six acres of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby the 5th of March, 5 Ed. IV. [Partially illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 748.

Richard Dole of Askeby and two others grant to Thomas Owdon of Somerleton and John Tudyngham one piece of land containing four acres more or less in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 16 May, 6 Ed. IV. [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1236.
Richard Dole of Askeby and others demise to Thomas Man of Lenne and others one piece of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 11 February, 6 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 749.

Margaret, relict of John Langton of Borogh Castell, and William Sygoe alias Ffytte demise to Richard Hacon and others a certain messuage and land in Askeby. Dated 10. Jan., 9 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 750.

Henry atte Doole, son of Richard atte Doole of Askeby, John Gernegan, esq., sen., John Reppes of Heryngflete, William Boundes of Henstede, and others, demise to Edmund Waryn of Somerleton and Thomas Man of Lounde all their messuages, lands, &c. in Askeby which
they had by concession of Agnes Doole of Askeby, daughter of Edward Bonde. Dated at Askeby on the feast of the apostles SS. Peter and Paul, 10 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 751.
John de ... grants to Robert le Pene (?) of Askeby one acre and one rood of land in the village of Askeby. Dated at Askeby the Sunday next ... [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 752.
Robert Inglose, esq., grants to John Yatys his manor of Askeby, Co. Suffolk, together with the advowson of the church. Dated at Askeby, 20 September, 12 Ed. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 753.

John Baly of Gorleston, in performance of the last will of Thomas Colyn late of Lound, now deceased, enfeoffs Thomas Crote and others in five pieces of land lying in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 6 January, 12 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 754.

Henry Smyth alias Page of Somerleyton and John Smythalias Page of Jernyngham demise to Richard Hawkyne alias Crystynmasse of Somerleyton and others, certain pieces of land lying in the fields of Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 29 May, 1 Rich. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 755.

Indenture made at Somerleton, 8 Sept., 1485, between John Jernegan, esq., of the one part, and Giles Brewys, gentleman, of the other, witnesseth that the said Giles has granted to the said John one tenement in Askeby called 'Bukmongrs' and 32 acres of land for one year, at a rent of 33s. 4d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 756.

Indenture made at Somerleyton on St. Mary Magdalen's day, 1 Hen. VII, witnessing that for the consideration of 40 marks paid by John Jernegan, esq., to Gyles Brews, gent., he the said Giles will convey a tenement and 32 acres of land in Askeby. [English] (See MS. Ch. Suffolk 1130) MS. Ch. Suffolk 757.

Richard Hacone alias Crystynmasse of Somerleyton and John Nogge of the same grant to John Beuper (elsewhere written Bewpere) of Somerleyton and others a messuage and a croft and three pieces of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 20 May, 2 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 758.

Alice, who was the wife of [blank] Chirche, late of Wyndele, and before that, the wife of Robert Manwook of Becclys grants to Alice, who was the wife of William Nairnton, esq., widow of John Todenham of Somerlaton, and others, four pieces of land in the village of Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 1 May, 5 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 759.
John Jernegan grants to John Leverych of Borow, Robert Larke, and Robert Gappe certain land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 3 October, 7 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 760.
Richard Gowle of London and others demise to Thomas Owedon of Somerleyton and others two acres of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 27 February, 9 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 761.

Elizabeth Brews, widow of ... knt., Giles Brews, and others infeoff Richard Jernegan, esq.,
son of John, and others, with all their rents, services, lands, &c. in the villages of Askeby, Somerleton, &c. Dated at Askeby, 1 February, 1 4 Hen. VII. [Partly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 762.
Thomas Doole of Askby, yeoman, grants to Joan his wife and others his messuage and croft and six pieces of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 20 June, 14 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 763.

John Ravyngham and Peter Nabbys demise to John Tudenham and others a messuage, land, and a small enclosure lying in the fields of Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 14 April, [1?] Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 764.

William Jakson and John Gro... grant to John Johnes (?) and Mary his wife certain land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 23 June ... Hen. VIII. (c. 1510-120) [Mutilated and partly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 765.
John Walle of Askeby grants to Margery Boys, widow, and others, a tenement with a croft and three pieces of land in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 8 December, 7 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 766.

Katherine Wylton of Ashby, widow, remits and quit-claims to John Nabbys of Ashby and others, all her right in two pieces of ground and a tenement in Asshby. Dated 3 November, 22 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 767.
Gregory Nabbys of Lound, son and heir of Peter Nabbys, demises to John Sugges of Somerleyton and others two pieces of land in Assheby. Dated at Assheby, 30 January, 19 Hen. VIII, MS. Ch. Suffolk 768.

Draft of an indenture (mutilated) dated 25 Feb., .. (2 or 3 Hen. VIII), by which dame Elinor Jenney of Theberton demises to Peter Nabbys her manor of Askeby for vij years, from Mich(elmas) 2 Henry VIII next coming at an annual rent of vi marks. [Paper] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 769.
Ashby. Gregory, John and Robert Nobbus grant to Robert Jamesson of Theberton, William Ayliff, and others, a messuage and six pieces of land. Dated 10 November, .. Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 770.

John Manne, William Palmer, Robert Candler, Richard Watson, and Robert Swanne grant to John Jernegan, William Drury, Robert Drury, and John Appylton two pieces of arable land lying in a certain field called Wykerfeld in Asshby, co. Suffolk, in exchange for four pieces of land in Lound, co. Suffolk. Dated at Asshby, 20 January, 24 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 771.

Indenture dated 20 March, 25 Hen. VIII, between sir John Spelman, kt., of the one part, and sir John Jernegan, kt., of the other, reciting a proposed marriage between George Jernegan, esq., son of the above John, and Ela, one of the daughters of the said sir John Spelman, with settlement of lands in consideration of the same. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 772.

Final concord, dated at Westminster, June 26 Hen. VIII, by which John Jernegan and others are acknowledged by William Kingeston, kt., and
Mary his wife, to be the owners of the manor and advowson of Ashby, for which acknowledgment the said John and others gave £100 sterling. MS. Ch. Suffolk 773.

John Jernegan, knt., grants to sir Thomas Bedyngfeld, kt., and others, his manor, lands, rents, &c. in Asshby, Lound, and Heryngfleete, in accordance with a marriage settlement dated 20 March, 25 Hen. VIII, by which his son George is contracted in marriage to Ela, daughter of John Spelman, knt.. Dated 8 Sept., 26 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 774.
Sir John Jernegan, kt., confirms to Robert Skottowe of Askeby in exchange six pieces of land lying in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 16 March, 31 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 775.

Recital (?) of a grant by Margaret ... to her sister, Joan Moore, wife of Richard Moore, of all her right &c. in certain parcels of land lying in Askeby. Dated 4 October, 38 Hen. VIII. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 776.

Alicia and Agnes, daughters of Robert Skottowe late of Askeby, and sisters of Thomas Skottowe, deceased, sell to William Stanton of Somerleyton a messuage &c. in Askeby. Dated 10 June, 7 Ed. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 777.

Ralph Walle, son and heir of John Walle, late of Aldeby, deceased,, grants to Richard Meze of Askeby, sen., a messuage or tenement in Askeby. Dated at Askeby, 2 January, 3 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 778.
Illegible grant of land in Askbie from William Sygooze to John .... Dated at Askeby, 25 October, 21 Elizabeth. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 779.

Indenture dated 4 Oct., 33 Q,. Elizabeth, by which John Wentworth of Somerleyton, gent., demises to Thomazen Cowper of Asheby his fish-house in Ashby and his two ponds on the east part of the said house, and also a certain whorde called the old whorde belonging to the manor of Ashby, and the waters in Asheby, Heringflete, and Lound, for 10 years, for specified large quantities of fish, or else at an annual rent of 46s. 8d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 780.

Bond in £160 from Thomas Moore of Askeby, husbandman, to John Wentworth of Somerleyton for securing the sale of a tenement and certain lands in Askeby. Dated 6 October, 38 Q. Elizabeth. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 781.

Thomas Moore of Askeby, in consideration of £70, sells to John Wentworth, esq. of Somerleton the half of a tenement, croft and land in Askeby, and also the half of other pieces of land in Askeby. Dated 6 October, 1596. MS. Ch. Suffolk 782.

Thomas Jernegan, gent. and Elizabeth his wife of the parish of St. Martin Charing Cross, for a certain sum of money in hand paid, grant to John Jernegan of Somerleton, his brother, the whole of their capital messuage in Askeby. Dated 30 May, 18 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 783.

BACTON. Charter by which .... son of ... de Baketun grants and quit-claims to sir Simon Peche and his heirs, all right in a messuage and one acre of land in Baketun; for this quit-claim the said sir Simon gave 20s. of silver. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1237.

BARNEBY. Richard Grave (?) of Barneby grants to John Brufleth of Karleton, John Voculd (?) of Gusselham, and John Danyel of Karleton one inclosure lying in Barneby. Dated at Barneby the Saturday after the feast of SS. Vedastus and Amand, 45 Ed. III. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1238.

BARTON (Little). Robert de Hese, for the soul of king John &c., grants to the church of St. Edmund, and to the abbot and monks there, in frankalmoigne, the whole of his land in Bertun of the honor of Nottingham, namely that land which the said king John while he was earl Roreton gave to him, for an annual service of one hawk, and to the said Robert and his heirs of one pound of cummin, (c. 1220-30.) Among the witn., Adam de Phawskene, Wodard de Hwelvotham MS. Ch. Suffolk 34.

BARTON (Little). Robert Canewas grants to the church of St. Edmund and the monks there, in frankalmoigne, the whole of the water running between Midehale and Bertune, with the fishery which belongs to him and the two lashers, viz. of Lodemuthe and Kemesingeford; for this donation the convent of St. Edmund gave to him one mark of silver in aid of his peregrination. (c. 1210-20.) Among the witnesses, Bartholomew provost of the Hundred. MS. Ch. Suffolk 85.

Hugh atteHallegate of St. Edmund grants to Walter del Brasynof St. Edmund, for his fealty and service and 14s. of silver, one half acre of arable land in the fields of Bertone; paying annually for the same one penny. (c. 1240-50.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1239.

BARTON (Great). Indenture made between John de Gosford, the prior of St. Edmund of Bury, and convent of the same, at the time of a vacancy in the abbacy, of the one part, and John Overton of Multon of the other, witnesseth that the said prior and convent have demised to the said John their manor of Redewelle with 'le Cagehalle' in Bertone near St. Edmund, for 20 years, paying annually to the chamberlain of St. Edmund at Bury £10 for the first 10 years, and £12 for the last 10 years, with other conditions. Dated on the feast of St. Matthew, 6 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 109.

BARTON (Little). Ralph, son of Andrew Canewaz of Bertone, chaplain, grants to Peter, son of Geoffrey Canewaz, for his homage and service and 10 marks in hand paid, the whole of his messuage and lands lying in Bertone, and his fishery paying annually 15d. (c. 1260-70.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1242.

BARTON. Semann, son of Reginald de Berton, grants to Roger his son, for his homage and service, that toft in the village of Berton of his fee which lies between the parson's croft on the one part, and his own croft on the other, with the adjacent land, computed at 7 roods, which Peter, son of Osbert de Wridewell, clerk, held of same by the gift of Walter the chaplain, his uncle, and which the said Peter quitclaimed to him; also he grants to the said Roger 2 acres of his land in the fields of Berton; paying annually to the church of Berton 6d., and to him and his heirs 2d. (c. 1250-60.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1241.

Sir William de Gimi[n]gham, kt., grants to Walter, son of John de Geytune, his nephew, one messuage with a croft in the village of Bertone; paying annually for the same 3d. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1240.

BARTON. Grant from Andrew son of Walter Bryen of Bertone to Adam son of Bartholomew the Miller of Bertone, for 3s. of a part of his messuage at Bertone, paying yearly one penny. (c. 1240-50) [Fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 84.

BAWDSEY (?). Ranulf le Gardener of Baudris' grants to Cecilia, his daughter and heir, one piece of his arable land in the village of Baudris'. Dated at Baudris' the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Margaret, virgin, 21 Ed. I. [With seal.]
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1243.

BECCLES. Matilda, late wife of William Nicole of Beccles, spycer, appoints Richard, the parson of South Elmham, and William Uprych, her attorneys to deliver seisin in her name of one plot of land in Beccles, to John le Neve of Brundysh, chaplain, and John le Neve of Wylebeye. Dated at Hildircle, 17 May, 16 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1245.
Illegible grant of land in Beccles dated 17 [Richard II]?. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1247.

Declaration by several clergy, the parson of Becclys, Edmund Garneys, priest, Robert Grene, priest, Adam Fraunceys, priest, and others that certain evidence in a box under a part of their seals, relating to Robert Boys of Blunston and Joan his wife, are true and credible. Dated 30 March, 2 Rich. III. [Mutilated.] [On paper.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1249.

BECCLES and ENDEGATE. Composition between John Attezate, rector of Beccles, and John Stowe, rector of Endgate, concerning the tithes of the two villages of Beccles and Endgate. Dated at Beccles, 2 April, 1319. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1246.

BECCLES and LOUND. Katherine Rose, formerly wife of Thomas Rose of Becclis, confirms to sir William de Ely, parson of Becclis, Robert Lyster, and Roger atte Lee, all her messuages, lands, tenements, &c. in the villages of Becclis and Lounde. Dated at Becclis the Sunday next after the feast of St. Michael, 17 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1248.

BEESTON, co. Norfolk. Edmund Mortoft of Beston grants to John Coche of Cossay, sir Robert Clere, kt., and others, to the use of the said John, one tenement called Corpesties and land in Beston. Dated at Beston, 8 October, 1 2 Hen. VII. [With seal.] [See Norfolk, MS. Ch. Suffolk 12.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1244.

BELTON. Thomas Kempster of Burgh Castell, William Heden, and Robert Clerk of the same, demise and enfeoff Thomas Gilberd of Belton, Richard Pope and Thomas Sparhow, with the whole of their messuage formerly Henry Roger's, and two pieces of land, a grange, and 6 acres of land in 9 pieces in Belton. Dated at Belton, 12 December, 9 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 784.

Thomas Gylberd of Belton grants to Henry Plumsted of Great Jernemouth, Joan his wife, and others, all his messuages, lands, tenements, &c. in Belton, and appoints John Palmer and John Boys his attorneys to deliver seisin of the same. Dated 15 January, 20 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 785.

The order and award of Richard Jenkenson, Robert Glover, Charles Sucklinge, esquires, and Daniell Walters, gent., made 12 April, 19 James I, between William Langton, the president, and fellows of Magdalen College, Oxford, of the one part, and William Sydnor the younger of the other, respecting the manor of Caldecote Hall. [Partly illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1250.

Robert Sterne of Belton, for a sum of £50, sells to sir John Wentworth, knt., one messuage, with houses, lands, and tenements adjacent, in Belton. Dated 14 January, 6 Charles I 1630. MS. Ch. Suffolk 787.

Power of attorney to Thomas Bussye from Robert Sterne to give seisin to sir John Wentworth of Somerleyton, kt., in a messuage, house, lands, &c. in Belton. Dated 14 January, 6 Charles I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 788.

Release from William Osborne (?) concerning the sale of the above messuage, houses, and lands to sir John Wentworth, kt. Dated 14 January, 6 Charles I. [Partly effaced and slightly mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 789.

BELTON, GAPTON, BRADWELL, GORLESTON, and FRITTON. Thomas Grey of Theberton remits and quit-claims to John Wentworth of Somerleyton all his right &c. in all messuages, lands, tenements, &c. situated in the above parishes. Dated 24 December, 36 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 786.

PETTHAUGH, STONHAM ASPAL, and CROWFIELD. William Jorald of Debenham demises to John Kebyl of Caxston, John Cachepoll, senior, and Robert Laneman of Stonham, all those lands and tenements called 'Sowterys' lying in the villages of Pethaugh, Stonham Aspall, and Croffeld. Dated at Stonham Aspall on the feast of St. Gregory, 13 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1251.

BLITHING. Indenture dated 14 Feb., 1 Elizabeth, by which Robert Hopton of London, esq. demises to Anthony Lyngwood of Goddyngham, yeoman, the hundred of Blything with all its appurtenances for twelve years, at an annual rent of £40. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1161.

Simon Toppe of Causton and Simon Bonde of Blythyngg grant to Richard Dyggard of Blythyngg a piece of land in the parish of Blythyngg. Dated at Blythyngg the Monday next after the feast of Pentecost, 19 Rich. II.
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1162.

BLITHBURGH. Indenture dated 31 August, 29 Hen. VIII, by which Richard Freston of Mendham, esq., demises to John Hapton of Blythbourgh, yeoman, the parsonage of Blythbourgh for 56 years, paying for the same annually £6. Signed by Hapton. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1163.

Indenture made 1 October, 3 James I, by which John Wentworth of Somerleyton, esq., leases unto Felix Crane of Blithburgh and William Marks of Darsham, gent., his parsonage or benefice of Blithburgh for 10 years, at an annual rent of £45. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1164.

BLUNDESTON, &c. John, son of Robert de Lund, acknowledges that he owes to Roger, son of Osbert, and his heirs 12d., at the feast of St. Michael, for half an acre of land in the village of Blundeston. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 790.

Richard Randolf of the east village of Gernemuts grants to William de Gernemuta (Yarmouth), for his homage and service and 30s. in
hand paid, one piece of his land in Blundeston, paying annually to him and his heirs one penny. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 791.

William, son of John de Alneto (Dawney), grants to William, son of Osbert, his cousin, for his homage and service, the whole gift which William de Alneto his uncle had given to Osbert de Gurnemuta and Matilda his wife by his charter, viz. 60 acres of land and one alder-bed in Blundeston, also certain other lands there and in Flixton, together with his mill in Blundeston. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 792a.
John, son of William de Alneto (Dawney) of Flixtun, grants to William, son of William de Gernemuta, six acres of land in Ingg...lhstoft and Tuenacres. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 792b.

Robert, son of the parson of Blundeston, grants to Robert, son of William de Blundeston, two acres of land in Blundeston. Dated there the Monday next before the feast of St. Faith, 11 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 793.

Robert de Blundeston grants to Osbert, rector of Blundeston, John de Jernemut and Oliver de Wysete, certain lands and tenements in Blundeston, together with the advowson of the church. Dated there the Friday next after the feast of St. John ante port. Lat., 23 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 795.

John Sekysteyn of Blundeston grants to Nicholas his servant a messuage and a piece of land in Blundeston. Dated the Thursday next after the feast of SS. Fabian and Sebastian, 7 Rich. II. [Endorsement.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 796.

William Pygot of Blundeston grants to John Jernemuth of the same place one piece of land there, of one acre. Dated at Blundeston the Monday next after the feast of St. James, 13 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 797.
Thomas Donnyng of Blundeston grants to Bartholomew Clerk of the same place one acre of arable land in Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 24 December, 7 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 798.

Grant from Roger Colleman to Robert Balle of all the lands and tenements which he had conjointly with Adam Jackson, deceased. Dated feast of SS. Fabian and Sebastian, 1 Henry VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 799.

Roger Colman of Blundeston grants to Osbert Pygot of the same half an acre of land lying in the fields of Blundeston. Dated there on the morrow of St. Valentine, martyr, 1 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 800.
Henry Mathew of Blundeston grants to Bartholomew (?) Clare certain land in Blundeston. Temp. Henry II. [Mutilated and almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 801.
Robert Bucheman of Olton grants to Andrew Cok of Olton and others one piece of land in Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 12 March [?], 6 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 802.

Roger Mey of Blundeston grants to Joan, who was the wife of Thomas Benaere of Blundeston, all the lands and tenements which the said Roger, with Adam, son of the said Thomas now deceased, lately had by the gift and feoffment of the said Thomas, as is contained
in a certain charter made on the morrow of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist, 1 Hen. VI. Dated at Blundeston the Friday after the feast of St. Laurence, 7 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 803.
Illegible grant from Thomas Ben... to Robert Boys of Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston the Saturday next after the feast of St. Nicholas, bp., 9 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 804.

Indenture, reciting an intended marriage between Robert Boys, son of Robert Boys of Blundeston, and Joan Clerk, daughter of John Clerk of Galston, and a concession by Robert Boys , sen., to certain feoffees of half a messuage and six pieces of land in Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, [1 ?] Hen. VI. [See MS. Ch. Suffolk 1249.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 805.

John Cok , clerk, and William Estmore remit and quit-claim to Thomas Bolle, clerck, all their right in lands, rents, and services in the villages of Blundeston and Somerleyton, which they had conjointly with the said Thomas by feoffment of John Gernegan and others. Dated at Blundeston, 5 October, 12 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 806.

Margaret, late the wife of Robert Palgrave of Gunton, quit-claims to John Cok and John Yve , clerks, all her right to and in the advowson of the church of Blundeston granted to them by Thomas Bolle and Richard Rycher, clerks. Dated at Wykkelwode, 12 March, 16 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 807.

Indenture witnesseth that Nicholas Gunvile of Gorleston, esq., leases to John Stiwardeslond of Hemesby his manor of Blunston in Blunston, Suffolk, for 7 years at an annual rent of 7 marks 6s. 8d. Dated at Blunston on the feast of St. Michael, 3 Hen. VI, in die ... [With seal.] [Slightly mutilated and much rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 809a.

Richard Gleynesford of Sutton and Margaret his wife lease to Robert .... of Blundeston all those lands &c., which sometime were William Symson's, in Blundeston, for 4 years. Dated Michaelmas, 20 Hen. VI. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 809b.
John Gosmere and Margaret his wife grant to Robert Waryn of Somerleton a certain piece of marsh in Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 20 ... 20 Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 810.

Henry Zernemuth , gent., of Blundeston, and John Chapeleyn of the same place, grant to Robert Raylle of Elyngham, William Wynston, and John Crowe, one acre of land in Blunston. Dated at Blunston, 32 Hen. VI. (no date of day) MS. Ch. Suffolk 811.

Thomas Walpooll of Bungey remits and quitclaims to John Jernyngham of Somerleton, gent., all his right &c. in five acres of land in Blundeston. Dated at Somerleton on the feast of St. Luke the evangelist, 17 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 812.

Thomas Pye of Blundeston, son and heir of John Pye, grants to Thomas Dunnyng of the same place a curtilage called Mawtheldisyord and a piece of land lying in Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 16 January, 11 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 813.

John Pye of Blundeston, Christiana his wife, Roger Wynstone and Robert Boys demise to William Wymer of Gorton and Robert Stares of Blundeston all their lands, rents, &c. in the village of Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 2 ... 19 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 814.

Richard Caly of Holt, Norfolk, fuller grants to John Nodge of Somerleyton and others, lands, rents, &c in the village of Blundeston, which came to him on the death of his mother Elizabeth Caly. Dated at Blundeston, 2 [April] 7 Hen. VII. [See MS. Ch. Suffolk 822.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 815.

Indenture dated 18 May, 6 Hen. VII, by which (in consideration of a marriage between John Durhaunte , gent., and Elyne, sister of John Bryghtyeve) Dame Anne Wingefeld, widow, late wife of sir Robert Wingefeld, kt., covenants to make to John Durhaunte a good estate in the manor of Blundeston, and John Bryghtyeve covenants to pay to the said John and Elyne 24 marcs. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 816.

Indenture dated 6 Nov., 13 Hen. VII, by which Alys Wrentham, widow, grants to her son William Wrentham the tenement lately her husband's lying in Blundeston, paying to the said Alice 5s. MS. Ch. Suffolk 817.

Robert Boys late of Blundeston and John Nodge of Somerleyton enfeoff Robert Boys of Somerleyton and others in two pieces of land in the west field of Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 24 September, 15 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 818.
Thomas Boys and others grant to Roger Wynston and Robert Starys one messuage in Blundeston and eight pieces of land in Somerleyton. Dated at Blundeston, 10 October, 15 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 819.

John Pygot of Lowestoft, John Andrew of the same, Robert Jeton and Robert Hoddye grant to Milo Kerych, rector of Blundeston, Roger Wynston and Robert Stares, one messuage, 3 pieces of land, and 2cl. annual rent in Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 20 (?) March, 16 Henry VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 820.

Thomas Boys of Blunston, son and heir of Robert Boys grants to Robert Starys, Edward Wynston, William Wrentem, William Wynston, Henry Wynston, Henry Starys and William Necoll, one piece of land of 4 acres lying in Blunston. Dated at Blunston, 14 July, 23 Hen, VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 821.

Thomas Coppyn, clerk, and John Boys demise to Edward Jernegan, esq., William Jakson, clerk, William Copyldyk, clerk, Thomas Kipyng, Edmund Candeler and Edmund Wynstone, all those messuages, lands, and tenements, rents and services, &c. in Blundeston, which they with others had by the gift and concession of Richard Caly, as by his charter dated 2 April, 7 Hen. VII, more plainly appears. Dated at Blundeston, 20 March, 24 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 822.

William Arnold, next heir to Milo Kerych of Blondeston, clerk, demises to Edmund Wynston, Sibil his wife, Thomas Aleyn, clerk, William Nogge and William Wrentham, one garden &c. situated in Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 8 December, 10 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 823.

Robert Starys of Blundeston demises to Edmund Wynston, Sibil
his wife, and others (as in preceding deed) of Blundeston, two pieces of land and 2d. annual rent in Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 8 December, 10 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 824.

Thomas Maundell grants to William Wrentham, and others both of Blunston, at the request of William Arnold certain land in the fields of Blunston. Dated at Blunston, 20 July, 5 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 825.

Joan Nycoll, and Margaret and Joan, daughters of William Nycoll, deceased, confirm to John Lane alias Baley certain lands in Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 9 February, 16 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 826.

Final concord made at Westminster, morrow of all souls 20 Hen. VIII, in consideration of a sum of £240, John Scrope and Felicia his wife acknowledge the right of Robert Coke and William Roberts to the manor of Gunville Hall, 9 messuages, 302 acres of land, 16 acres of meadow, &c., in Blundeston. MS. Ch. Suffolk 827.
Fine dated 20 Hen. VIII. [A duplicate of MS. Ch. Suffolk 827.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 828.

William Wrentham of Blundeston grants to Umfrey Yermouthe, sen., and Umfrey his son, jun., two pieces of land in the west field of Blundeston. Dated at Blundeston, 2 February, 37 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 830.

Indenture dated 18 July, 28 Hen. VIII, by which John Jernegan of Somerleyton, kt., for £50 sterling, buys of John Jettour of Leystoft certain lands &c. in the parish of Blundeston. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 831.

Sir John Jernegan, kt., and George Jernegan, esq., his son, remit and quit-claim to John Jettor their manor called Gunvyles in the parishes of Blundeston, Flixton, Oulton, Gunton, and Gorton. Dated at Blundeston, 12 March, 29 Hen. VIII. [Copy on paper.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 832.

An arbitration and award in a dispute between Humphrey Yermouth, gent., and certain of the parishioners of Blundeston, as to the right to a certain marsh, water, and way. Dated 26 June, 30 Hen. VIII. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 833.

John Jettour of Leystoft grants to Humphrey Yermouth, gent., seven pieces of land in Blundeston, in exchange, and for £4.10. Dated at Blundeston, 5 .... 36 Hen. VIII. [Mutilated and partially illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 834.
Indenture dated 4 December, 1 Ed. VI, by which John Jetter of Leystoft bargains and sells to John Jernegan of Somerleyton, kt., two closes in the fields of Blundeston. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 835.
John Deeham of Blunston sells to Humphrey Yarmouth one piece of land in Clerys croft in Blunston. Dated 10 June, 4 Ed. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 836.

William Sydnor of Blundeston grants to Alice Woulcye of Lowestoft, widow of William Wrentham for her life an annuity of 26s. 8d., issuing from his lands &c. in Blundeston. Dated 7 June, . . Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 837.

Humphrey Yermouth of Soaterley grants to William Sydnor and his assigns for £40 and £960 the whole of the manor of Blunston. (here three times distinctly but wrongly written as "Elmiston") Dated 30 September, 12 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 838.
William Sydnor grants to Walter Jernegan and John Jenney his manor of Blundeston as trustees for certain uses. Dated 19 April, 13 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 839.
Humphrey Yarmouth of Hensted, co. Suffolk, remits and quitclaims to William Sydnor of Blundeston all right of action. Dated 2 August, 16 Elizabeth. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 373.

Richard Mighell, sen., lord of the manor of Flixton, in consideration of the payment of £26 13s. 4d., grants to John Wood two pieces of land containing 6½ acres called Flixton hall land in Blundeston. Dated 7 ... 21 Elizabeth. [Slightly mutilated and partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 841.

Richard Mighell, in consideration of the receipt of £6, remits and quit-claims to William Sydnor, his heirs and executors, all right to rents and customs of the manor of Flixton. Dated 11 November, .. Elizabeth. [Slightly mutilated and partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 842.
BOXFORD and GROTON. Robert Swayn of Stoke sells to Richard Walton certain lands &c. in the parishes of Boxford and Groton. Dated 10 December, 18 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 259.

Richard Walton of Boxford, clothier, sells and confirms to Henry Vintenor of Groton, clothier, a capital messuage, houses, lands, orchards, crofts, &c. situated in the parishes of Boxford and Groton. Dated 6 September, 31 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 260.

BOXSTEAD. Cecilia, daughter and heir of sir William Giffard, kt., jun., came here in court the Wednesday next after the octave of the Holy Trinity, and inrolled a charter dated at Boxstede the Monday next after the feast of St. Barnabas, 36 Ed. III, by which she quit-claimed to Stephen Bacoun and Beatrice his wife all her right in the manor with the advowson of the church of Boxstede and all the lands which they hold in Hertherst and Glemusford. MS. Ch. Suffolk 261.

BOYTON. Thomas, son of Osbert de Hopetune, grants to Roger, son of Osbert, and his heirs, all right in the whole of a tenement which Osbert his father possessed of the fee of the ancestors of the said Roger, in Boytune. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1252.

BRADMERE. Convention between Samson, the abbot, and Geoffrey the clerk, of Mildenhale, by which a messuage and certain lands lying in Bradmere are granted to the said Geoffrey. (c. 1190-1200.) Robert, prior, witness; died in 1200. [Partially obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 26.

BRADWELL. Alianora and Margaret, daughters of Seman Rokkes of Habelound, grant to Alicia, daughter of Seman Cabellowe of Habelound, and William her son, one piece of land in the parish of Bradwell. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 843.
Illegible deed, dated at Bradewell on the feast of St. Katherine, virgin, 18 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 844.

William Burgate, knt., Gilbert de Debenham, and others remit to John Gernegan of Somerleton all their right in certain land, and the advowson of the church of Bradwell, which they had by feoffment of the same. Dated at Somerleton, 6 Sept., 1 Hen. IV. [Mutilated.] [With 2 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 845.
Mutilated and in great part effaced charter, dated 6 March, 19 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 846.

John Hevenyngham, Edmund Wrigth, and others appoint John Deney and another their attorneys to deliver seisin of lands and tenements, with the advowson of the church of Bradewell. Dated at Bradwell the [Saturday after ?] the feast of the Invention of the Cross, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 847.
Edmund Bakoun, parson of the church of Gapton, grants to John de Gorliston all his lands and tenements in Bradewell and elsewhere. Dated ... Hen. VI. [In grat part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 848.

Katherine Boydon of Great Jernemuth grants to Richard Smyth of Redham a tenement and certain pieces of land in the village and field of Gapton alias Bradwell. Dated at Gapton, 21 Sept., 22 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 849.

Indenture made 6 May, 11 K. Henry VIII, by which sir William Skevyn, prest, and executor of the will of John Stonham late of Gorleston, sells to Henry Smyth of Bradwell certain messuages, land, &c. in Bradwell for a sum of £26 13s. 4d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 850.

Thomas and Henry Smyth grant to John Lavyle of Great Jernemuth, Rose his wife, who was formerly wife of John Lampett, esq., now deceased, John Harvy, Thomas Cotoyle, John Hakon of Whetacreburgh, William Adams of Gorlyston, William Shawe and John Barton of Jernemuth, all those lands, pastures, and woods lying in Little Yarmouth, Southtowne, and Bradwell, which they lately had by the gift of the said John Lampett and Rose his then wife. Dated at Bradwell, 1 July, 16 Hen. VIII MS. Ch. Suffolk 851.
John Barker of Bradwell sells to John Bucke of Sowthtowne one acre of arable land in Bradewell. Dated .... 29 Hen. VIII. [In most part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 852.

John Jernegan, esq., patron of the church of Bradwell, grants to Walter Jernegan, his brother, the right of patronage of the said church of Bradwell for the term of his life. Dated 29 September, 13 Elizabeth. [Torn and mutilated.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 853.
Robert Sutton of Bradwell sells to Henry Clyfford one piece of land in Bradwell. Dated 12 Nov., 31 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 854.

Presentation of Thomas Heche, clerk, to the church of Bradwell, by John Jernegan, esq., the patron, vacant by the death of James Aspinall. Dated 16 November, 38 Elizabeth. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 855a.

Thomas Caundyssh of Trymley St. Martin appoints John Elles and John Mellyn his attorneys to take seisin for him of certain lands in Gapton, Bradwell, &c, now in the tenure of William Roberds, esq. Dated 13 May, 31 Elizabeth. [English] [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 855b.
Robert Houghton of Itteringham, Norfolk, gent., sells unto William Umfrye of Bradwell, carpenter, for £20, a cottage in Bradwell. Dated .... October, 1613. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 856.

BRAMFORD. Walter de Reymes of Bromford grants to Alexander de Reymes of Burstalle, for his homage and service and for 2 marks of silver, one piece of land in the village of Bromford. (c. 1250-70) MS. Ch. Suffolk 519.
Christiana de Branford, widow, and Robert her son grant to Constantine for two years from 53 [Henry III] a piece of meadow land in the parish of Branford. [Much faded.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 520.

BBAMPSTON. Indenture between Adam Reyner, master of the hospital of St. James, Donewic, of one part, and John Crakenell of Bramston of the other, witnesseth that the master and brethren and sisters of the hospital have demised to the said John two pieces of land lying in Bramston for 30 years, at an annual rent of 2s. l0d. Dated on the feast of St. Mary Magdalen, 15 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 198.

Indenture made on the feast of St. Michael, 21 Henry VII, by which Adam Reyner, master of the hospital of St. James in Donwich, grants to James Davy of Bramston a messuage &c. in Bramston for a term of 76 years, paying yearly 10s. to the use of the said hospital. MS. Ch. Suffolk 199.

Nicholas, the prior, and convent of St. Mary of Woodbridge confirm to Robert Wyvyle, esq., an annual pension of £6 for his life, issuing out of the manors of Bramston, Neuburne, and Helmole, co. Suffolk; and if Beatrice, wife of the said Robert, should survive him, she to have a pension of 4 marks. Dated at Woodbridge, 10 August, 31 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 246.

Nicholas, the prior, and convent of Woodbridge grant to Robert Wyvyle, esq., a certain annual rent or pension of £6 sterling for the term of his life, issuing out of their lands &c. in the villages of Bramston, Neuburne, and Helmole. Dated at Woodbridge, 10 August, 31 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 247.

BRANDESTON. Walter de Ribof grants and confirms to the church of St. James of Dunwich and house of the lepers, and to Hubert, chaplain there, and his decessors, for the health of the soul of H. de Cressi and himself, &c., 40 acres of land in Brantest', together with other lands, rents, tithes, &c. (c. 1190-1200) [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 196a.

BRANDISTON. John de Hadeleye, prior of St. Mary, Woodbrigge, and the convent there, grant to John del Wode of Brandiston one piece of land in Brandiston. Dated at Wodebrigge the Friday next after the feast of St. John ante port. Lat., 24 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 245.

Edmund Lyster, master of the hospital of St. James, apostle, of Donawyc, and the brethren and sisters of the same place, grant to
farm to William Burnham of Earl's Soham a piece of land in the village of Brandyston, paying annually for the same 3s. 4d. Indenture made at Donewyc Monday in Pentecost week, 3 Hen. IV. [Fine seal, in drawer, of the Hospital., inscription broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 197.

William Bule of Branttestune grants to William Daco of Gretingham, for 7s 6d. all his right in two pieces of land in the village of Brantestune which Richard his father formerly held, from Roger Daco, father of the said William. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1253.

Henry, the prior, and convent of the church of B. Mary, Wodebregge, grant to Thomas de Bosco ('Wood') of Brandestone and Alice his wife for 20s. and paying annually two pence an old ditch ("foream") surrounding the messuage of the aforesaid Thomas and Alice, containing ten perches and ten feet, the perch containing 24 feet in width one foot. Dated at Brandeston the Wednesday next before the feast of St. Edmund, 35 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1254.

Power of attorney to Robert Cook, vicar of Brandeston, from William Walle, Thomas Chaumpnays, and John Wylde chaplain of Brandeston to give seisin of two pieces of land in Brandeston to John Barnagge, jun., and John Glewman, their heirs, &c. Dated at Brandeston the Sunday next after the Epiphany, 2 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1255.

John Chapman of Brandeston demises and confirms to John Wylde chaplain, William Grellyng and William Holm tenement Feverell in Brandeston with a close and field adjoining. Dated at Brandeston the Monday next before the feast of the Nativity of B. V. M., 6 Hen. VI "incipiente". MS. Ch. Suffolk 1256.

BRESETH. Exemplification by Robert prior of the Holy Trinity, Norwich, of a composition dated 5 Kalends June, 1259 between Stephen the prior and convent of Nobiliac in the diocese of Limoges, and John the prior and convent of St. Leonard, Bresethe, respecting the rights of the former house over the latter, including visitation every five yers, and a yearly pension of 10s.; with confirmation by the bishop of Norwich dated at Thefford 5 id. May 1310. Dated in the chapter-house of Bresethe, 17 Kl. August, 1310. (Robert, prior) MS. Ch. Suffolk 188

BROCKFORD. William Keyman of Brocford grants to Roger de Bertone, clerk, for 2s. 3d. the whole of the service that Thomas Gernun owed to him and his heirs, namely, three-pence from the fee of Peter de Hollegate, paying annually one halfpenny. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1257.

BRUSYARD. Bond entered into by Emma de Beauchamp, abbess, and convent of Brusyard, to Henry, bp. of Norwich, and his successors, to pay annually 13s. 4d., by reason of the appropriation of the church of Brusyard, and 12d to the prior and chapter of Norwich. Dated at Norwich, 15 June, 1390. MS. Ch. Suffolk 189.
BUNGAY. Will of John Undyrwode of Bungay, dated 16 May, 1473. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1258.

John Younges, senior, of Earsham, Norfolk in consideration of the receipt of £50, sells to Richard Burry of Bungay in Suffolk, butcher, a tenement called Gildings in Bungay, with a barn and curtilage adjacent. Dated 9 April, 6 Charles I, 1630. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1259.

BURGH-CASTLE, &c. Final concord made at Westminster, 12 Hen. VIII, between Thomas and Henry Smyth, querents, and John
Lampett and Rose his wife, deforciants, concerning two tofts, 50 acres of land, 3 acres of meadow, 6 acres of marsh, 3 acres of wood in Burgh Castell, Lovengland, Little Yermouth, Bradewell, &c. (Partly effaced.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 857.

BURY ST. EDMUND. Katherine, daughter of Norman of St. Edmund, grants and confirms to Peter de Nereford the whole of her messuage which was Norman's her brother, in the village of St. Edmund, as a free burgage, for two farthings to be annually paid to the sacrist, viz. that messuage which lies near the house of Arnald the priest towards the north; for this donation the sard Peter gave her 12 marks of silver 'in pleno porthmannemoth, and 'hostolagium' for herself and two servants in the said messuage for the term of her life. (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 7.

Walter, son of Robert Alebald de St. Edmund, grants to William, son of Huchtred de St. Edmund, for his fealty and service and 220s. of silver, one acre of arable land in the fields of St. Edmund. (c. 1190-1200.) [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 11 .

Geoffrey, son of William de Costentin, grants to John his brother the whole of his portion of the land and tenements which their father William held in the villages of St. Edmund and Richingehale. (c. 1180-1190.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 12.

Concession and confirmation by king John to the abbot and monks of St. Edmund, that no market or fair shall be held within the liberties of St. Edmund to their injury. Dated at Loches, 17 August, 3 John. MS. Ch. Suffolk 14.

Adam, son of William the armiger of St. Edmund, grants to Ailwin Lenarius of St. Edmund, for his fealty and service and 2s. of silver, part of his toft without the village of St. Edmund lying at Tewene, at an annual rent of 3d. (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 17.

Alwine Lanar[ius], son of Gocellin de Hemmegrave, sells and quitclaims to Stephen, son of Humphrey, for 10s., the whole of his toft in the suburb of St. Edmund lying at Teyuene, making the service to the chief lords of the fee, viz. to the cellarer of St. Edmund 3d yearly. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 18.

Alan and the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter without the gate of Risebi grant to the brethren of the hospital of St. Nicholas one rood of land which Adam de Hopetun gave to the said brethren, paying annually ½lb of cummin. (c. 1210-20.) Witn. Adam de Falesham, Wdard son of Elias, etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 28.

Norman Treietarius of St. Edmund grants to the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter in the suburb of St. Edmund, in frankalmoigne, 2d. of annual rent from an acre of arable land in the fields of St. Edmund lying towards Teyvenne. (c. 1220-30.) Witn. Stephen fitz Ralph, alderman of St. Edmund, and Martin de Bertune and Thomas fitz Ralph, provosts MS. Ch. Suffolk 29.

Adam, son of Hervey de Hopetun, grants to God, St. Mary and St. Peter, and the infirm brethren of St. Eudmund, viz. of the house of St. Peter, that land which Andrew the janitor of St. Edmund was accustomed to hold, except one rood which Adam gave to the brethren of St. Nicholas in frankalmoigne; also he gives to them ½lb of cummin which the brethren of St. Nicholas were accustomed to pay him. (c. 1210-20.) Witn. Adam provost of St. Edmund, Wdard mayor, etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 30.

Convention made in the village of St. Edmund, in full "portmaneiot", before Adam de Phalelham then provost, and others, by which Isabella, daughter of Walter Gochep, gave to the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter, for five marks one acre of arable land opposite the hospital in the fields of St. Edmund, in exchange for one acre of arable land with a meadow adjacent in the fields of the same vill, "extra portam del Su", viz. that which master Abbraham gave to the said brethren of St. Peter in frankalmoigne. (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 31.

Walter Tighethe, son of Robert de St. Eadmund, grants to the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter, in frankalmoigne, an annual rent of 5½d., viz. from an acre of laud which Lemman 'ferrator' held of him 1½d., and from an acre which Richard Brun held 2d., and from William, son of Huttred, 2d. (c. 1210-20.) Witn. Adam de Falesham, provost of St. Eadmund, Wodart son of Elyas alderman etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 32.

Richard de la Care, the prior, and brethren of the hospital of St. Nicholas without the east gate of St. Edmund, grant and quitclaim to the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter all their right in a fourth part of one acre of arable land called 'Holdefader acre' lying at Dristnapes, which they had by the gift of Thomas de Canter of St. Eadmund; for this grant the said brethren of St. Peter gave 6s. of silver. (c. 1220-30.) Witn. Stephen alderman of St. Eadmund, Martyn de Bertune provost, etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 33.

Memorandum of the election of Richard de Lisle, abbot of Burton, to the abbacy of Bury St. Edmund, vacant by the resignation of Hugh de Northwold on his election to Ely. [Abbot 1229-1234.] [Printed by Hearne, in Chron. Dunstable, vol. II. p. 837, as a note to vol. I. p. 185.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 37.

Silvester de St. Edmund grants to the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter, in frankalmoigne, the whole of his toft in the village of St. Edmund which Walter Hodles sold him, making the service due for the same to the lords of the fee, viz. to the sacrist of St. Edmund 3s. and to the heirs of Umfrid, son of Richard 12d. (c. 1260-70.) Witn. Geoffrey the alderman, Richard de Mildenhale and Richard de Pulham, bailiffs. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 40.

Return of a jury in a dispute between the abbot and convent of St. Edmund and the prior and convent of Ely, concerning the right to the fishery of 'la Kyng leche,' in favour of the prior and convent of Ely; together with a fine levied at .... St. John the Baptist's day, 29 Hen. III, by which the prior and convent of Ely remit and quit-claim all their right in the said fishery to the abbot and convent of St. Edmund. [Partially effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 41.

Robert, son of William Branche of St. Edmund, grants to Alexander the spicer, in marriage with Margaret his sister, a certain shop with a solar which is in the Cordwainers' Street in St. Edmund, and two acres of arable land, paying 9d. yearly to the hospital of St. Peter. (c. 1230-40.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 46.

Margaret, relict of Alexander the spicerer of St. Edmund, quitclaims to the prior and brethren of the hospital of St. Peter for 8 marks all right in two acres of arable land in the fields of St. Edmund. (c. 1260-70.) Witn. Geoffrey Fitz-Robert, alderman, Jocey de Walpole and Richard de Pulman, bailiffs, etc. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 47.

Wydo, son of Henry de St. Edmund, and Avicia his wife grant to
the hospital of St. Peter, in frankalmoigne, 3d. of annual quit-rent from a certain toft in the village of St. Edmund. (c. 1220-30.) Witn. Stephen Fitz-Ralph, alderman, Martin de Bertune and Thomas Fitz-Ralph, provosts etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 59.

Lucas the chaplain, son of Reginald de Fordham, grants to the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter without the gate of Riseby of St. Eadmund, 1d. of annual rent which he received at Easter of the heirs of Hugh Palmer of St. Eadmund, for one acre of arable land called 'Fordham acre' in the fields of St. Eadmund. Witn. John son of Luke, alderman William de Feretro and Richard de Pulham, bailiffs, Adam Wuderd, Robert (c. 1260.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 61.

Mabilia, relict of Baldewyn de Sympling, remits and quit-claims to the prior and brethren of the hospital of St. Peter all right by name of dowry in three acres of arable land in the fields of St. Edmund towards the west, which the said prior acquired of the executors of the said Baldewyn, formerly her husband. (c. 1260-70.) Witn. Geofrey son of Robert alderman, Richard de Pulham and Jocey de Walpole, bailiffs MS. Ch. Suffolk 62.

Walter le Mercer bequeaths to the brethren and infirm of the hospital of St. Peter the half of the rent which lies between his house and the house of Tomas le Gaunter, for keeping a certain light burning daily at mass, viz. three halfpence. (c. 1240.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 63.

Thomas de Marsh "Marisco" of St. Edmund, clerk, grants to sir Gilbert de Pillekoc, master of the hospital of St. Peter, for half a mark, sixpence annual rent from a messuage in St. Edmund in the street called 'Longebrakelond.' Witn. Geoffrey fitz-Robert alderman, Nicholas fitz-Fulk and John le Blunt, bailiffs (c. 1260-70.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 66.

Mabel, formerly wife of Baldewyne de Symplinge, Ralph Hereward, Roger Sumer, and Roger de Lausel, executors of the will of the said Baldewyne, deceased, sell to the prior and brethren of the hospital of St. Peter, for 11 marks of silver, three acres of arable land in the fields of St. Edmund towards the west. Witn. the same as MS. Ch. Suffolk 47. (c. 1260-70.) [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 68.

Alexander Brun of St. Edmund grants to Robert, the prior, and brethren of the hospital of St. Peter, for 40s. three roods of arable land lying in the field of St. Edmund, at Aylmerescroft. (c. 1270-75.) Witn. Geoffrey Fitz-Robert alderman Richard de Pulham and Jocey de Walepole, bailiffs. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 70.

Lecia, relict of William le Juvene, releases to the prior and brethren of the hospital of St. Peter all right and claim in one acre of arable land in the field of St. Edmund. (c. 1260-70.) Witn. Geoffrey son of Gilbert (sic) alderman Richard de Pulham and Jocey de Walepole, bailiffs [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 72.

Alexander Brun of St. Edmund grants to [Robert the provost] and the hospital of St. Peter for 40s. three roods of arable land lying in the field of St. Edmund, at Aylmerescroft; paying annually to him and his heirs one clove, and to the Gilda Mercatorum of St. Edmund 2d. (c. 1270-75.) Witn. Geoffrey, alderman Richard de Pulham and Gocey, provosts. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 78.

Robert le Rus of St. Edmund grants to Nicholas de Neketune, burgess of St. Edmund, for his fidelity and for 7 marks in hand paid, 9s. of annual quit-rent from a shop in the street called 'La Rue Marchaunde.' (c. 1250-60.) Witn. William de Carge and Jocey de Walepole, bailiffs Geoffrey fitz-Robert alderman. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 79.

William Trussebut, glover, of St. Edmund, and Margery his wife grant to John de Pastone, vintner, of the same town, for 14 marks one messuage in St. Edmund in the street which is called 'le Mustowe,' at an annual rent to the sacristan of St. Edmund of 32 pence of silver for all services. (c. 1270.) Witn. Geoffrey fitz-Robert alderman, Luke fitz-John and Geoffrey de Eli, bailiffs. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 80.

Basilia, wife of Alexander Brun of St. Edmund, quit-claims to the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter without the gate of Rysseby, and Robert the warden those three roods of arable land which her husband granted to them in the field of Aylmerecroft. (c. 1270-75.)
[With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 81.

Adam, son of Walter de Westle, grants in frankalmoigne to the hospital of St. Peter 9d. quit-rent from a toft with buildings in the suburb of St. Edmund without the gate of Ryseby. (c. 1260-70.) Witn. Geoffrey alderman, Richard de Pulham and Jocey de Walepole, bailiffs, Luke fitz-John etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 82.

Alan, called the prior, and convent of the hospital of St. Peter grant to the brethren of the hospital of St. Nicholas the whole of the tithe which belonged to them from the land which Adam de Hopetun gave in frankalmoigne to the said hospital of St. Nicholas, paying annually to the hospital of St. Peter five-pence. (c. 1220-30.) Witn. master Hervey, Adam le Phalesham, master Gilbert, Wodard son of Elyas, etc. (Chirograph.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 83.

Richard, son of Katherine of St. Edmund, grants to Robert, the prior, and the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter all right to 6d. annual rent which he was accustomed to take from the said brethren for one acre of arable land in Hamerlound. (c. 1260-70.) Witn. Geoffrey, alderman, William son of Bartholomew and William da Walepole, bailiffs Adam de Westle, etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 84a.
