Convention made between Robert, the prior, and the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter without the gate of Risseby of the town of St. Edmund, of the one part, and Adam de Cokefeud of the other, by which the said prior and brethren demise one shop in the town of St. Edmund, in the way called Schapmannisrowe, for 10 years from Michaelmas 1 Ed. I, at an annual rent of 3s. Witn. Geoffrey son of Robert alderman, Luke son of John, bailiff etc. (Chirograph.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 87.

Convention between Richard, abbot of Bury St. Edmund, and Sir Ralph Bockyng, about the sub-stewartship of the abbey. [Sir John de being steward] [Temp. Ed. I.] (c. 1312?) (See Roberts' Calendarium Genealogicum, II. 633. 20 Edw. I. Abbot Richard was elected in 1312.) [Mutilated and much effaced.] [French] MS. Ch. Suffolk 89.

John de Brolkleye of St. Edmund, baker, grants to the hospital of St. Peter 4s. of annual rent from his capital messuage situated in Wellestrete in St. Edmund. Dated at St. Edmund the Wednesday next before the feast of St. Valentine, 2 Ed. I. [Spurious.] (Probably written about 1400. Dated (as above) "anno regni regis Edwardi primi") Witn. Stephen de Ecclesia, alderman, John de Lincolnia, bailiff MS. Ch. Suffolk 90.

Convention dated on the vigil of St. Matthew, apostle, 6 Ed. [I], between the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter of the one part, and Adam de Cokefeud, merchant, of the other, viz. that the said brethren grant to the said Adam, for his fealty and service and 4s. of silver, one shop in St. Edmund in the street called Chapmannisrowze, paying annually for the same 30 pence, to the heirs of Thomas de Backyrgges 30 pence, and to the bailiffs of the town one penny. Witn. Geoffrey son of Robert, alderman William son of Bartholomew and William de Walpole, bailiffs. MS. Ch. Suffolk 91.

John de Rammesdene of St. Edmund grants to Thomas, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund, in frankalmoigne, 2s. of annual rent from his messuage in 'le Eldemarketestede' of St. Edmund, to be distributed among the monks "dies qua duplex sonittus in adventu Domine cum missarum sollempnitate celebratur". Dated at St. Edmund the Friday next after the feast of St. Matthew, 33 Ed. I. (Fine deeds, written in large hand). Witn. Edmund son of Luke de St. Eadmund, William de Gypwic, and Laur. de Reda, bailiffs, etc.. MS. Ch. Suffolk 94.

Geoffrey, son of William de Tostoke, and Margaret his mother, widow grant to Stephen de Wrotham, for his fealty and service and 4 marks and 4s. of silver, which he gave them to eneble them to fulfil the will of the said William, two acres of arable land called Tuptys in the fields of St. Edmund lying towards the little mill, paying annually to the heirs of Peter Marescall two pence. (c. 1250-60.) Witn. John son of Luke alderman, Ralph de Anhus, and Thomas de Boeringe, bailiff. MS. Ch. Suffolk 95.

Gilbert de Neketone of St. Edmund grants to Ralph de Mildenhale 9s. of annual rent in the village of St. Edmund, from a shop situated in the street which is called 'La Rue Marchaunde.' Dated at St. Edmund the Friday after the feast of the Nativity of St. John B., 4 Ed. II. Witn. John de Ingham and John de Lyncoln, bailiffs, Thomas le Cornur, alderman. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 98.

Richard Vileyn of St. Edmund grants and confirms to Thomas de Swanitone, keeper of the hospital of St. Peter without the gate of Rysby of St. Edmund, and the brethren there, 12d. of annual rent from a messuage in St. Edmund in the street called Scolehallestrete. Dated at St. Edmund the Monday next after the feast of St. Matthew, 18 Ed. II. Witn. Stephen de Ecclesia, alderman, John de Lincoln, bailiff etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 100.

Roger Baldwyne of Stowemercat grants to William de Bernigham of St. Edmund one messuage with edifices and appurtenances in the village of St. Edmund in the merchants' street (Vicus mercatorum). Dated at St. Edmund the Monday next after Michaelmas, 9 Ed. III. Witn. Robert de Paston, alderman Henry Paux and John de Heunigham, bailiffs, etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 102.

Andrew Shurkyld of Northwold grants to William de Waketon, Geoffrey de Caverham and Alan Gdene of Swanton, chaplains and brethren of the hospital of St. Peter one acre of land in the fields of the town of St. Edmund without the gate called Rysby gate. Dated at St. Edmund the Thursday next after the feast of the Epiphany, 14 Ed. III. Witn. [Richard] de Waltham and John de Honyngham, bailiffs etc. MS. Ch. Suffolk 104.

William Maymond, master of the hospital of St. Nicholas of St. Edmund, and the brethren there, grant to Alan, son of Alan Grene of Swanton, one acre and one rood of land lying in the fields of the town (ville) of St. Edmund, in a place called 'le Spynthelfeld', in exchange for an acre without the east gate.
Dated at St. Edmund the Tuesday on the feast of the Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin, 17 Ed. III. Witn. Ralp. le Taillour, alderman, Richard de Wellham and John de Honyngham, bailiffs MS. Ch. Suffolk 105.

William Blounvyle grants and quit-claims to sir Thomas de Morieux', kt., Ralph, son of Ralph de Bokkyngge, and William Suklyng, chaplain, all right and claim in a messuage in the village of St. Edmund, which he had by the gift of Ralph de Bokkyng, knt. Dated at St. Edmund the Thursday after the feast of St. Gregory, 31 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 108.

William Draghton of Bury St. Edmund and others confirm to Edward Woderton, Alice his wife, and Thomas Bernyngham, one tenement in the village of Bury in the street called le Heyestrete. Dated at Bury aforesaid the Wednesday before the feast of St. Luke, evang., 21 Rich. II. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 111.

Indenture witnessing that whereas Ralph Bayle of Bury St. Edmund, draper, has granted to Henry Kyrton of Bury aforesaid and Agnes his wife one tenement in the village of Bury St. Edmund, in the street called le Heyestrete, it is on condition of their paying during two years without the delay of a single day at stated periods 8 marks and 10s. (c. 1390-1400.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 112.

Richard Goldsmyth of Bury St. Edmund grants to Walter Burton, clerk, master of the hospital of St. Peter, one garden lying in Maydewater lane in Bury aforesaid. Dated at Bury St. Edmund the Wednesday on the feast of St. Valentine, 4 Hen. IV. Witn. Roger Frampton, alderman, Laurence Trussbut, and Robert Somerton, bailiff. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 113.

John Bonde, chaplain, grants to William Lelye and Agnes his wife three cottages in the town of Bury St. Edmund, in the street called 'Oldsbaxsteristrete'. Dated at Bury St. Edmund the Sunday next after the feast of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist, 12 Hen. IV. Witn. William Methewold, alderman, Ralph Chaunberleyn and Robert Sonwetone, bailiffs. MS. Ch. Suffolk 114.

Indenture witnessing that whereas William Warde of Bury St. Edmund, chaplain, grants and by a certain charter confirms to John Rothe, brasier and Richard Rothe of Carleton, clerk, two tenements within the borough of Bury St. Edmund, near the great market-place, viz. in 'le Smytherowe,' they are bound to the payment of £20 by certain instalments. Dated at Bury St. Edmund, 8 January, 4 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 115 .

William Warde of Bury St. Edmund, chaplain, grants to John Rothe, brasier and Richard Rothe, clerk two tenements in Bury St. Edmund in 'le Smytherowe', near the great market-place. Dated at Bury aforesaid, 8 January, 4 Hen. V. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 116 .

William Leyr of Bury St. Edmund, mason, Ralph Reward and Stephen Gardyner demise and assign to Thomas Bolesham of Bury aforesaid, Roger Messager, William Rycher, John Smyth, John Gouty, and Roger Gardyner, a certain tenement with three messuages and four pieces of arable land within the borough of Bury St. Edmund, in the streets called 'Lombislane' and 'Th'ustowe.' Dated at Bury aforesaid, 26 Nov., 18 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 117.

Robert Crench of Bury St. Edmund, cordwainer,, executor of the will of Bartholomew Chapeleyn, "cotyller,", confirms to John Stonhard, John Wherham, and George Burton, one grange with a curtilage in the vill of Bury aforesaid, in the street called Overabaxterestrete. Dated at Bury aforesaid the last day of June, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 118

Robert Crench of Bury St. Edmund remits and quit-claims to John Stonhard and others all right in a certain grange with a curtilage in the village of Bury aforesaid. Dated at Bury aforesaid the last day of June, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 119.

Isabella Gosselyn and Margaret Gosselyn of Bury St. Edmund grant to John Stonhard, John Wherham, and George Burton, of Bury aforesaid, one tenement situated in the village of Bury St. Edmund. Dated at Bury aforesaid, 20 May, 24 Hen. VI. Witn. John Smyth, alderman, Thomas Heigham and John Curteys, bailiffs. [With seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 120.

Bury St. Edmund John Baret, esq., acknowledges to have received, for himself and John Lydgate, monk of Bury St. Edmund, of William Tyrell, sheriff of Norfolk and Suffolk, £3 16s. 8d. of that £7s. 13s. 4d. which the king by letters patent granted to them for the term of their lives. Dated 2 October, 25 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 121.

Memorandum of the receipt by John Boone, abbot of Bury St. Edmund, by the hands of Thomas Cresse, bailiff of Edward Doyle, 26s. 9½d. for the rent of la Pondehill and Gosford for one whole year. Dated on the feast of St. Edmund the King, 34 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 122.

Indenture by which William Stowe, master of the hospital of St. Nicholas of Bury St. Edmund, with the assent of his brethren, demises to William Somere of Bury, taylor, a tenement in Bury in the street called Estgatestrete for 98 years, at an annual rent of 3s. Dated at Bury, 5 February, 38 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 123.

Edmund Lerlyn of Bury St. Edmund, Agnes his wife, Edmund Baker, weaver, David Humfrey, baker, and Robert Totay, "corvoser" demise to Robert Drake and Matilda his wife, John Aylewyn, weaver, Thomas Turnour, carpenter, and Thomas Barry, a messuage, way and garden within the town of Bury aforesaid, in the street called Overbaxterestrete alias Wellestrete, on condition of payment of £6 at fined times during five years. Dated at Bury St. Edmund, 16 September, 14 Ed. IV. Witn. Thomas Gret, alderman, Thomas Heigham, esq. and William Helperby, bailiffs. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 126.

John Clopton, esq., William Thweyte, senior, gent., and Thomas Bunnyng, mercer, demise to John Coote, gent. and Margaret his wife, of Bury St. Edmund, one tenement late John Skeet's situated within the borough of Bury St. Edmund, in the street called 'Hennecotestrete' alias 'Bernewellestrete' viz. between a messuage late William Coote's and a lane called 'Bryceslane;' also another messuage in the same town and street. Dated at Bury St. Edmund, 9 March, 18 Ed. IV. Witn. Walter Thurston, alderman, Thomas Meigham, jun., esq. and William Helperby, bailiffs MS. Ch. Suffolk 127.

Edward Caster, clerk, Thomas Ampe, clerk, Henry Davy of Fornham All Saints, Thomas Sporle, chaplain, Henry Hardman, clerk, William Thweytt, senior, gent., and Thomas Edon, gent. demise to John Page of Bury St. Edmund, chaplain, George Watton, chaplain, John Page, senior, of Walsham, William Coppynger, woolman and Roger Leynge, fuller, one messuage and all that belongs to it within Bury St. Edmund, in the street called 'Cherchegonelstrete.' Dated at Bury aforesaid, 24 Sept., 20 Ed. IV. Witn. Thomas Heigham, jun., esq. and William Helperby, bailiffs MS. Ch. Suffolk 128.

Will of Katherine Ofhoo of Bury St. Edmund, widow, made 12 January, 1483, bequething the greater part of her property to her daughter Agnes Polstade. Probate dated last day of February, 1493. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 129.

Robert Drake of Bury St. Edmund, carpenter, Matilda his wife, Thomas Turnur, a carpenter, and Thomas Barry, "corvorser" demise to John Mannyng, labourer, Thomas Pykerell, yeoman, Robert Smyth, yeoman and William Talyes, butcher, a certain messuage in Bury aforesaid, in the street called Overbaxterestrete alias Wellystrete. Dated at Bury St. Edmund, 23 December, 10 Hen. VII. [With 2 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 131.

Thomas Purdon of Redgrave, John Hamelyn of Weston, and Thomas Lovesson of Bury grant to Thomas Turnur of Bury and Margaret his wife, John Hegge, Robert Turnur, William Lawnde and William Bulbroke, two messuages in the village of Bury St. Edmund, in the street called 'Estgatestrete', paying yearly 8/8d. for 22 years. Dated at Bury aforesaid, 6 February, 2 Rich, III. Witn. Thomas Heigham, esq., and William Helperby, bailiffs. MS. Ch. Suffolk 130.

Statement by an abbot respecting the original appointment and duties of the steward of the franchises and liberties of the abbot of Bury St. Edmund, with complaint of neglect and of wrongs suffered thereby, (one word illegible) bailiff and sub-bailiff almost beaten to death at Sudbury, others taken from Chevington and imprisoned at Bury, etc. [Temp. Hen. VI.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 134.

Indenture made 23 March, 7 Hen. VII, witnesseth that Robert Crane hath delivered to Thomas, the abbot of Bury St. Edmund, collector of the benevolence granted to the king in the shire of Suffolk towards his voyage royal into France, £212 16s. 4d. collected within the hundred of Babergh. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 135.
Will of William Bataly of Bury St. Edmund, dated 20 October, 1500. Probate dated the Tuesday on the feast of St. Wulstan, bp., 1500. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 136.

Thomas, son and heir of Thomas Purdy late of Redgrave, remits and quit-claims all his right in two messuages in the borough of Bury St. Edmund in the street called Estgatestrete to Thomas Godard of Bury aforesaid. Dated 4 January, 20 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 139.

Thomas Parker of Bury St. Edmund, fishmonger, grants to Richard Frost, chaplain, one tenement, one parcel of a certain house, with a garden and parcel of land in Bury aforesaid in the street called Whitingstrete. Dated at Bury St. Edmund, 8 March, 22 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 140.

An acquittance dated 4 March, 1 Henry VIII, given by sir John Gye, cellarer of the abbey of Bury St. Edmund, to George Plesaunce, for all manner of reckonings between them before Mich. last. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 141.

Robert Worlyche of Bury St. Edmund, mason, Reginald Lerlynge, tiler, John Robynson, carpenter, and John Selond, smith, executors of John Busshe, mason, demise to Katherine Busshe, widow, Thomas Browne, chandler, and John Cracheroode, scrivener one messuage, a garden, and certain land in Bury aforesaid, in the street called 'Gyldehalstrete.' Dated at Bury St. Edmund, 16 January, 10 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 143.

Robert Sttlyard, clerk, demises to Margery Draper of Bury St. Edmund, widow of John Batys and others a tenement in Bury St. Edmund in the street called Chirchegatestrete, conveyed to him by the said Margery by deed dated 10 Sept. in the same year. Dated at Bury aforesaid, 15 Sept., 13 Hen. VIII. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 144.

Thomas Heryes, yeoman, Henry Tame, Henry Gunse, and George Langham confirm to John Mower of Bury, thatcher, John Reche, thatcher, Richard Dowsyng, Thomas Mower, and William Halle one tenement situated in the vill of Bury St. Edmund, in the street called 'Overbaxterstrete.' Dated at Bury aforesaid, 16 October, 12 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 145.

Thomas Heryes, Henry Tame, Henry Gunse, and George Langham grant to John Skitlard of Bury, labourer, John Arnolde, carpenter, Robert Sketlard, John Mower, and Thomas Mannyng one tenement in the village of Bury St. Edmund, in the street called 'Overbaxsterstrete' Dated at Bury aforesaid, 16 October, 12 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 146.

Final concord made at Westminster on the morrow of [All] Souls, 18 Hen. VIII, by which Nicholas Sywhat and Katherine his wife acknowledge the right of Robert Jamys, citizen and alderman of
Norwich, Robert Germy, and William Wyburgh to six messuages, 2 barns, 2 gardens, 8 acres of pasture, and one acre of wood in Bury St. Edmund and Nowton near Bury aforesaid. MS. Ch. Suffolk 147.

Christopher Lant, master of the hospital of St. Peter and house of the lepers, and brethren of the same appoint Edmund Hurste their proctor and special nuncio to ask and collect in their name throughout England alms and charity for the leprous of the hospital of St. Peter aforesaid. Dated 7 April, 30 Hen. VIII. 1539. MS. Ch. Suffolk 151.

Indenture made 31 January, 34 Hen. VIII, by which John Swanton and Robert Sharpe, supervisors of the lands and tenements of late Margaret Odeham of Bury St. Edmund, with the assent of the alderman and brethren of the guild of the Purification of our Lady, have demised to Thomas Creme, brewer a piece of land in Bury aforesaid in the field called Westgatefeld for 20 years, at an annual rent of 3s. 4d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 154.

Nicholas Sywhat, citizen and alderman of Norwich, grants to William Garton of Great Jernemuthe 4 messuages and one barn with edifices and appurtenances in Bury St. Edmund, of which one messuage and the barn called 'the moone' lie in the street called Netemarket, and another messuage in the street called 'Oldebaxterstrete,' and the two others in the street called Overbaxsterstrete alias Wellestrete, and he appoints William Rogers, citizen and alderman of Norwich, his attorney to deliver seisin of the same. Dated at Bury St. Edmund, 26 March, 32 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 155.

Indenture made 1 June, 35 Hen. VIII, by which Robard Sharpe, and John Swanton, supervisors of lands &c. of late Margaret Odeliam, now belonging to the guild of the Purification of our B. Lady, demise to Nicholas Avies, the elder roughmason, four pieces of arable land containing by estimation 16 acres in Bury St. Edmund, for 21 years, at an annual rent of 20s, with consent of the alderman Dye and brethren of the gild. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 156.

Indenture made 1 July, 35 Hen. VIII, by which Robert Sharpe, tallowchandler of Bury St. Edmund, and John Swanton, brewer, keepers of the lands and tenements of Candlemas Guild, demise to Thomas Lacy of Bury St. Edmund a messuage in the Marketsted of Bury aforesaid, for 20 years, at an annual rent of 33s. 4d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 157.

John Eyer, esq., sells to John Regate "(K?)ommer" the whole of a tenement and garden in the village of Bury St. Edmund in the street called Scolehalstrete within the parish of St. Mary, and a garden in Reyngate strete in the same parish of St. Mary. Dated 21 November, 37 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 158.

Robert Hanham of Bury St. Edmund, gent., grants to John Cutteris of the same, yeoman, three tenements in the borough of Bury aforesaid, in the street which is called Wellestrett alias Overbaxstrett. Dated at Bury St. Edmund, 12 May, 37 Hen. VIII. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 159.

Indenture made 17 April, 1 Ed. VI, by which Robard Sharpe and Nicolas Avys the elder, supervisors of the lands and tenements given
to the town of Bury St. Edmund by Margaret Odam, gentylwoman, according to the will of the said Margaret, have demised to William Parke of Bury, mercer, a shop with a soeler in the Fyshmarket for 21 years, at an annual rent of 8s. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 160.

Agnes Illyon of Bury St. Edmund, single woman, in co. Suffolk, grants for a sum of £18 to Margaret Tyrell of Wetherden, widow, one messuage situate in Bury aforesaid, between a messuage lately Henry Wisshe's on the north and a lane on the south, and abutting towards the east upon the street called Churchegovellstrete and towards the west upon Maister Andrew's strete. Dated at Bury, 10 December, 2 Ed. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 161.

Juliana Orysby of Bury St. Edmund, late wife of John Orysby, for a sum of £9 grants to William Brown a messuage and land with two houses in Bury St. Edmund, situated in the street called Netemarket. Dated at Bury St. Edmund, 10 April, 4 Ed. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 162.

Indenture made 1 Oct., 4 Ed. VI, by which Thomas Browse and Edmond Hawkyn, supervisors of the purchasyd town lands, demise to John Jelly one tanner's stall in the Marketsted in Bury for 21 years, at an annual rent of 2s. [Two seals.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 163.

Indenture made 3 Feb., 35 Hen. VIII, by which Robert Sharppe and John Swanton, supervisors of the lands late Margaret Odam's, now belonging to the guild of the Purification of S. Mary V. demise unto Roger Barbor 27 acres of land in Bury, Westeley and Moche Hornyngferth for 20 years, at an annual rent of 25s. 8d. [Plain seal.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 164.

Indenture dated 7 Aug. 2 and 3 Philip and Mary, by which Roger Barbour and William Parke of Bury St. Edmund, mercer demyse and grant to Edmund Hawkyns, grocer a close containing 7 a. 3 r. 18p. in Westgatefelde of Bury, for 21 years, at an annual rent of 24s. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 165.

Indenture made 24 Nov., 9 Elizabeth, by which Thomas Buttery of Bury St. Edmund, yeoman sells to John Nycholysson, for 100 pounds, two pieces of arable land lying in the fields of Bury aforesaid, containing 11 acres. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 166.

Power of attorney given by Thomas, duke of Norfolk, to Thomas Kytsen, esq. and Thomas Andrews, gent., to be his deputies in the office of Seneschal of Bury St. Edmund. Dated 20 January, 10 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 167.

Henry Collyn and Anthony Butler, gents., grant to Richard Moore the whole of a stone chapel in Bury St. Edmund on the S. and W. of le Risbygate which late belonged to the monastery of Bury St. Edmund. Dated 12 April, 13 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 168.

Bond entered into by Thomas Barnard of Hardygrave, Suffolk, "sponer", in a sum of twenty marks, for the sale of a garden and a tenement in the High Street, Bury to Thomas Cleris, discharging the letter from the dower of Margaret wife of the said Thomas Barnard. Dated 14 October, 14 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 169.

Richard More of Bury St. Edmund, draper (?), enfeoffs John Hiegham, sir Thomas Kytson, knt., and 22 others in the whole of a late ("nuper") stone chapel situated in Bury aforesaid to the west of Rysbyegate. Dated 24 April, 25 Elizabeth, 1583. MS. Ch. Suffolk 170.

Simon Hubbard, for the sum of £20, grants to Thomas Genne, maltster, of Bury two tenements with a garden, one of them late part of the possessions of the chapel of St. Nicholas in the town of Bury St. Edmund. Dated 27 July, 1585. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 172.

Indenture by which George Dawson, "imbreyderer", for good causes and considerations, grants to John Cadge, yeoman and Thomas Spittilhowse, draper of Bury St. Edmund a messuage and garden in Bury aforesaid, in the street called 'le Churchegatestrete' in perpetuity. Dated 8 June, 29 Elizabeth, 1587. MS. Ch. Suffolk 173.

Indenture made 15 May, 34 Q. Elizabeth 1592, by which Christopher Baker of Bury St. Edmund, scrivener demises to farm to Gregory Bridon, "bower", a messuage in Bury St. Edmund for 21 years, at an annual rent of 1d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 174.

Thomas Bright of Bury St. Edmund, draper, son and heir of Thomas Bright, deceased, grants to Thomas Reade of Bury St. Edmund, mercer, a messuage situated in Bury St. Edmund in the street called le Bokrowe. Dated 20 December, 39 Q. Elizabeth, 1596. MS. Ch. Suffolk 175.

Indenture made 24 December, 45 Q. Elizabeth, 1602 by which Gilbert Spalding of Hawsted, in the county of Suffolk, sells to Thomas Cooke, tailor a messuage &c. in Bury St. Edmund, next Risbygate in consideration of a sum of £39 paid to the said Gilbert. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 176.
Recognizance entered into by Elizabeth Milward of Bury St. Edmund on her being allowed to keep an alehouse in that town. Dated 24 January, 1 James I. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 177.

Sir Robert Jermyn of Rushbrooke, co. Suffolk, kt., grants to Edmund Corksage of Stansteed, taylor, a cottage or shop situate in 'le Rayngate streete' in Bury St. Edmund, near a sherehowse and three pieces of a farm ("fandi") lying near the tenement of Alice Corksage, widow, being part of a garden called le Sentryyard. Dated 19 July, 3 James I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 178.

Indenture to save harmless Richard Gippes and Robert Martyn in any action or suits by virtue of their patent or warrant. Given by the alderman and burgesses of Bury St. Edmund, whose names are signed on the back. Dated 12 May, 1625. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 179.
The will of Edward Gatewade of Bury St. Edmund, clothier, dated 31 October, 7 Charles I. Probate dated 2 Dec., 1631. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 180.

Indenture made 6 October, 24 Charles I, by which Myles Burgh, gent., alderman and keeper of the gaol of Bury St. Edmund, acknowledges to have received of John Clarke, late keeper, 21 prisoners for debt etc. as described in a schedule annexed. [On paper.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 181.

Indenture made 30 May, 1657, by which Edward Freeman of Wymondham, Norfolk, husbandman, in consideration of the sum of fifty pounds, demises to Joseph Alexander of Bury St. Edmund, apothecary, in Guildhall street, a messuage in Bury St. Edmund for 30 years, at an annual rent of a pepper corn. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 182.

Indenture made 14 April, 21 Charles II, by which James, earl of Suffolk, steward of the franchises of Bury St. Edmund, appoints
Jonathan Perry of Bury St. Edmund, gent. his deputy steward of the said franchises during the will and pleasure of the said earl. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 183.

Indenture dated 28 September, 21 Charles II, by which John Sothebie, esq., and others, feoffees of the town lands of Bury, in consideration of the sum of £15, have demised to Samuel Burrough, baker, certain small tenements for 50 years, at an annual rent of 5s. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 184.

Indenture made 13 June, 28 Charles II, by which the rt. hon. James, earle of Suffolk, appoints John Catesby, of Clifford's Inn, gent., steward of the franchise of Bury St. Edmund during pleasure. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 185.
List of lands belonging to the hospital of St. Peter, Bury St. Edmund. (End of 16th century). [On paper.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 186a.

BECCLES. BURY ST. EDMUND (Abbey of). Geoffrey de Brakenest, John Dannard, Henry Maynard, Richard Wrong, William son of Reiner, Alexander de la Grene, William de Troux, Alexander Godefrey, Alan le Mellere, Alan Kempe, Vincent Godale, Alan son of Matthew, sen., Adam Fraunceys, Warine de Dunbergh, Robert de le Apiltone, Thomas Dannard, John de la Grene, John Case, Daniel le Cupere, John de Brakenest, Bartholomew de Nortone, Robert Becke, John le Clerck, Reginald le Draper, William Werpelock, Richardde Welington, Walter Godefrey, Nicholas de Miteford, Geoffrey de St. Edmund, Alan de Carletone, Richard de Brakenest, Richard le Cock, Thomas Wrong, William Porre, Philip de la Grene, Geoffrey de la Forthe, Roger Rogerum, Sewall Sycary, and John Cotoun bond themselves, their heirs and the whole of the community of Becclis, under agreement with John, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund to make oath and assart yearly to the bailiffs of the abbot at the view of frankpledge for the whole community of Becclis, under pain of a fine of 100 marks to the king. Dated at Becclis the Sunday next before the feast-of St. Matthew, 22 Ed. I. [With seals, most of them broken.] Endorsed, "de fine rebellionis contra Regem per homines dicte ville tempore vacantis abbatie." MS. Ch. Suffolk 186b.

BUXLOW. William Kenrych of Buckesloue grants to Thomas Portman, son of Roger Portman of Cnodessale, and Matilda his wife, for 20s. one piece of arable land in Buckesloue paying annually to them one root of ginger, and to the rector of the ch. of Buckesloue two pence. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1165.
Richard de Elmedene and Matilda his wife grant to Henry, son of Robert Hamund of Beterynge, for three shillings one piece of pasture in Buckeslowe. (c. 1290-1300.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1166 .

Richard Page of Buckeslowe grants in exchange with Henry, son of Robert Hamund, the whole of his tenement in Buckeslowe and Sternefeld for the whole of the latter's tenement in Betering and 10 marks sterling. Dated at Buckeslowe on the feast of Pentecost, 32 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1167.

Simon Gamen of Semere and Alice le Gordebof of Buckeslowe, his wife, grant to Henry, son of Robert Hamund of Betering, one piece of land in Buckeslowe, for five shillings. Dated at Buckeslowe the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Matthew, 33 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1168.

Alice le Cordebof of Buckeslowe grants to Henry Hamund of Beteryngs one piece of her pasture in the village of Buckeslowe, in exchange for a piece of his land. Dated at Buckeslowe the Tuesday next before the feast of the Annunciation, 2 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1169.

Richard de Elmedene and Matilda his wife of Buckeslowe grant to farm to Henry de Bettrynge for five shillings one piece of pasture called 'le Mor' for five years from the feast of St. Michael 5 Edw. [II]. Dated at Buckeslowe the Sunday next before the feast of St. Dunstan (?) 4 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1170.

Laurence de Baldock, parson of Buxlowe, grants to Henry de Betering his third part of certain lands and tenements in Buxlowe which he held continually with Mathilda de Bopham, daughter of the said Henry. Dated at Buxlowe the Sunday next before the feast of St. Martin, 16 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1171.

Galiena, relict of Henry Portman of Buxlowe, grants to William Reydone and Alice his wife two pieces of land in Buxlow. Dated at Buxlowe the Monday before the feast of the Annunciation of the Lord, 5 (?) Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1172.

John, son of William de Repdene of Buckeslowe, grants to Thomas his brother five pieces of his land lying in the said village of Buckeslowe. Dated at Buckeslowe the Sunday next before the feast of the Annunciation of the B. V. M., 10 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1173 .
Henry le Cordebof of Buxlowe grants to John de Braham certain land lying in the village of Buxlowe. Dated at Buxlowe the Sunday next after the feast of St. Michael, 12 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1174.
Robert Smythman demises to John Wyngefeld, kt., and four others an enclosed pightell newly built on in Buxlowe. Dated at Buxlow, 12 January, 7 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1176.

BUXLOW, FRESTON, and FARWHAM. Robert Beker of Stratford remits and quit-claims to John Braham of Buxlowe and his heirs all his right in certain lands, tenements, &c. in the village of Buxlow, Freston, Snape, and Farnham. Dated at Freston, 4 March, 5 Hen. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1260.

BUXLOW, KNOTTESHALL, &c. William de Reydon of Buxlow grants to John de Braham of Cnodeshale and Roger his son all the messuages, lands, rents in the villages of Buxlowe, Cnodeshale, Haselwode, Fresston, Snapes, Sternefeyld, with the advowson of Buxlow. Dated at Buxlow the Monday in the feast of St. Matthias, 17 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1175

CARLETON, KELSALE, MONKS-SAHAM, and CRANSFORD. Convention made between the lord Roger, earl Bigot, marshal of England, of the one part, and Roger de Karletone of the other, viz. that the said Roger de Karletone has sold to the lord Roger the whole of his manor and advowson of Karleton, with appurtenances in Karleton and Keleshal, and in Saham Monks and
in the village of Cranesford, for 250 marks sterling, to be paid on the vigil and written the octave of Pentecost, 34 Hen. Ill, in the castle of the said earl Roger at Framingham; and the said earl shall maintain the said grantor's daughter Camille honourably in some manner, until she is 13 years old, and then procure her admission as a nun, but if she refuse to take a religious habit shall then provide her with ten pounds' worth of land. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1261.

CARLETON COLVYLE, KYRKLE, PAKEFELD, GISLEHAM, MULFORD, and HENSTEAD. John de Kymburle, parson of Mutford, Roger atte Heth, parson of Todenham, and Edmund Man of Mutford remit and by these presents quit-claim to Ralph Megre, parson of Kessynglond, all the right they have in Fastolf's manor, viz. in all lands &c. in Carleton Colvyle, Kyrkele, Pakefeld, Gyselham, Mutford and Henstede, which they had by the gift of sir Edm. de Hemgrave, kt. Dated at Mutford the Wednesday on the feast of St. Botolph, 29 Ed. III. [With three seals, one armorial.] Charters Suffolk 1262-65 are endorsed as having been exhibited in a law-suit, 15 March, 1697/98. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1263.

Warine de Barneby and Alan Reynald remit and quit-claim to sir Robert Spenser, parson of Elgh[am], sir Edmund de Welles, parson of Beccles, and Richard Megre all their right in the manor of Carleton Colvile called Fastolfes, and in all lands &c. in Carleton Colvyle, Mutford, Barneby, Lowystoft, Kirkele, Pakefeld, Gysilham, Kessynglond, Resshemere, and Hensted. Dated at Carleton Colvile the Monday on the vigil of the Nativity of our Lord, 32 Ed. III. [With two seals.] Charters Suffolk 1262-65 are endorsed as having been exhibited in a law-suit, 15 March, 1697/98. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1262.

Ralph Megre, parson of the church of Kessinglond, grants to sir Robert Spenser, parson of Elgh[am], sir Edmund de Wells, parson of Bekklis, Richard Megre, Warine de Barneby, and Alan Reynald his manor of Carleton Colvyle called Fastolfs, with appurtenances, lands, &c. in the villages of Carleton, Montforye, Barneby, Henstede, Ruschemer, Gyselham, Pakefeld, and Kyrkle. Dated at Carleton Colvyle the Friday after the feast of St. Nicholas, bp., 32 Ed. [III]. [With seal.] Charters Suffolk 1262-65 are endorsed as having been exhibited in a law-suit, 15 March, 1697/98. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1264.

Ralph Megre, parson of the church of Kessynglond, quit-claims to sir Erneric de Welyngton, kt., all right in the whole manor of Carleton Colvyle called Falstolfs, and in all lands &c. in Carleton Colvyle, Mutford, Barneby, &c. lately acquired from sir Edmund de Hemgrave, knt. Dated at Carleton Colvyle the Thursday on the feast of St. John, apostle, 32 Ed. III. [With seal.] Charters Suffolk 1262-65 are endorsed as having been exhibited in a law-suit, 15 March, 1697/98. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1265.

CARLETON COLVILE. William Horman, Robert Rypyng, and Robert Dolfyn, of Carleton Colvile, grant to John Oldryng and Agnes his wife one messuage, 34 acres of land, and 3s. annual rent in Carleton Colvyle. Dated there, 16 Oct., 14 Hen. VI. [With three seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1266.

William Rypyng of Carleton Colvyle, John Denyell, Thomas Whitton, Robert Thyrkeld, Thomas Craske, and Thomas Dolphyn demise and confirm to Thomas, son of John Olderyng, all those messuages, lands, &c. in Carleton aforesaid which they had by feoifment of the said John Olderyng. Dated at Carleton aforesaid, 6 June, 3 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1267.

Thomas Dolphyn of Carleton Colvyle, William Rypyng, John
Denyell, and Thomas Whitton, at the requisition of Thomas Olderyng of Carleton aforesaid, demise to John, son of the said Thomas, and Alice his wife, Alexander Olderyng, Robert Dolphyn, sen., John Craske, and John Everarde all his messuages and lands in Carleton aforesaid, to hold the same for the said John and Alice and their heirs after the decease of the said Thomas Olderyng and Margaret his wife. Dated at Carleton, 30 July, 10 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1268.

William Herman of Gyslam, Richard Rypyng of Mutford, and Robert Dolfyn of Carleton grant to John Oldryng and Agnes his wife two messuages, 34 acres of land, and 3s. of annual rent in the village of Carleton Colvyle, which they had had by the grant of the said John, for the term of their lives, with remainder to their son Thomas Oldryng and Margaret his wife. Dated at Carleton Colvyle, 16 October, 14 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1269.

Indenture made 2 August, 28 Hen. VIII, between John Couper of Carleton Colvyle and Alys his wife of the one part, and John Jettor of Lowystoft of the other part, witnesseth that the said John and Alys sell to him all their messuages, lands, and tenements in Carleton Colvyle. [English] [Much effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1270.

Indenture (on paper) dated 20 June, 23 Q. Elizabeth, by which John Jernegon of Somerleyton, esq., demised to George Hervy of Oulton his "heathe doole" in the town of Carleton Colvyle for 21 years, at an annual rent of 2s. Signed. [English] [Paper.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1271.
Release from Edmund ... 2 Elizabeth. Almost entirely effaced. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1272.
Illegible deed of Robert Battely's, temp. James I. Almost entirely effaced. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1273.

Memorandum that sir Edmund Themylthorpe of Tunswod, kt., has received of Francis Claxtone of Wysset, gent. £500 for the purchase of certain lands &c. in Carleton Colvyle, as mentioned in a pair of indentures dated 25 January, 2 James I. Dated 28 March, 3 James I. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1274.

Francis Claxton of Wisset, gent., in performance of certain covenants sells to Nicholas Batteley of Romburgh, yeoman, a messuage &c. in Carleton Colvile. Dated 16 October, 4 James I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1275.

Indenture dated 16 October, 4 James I, by which Francis Claxton of Wysset, co. Suffolk, gent., in consideration of the receipt of £500, sells to Nicholas Battely the younger, of Romburgh, co. Suffolk, yeoman, lands, tenements, &c. in Carleton Colvile. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1276.
Memorandum from the court roll of the manor of Carleton Colvyle, dated 27 April, 7 James I, concerning the grant of Francis Claxton to Robert Battelye. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1277.

CARLTON COLVILE, BARSHAM, ILKETTISHALL, ST. ANDREW, and LOWESTOFT. Indenture made 10 October, 1626, by which Robert London of Whetacre and Edmund Smith of Gillingham are to have a fine levied by John Codd and Mary his wife and
Richard Burnell for conveying certain messuages and lands in the above villages to them. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1279.

Final concord, made at Westminster on the morrow of All Souls,
2 Charles I, by which John Codd and Mary his wife, Henry Coppinger and Sarah his wife, and Richard Burnell acknowledge that two messuages, one curtilage, two gardens, orchard, &c. and certain lands in Carleton Colvyle, Barsham, Ilkettishall St. Andrews, and Lowestoft belong to Robert London, sen., and Edmund Smith; for this fine the said Robert and Edmund gave to John and Marya, Henry and Sarah, and Richard, £100 sterling. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1278.

CATTGRAVE. Richard Benet of Teurtone grants to William de Winst[on], chaplain, for his homage and service and 2s. of silver, 2d. of annual rent from William, son of Serlo of Plumstede, for one acre of land in the field of Cattegrave, paying annually one apple for all service. (c. 1240.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1280.

CAVENDISH. Robert le Meller of Denarddestun, Margaret his wife, and William, son of Reginald of Beauchamp St. Paul, grant to William, son of Ralph Pit' of Wrottinge, one messuage and one piece of land to the same belonging, in the village of Cavened'. Dated at Cavenedis the Saturday next after the feast of St. Martin, 24 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 262.

Walter Caleys, citizen and clothier of London, son and heir of Thomas Caleys, quit-claims to Richard Chaundeler all right in .... in Cavendyssh .... and Stansted, co. Suffolk. Dated at [Mutilated and partly effaced.] Temp. Hen. VI MS. Ch. Suffolk 263.

Edward Felton, gent., confirms to John Golding of Glemsford and others the conditions of a grant of lands in Cavendish as is contained in a charter dated at Glemsford, 20 Feb., 24 Hen. VII. Dated at Glemsford, 23 Feb., 24 Hen. VII. [In great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 265.

Bond of William Methwold of Langford in co. Norfolk, to John Smith of Cavendish, gent., in a sum of £100 for performance of covenants respecting lands called Melhwolds and Wymvolds. Dated 5 October, 4 Hen. VIII. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 264.

CHARLESWORTH. Samson, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund grant to Benedict, son of Richard de Blacheham, to hold in fee and heirship at Thymworde, the land which was Theodric's, saving the custom and right which was due to the abbot of St. Edmund from that land, and Cherlesworde in fee farm, paying each year two farms to the cellarer and which is called the farm of St. Edmund and to extreme farm of Ornigheseord 20s.; and Lacheforde in fee farm. Dated in full chapter, 1198. [With seal, nearly perfect.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 10.

CHARSFIELD. Indenture witnessing that on St. Michael's day, 12 Hen. VII, at Letheryngham, between Henry, the prior, and canons of St. Mary, Letheryngham, on the one part, and Thomas Robertsunne of Charsfeld on the other part, viz. that the said prior and canons grant to the said Thomas 4 pieces of land in Charsfeld, lying in a field called 'Le Sondes,' in Aldeburghfeld, for 60 years, at an annual rent of 12d. [With convent seal, perfect.] [Wrongly listed as Ch. Suffolk 219.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1446.

CHEDISTON. Bartholomew de Norfolch in Chedistane and Joan his wife grant to sir William de Nerford, kt., and Petronilla his wife, 1½d., three stalks of ginger, and three cloves annual rents in the village of Chedistane, from Roger Barsham. Dated at Wyssete the Sunday next after the feast of the Nativity of our Lord 27 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1177.

CHELMONDESTON. Indenture made 31 March, 41 Elizabeth, between Robert Mighell of Chelmondeston, Suffolk, and Robert Cundy of .... by which the said Robert Mighell leases to Robert Cundy [or Curdy] a marsh and certain closes ... [English] [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1282.

CHILTON. Gilebert Karbunel grants to Geoffrey his brother the whole of his land of Chiltune, with two men of Middeltune pertaining to the same land, for his service and homage and his money, viz. gold and silver, which he gave to him; with covenants for an exchange should the grantor marry and have a son, and deside to make an exchange. (c. 1170-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 266.

Roger, son of William de Huntingefeld, grants to Gilebert Karbunel, Chiltun and Buras and Wendeshale, by the service of one knight's fee, for which the said Gilebert gave 15 marks of silver and one war-horse of the price of 5 marks, and to Aeliza, wife of the said Roger, three bezants. (c. 1170-80.) Witn. Rand. de Glanvill and 30 others. MS. Ch. Suffolk 267.

Sampson, the abbot of St. Edmund, grants to William Carbonel a certain liberty which is called Infongenethef in his village of Chilton, which is of the fee of Eye, at an annual rent of 1 lb of white incense. (c. 1190-1200) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 6.

William de Huntingefeld grants to Richard Agelliun and Alice his wife the custody of the lands and heirs of William Carbunel, formerly husband of the said Alice, also the manor of Chilton in dower, for the term of the life of the said Alice. (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 268.

Alice Lorkyn of Chilton, widow, Richard son of the said Alice, John Syday, and others demise to Robert Syday, servant of Robert Crane esq., John Syday, bailiff of the said R. Crane, John Thurgor, and Ralph Parkerof Waldyngfeld a cottage with a garden adjoining in Chilton. Dated at Chilton, 29 June, 11 Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 269.

John Clopton, esq., and others infeoff Robert Crane, esq., and ... the manors of Chilton and Great Waldingfield, with the advowson of the church of Chilton. 10 December [13 (?)Hen. VI]. [Decayed and mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 270.

Robert Stowe, 'lymbrenner', John Broun, and John Tylle demise to Matilda Stace, Simon Sparwe, Stephen Barbour, and Thomas Cook one piece of land in Chilton called Chilton acre. Dated on the vigil of St. John the Baptist, 30 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 271.

John Sydey, senior, husbandman, and Richard Sydey of Great Waldingfield demise and confirm to John Sydey, son of the above John, John Apiltone, John Folour, and Robert Ponder a croft in Chilton called of old 'Wylnenes croft.' Dated at Chilton, 9 January, 33 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 272.

John Sydey of Great Waldingfeld, "plowman" quit-claims to John Apilton of Little Waldingfeld, John Folour of Sudbery, baker, and Robert Pondere, all his right in a croft called Wylkenercroft and land at Chilton. Dated at Chilton, 20 July, 1 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 273.

John Syday atte Helmes of Great Waldingfeld and others grant to Robert Syday, servant of Robert Crane, and others, a tenement with a croft in the village of Chilton. Dated at Great Waldingfield, 20 .... 2 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 274.

Richard Symoii of Great Waldingfield, John Sydey, servant of Robert Crane, esq., John Randolf, and John .... confirm to Alice Lorkyn of Chilton, widow, Richard Lorkyn her son, and others, a cottage and garden in Chilton. Dated at Chilton, 31 March, 4 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 275.

Robert Thurston, son and heir of Richard Thurston of Great Waldingfield, grants to John Sydey of the same, dyer, and three others, one acre of pasture in Chilton, which his father and others had by deed dated 4 June 9 Hen. VI. Dated at Chilton, 20 Dec., 9 Hen. VII. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 276.

Alicia Lorkyn of Chilton, Richard Lorkyn her son, John Syday, and William Downyng, "ploughman" grant to Robert Syday, John Syday, John Thurgore, and Ralph Parker a cottage with a garden in Chilton, for the use of the said Robert Syday. Dated at Chilton, 29 June, 11 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 277:

Richard Lorkyn of Monks Illegh, William Parker, John Heryot, George Lorkyn, and William Randolff deliver and confirm to John Lorkyn of Alphamstone, co. Essex, Robert Sperlyng, John Sewals, and Hugh Lorkyn a tenement with certain land adjoining, situate in Chilton. Dated at Chilton, 6 July, 17 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 278.

William Randolf of Great Waldingfield grants to Robert Syday of the same, Isabella his wife, Ralph Parker, Robert Parker, and John Grene one tenement with a croft of land lying in Chilton, called Colmanys Grant (?). Dated at Great Waldingfield, 5 July, 22 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 279.

John Thurgore of Great Waldingfield and John Syday of the same, dyer, grant to Simon Smythee of Preston, ThomasRyse, and Thomas Wode one croft of land called Beneyzts in Chilton. Dated at Chilton, 9 March, 22 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 280.

Indenture made 14 April, 24 Hen. VII, by which Robert Crane of Chilton, esq., has demised to John Coole of Sudbury, mercer, a croft of arable land &c. in Chilton, for 20 years, at an annual rent of 20s. 9d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 281,

Isabella of Alvenstone, Essex, widow of Robert Siday of Great Waldingfield, and Ralph Parcar grant to Robert Crane, William Holms, Nicolas Mawyn, and John Wasp a tenement with a croft of land in Chilton, called "Colmans front". Dated at Chilton, 20 Jan., 18 Hen. VIII. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 282.

Indenture dated 4 Sept., 19 Hen. VIII, by which Robert Crane of Chilton, in the county of Suffolk, esq., demises to William Jervis of Sudbury a close containing 7 acres in the parish of Chilton, for 30 years, at an annual rent of 10s. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 283.

John Sydey of Great Waldingfield and Roger of the same demise to John Hutton, rector of the church of Chilton, Thomas Wright, rector of Stanstede, William Mey of Sudbury, and Robert Sydey one acre of pasture land in the village of Chilton. Dated at Chilton, 2 July, 21 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 284.
Edward Crane, gent., remits and quit-claims to Robert Crane of Chilton, gent., all right to actions, debts, &c. to the date of this present charter, viz. 28 July, 23 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 285.

Indenture made 4 March, 24 K. Hen. VIII, by which Robert Crane demises unto John Coole his field of 14 acres lying in the townfield of Chilton, for 21 years, at an annual rent of 20s. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 286.
Duplicate of MS. Ch. Suffolk 286. MS. Ch. Suffolk 287.

Receipt given by Alice Methwold, sometime wife to William Methwold, of Langford, Norf., esq. and others, executors of the will of William Methwold, to sir Robert Crane of Chilton, for £20 in part payment of a larger sum. Dated 16 Feb., 30 Hen. VIII. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 288.

Indenture made 16 August, I Mary, between sir Robert Crane of Chilton, esq., of the one part, and John Coolie , gent., of the second part, witnesseth that the said Robert grants to the said John certain lands in Chilton aforesaid. [English] [Slightly mutilated, and in part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1283.

Appointment by Thomas, earl of Suffolk, lord lieutenant of Suffolk and Cambridge, of sir Robert Crane, kt., as a deputy lieutenant of the county of Suffolk. Dated and signed 12 May, 1 Charles I. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 289.

CLARE. Mutilated convention, dated St Michael's day 1327, by which Edmund son of sir John de Norttoft, knt. leases his manor of Tyllebery juxta Clare to several persons (names altered). MS. Ch. Suffolk 1281.

CODDENHAM, &c. Sefuhelus de Vlendene confirms to William de Cyresi, for his homage and service and for 18s., one piece of his land in the village of Code[n]ham; paying annually to him and his heirs one grain of pepper. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 522.

Hugh de Gosebeth quit-claims two marks to Robert, son of Gilebert de Vlendene, and (the undermentioned) Roys and his heirs, the homage and service of Roger the smith and his heirs, with the whole of the tenement of the said Roger, for which the said Hugh impleaded Adam de Bedige and Roys his wife "per breve de recto", who had it in dowry at a rent of 5s. for the said tenement, and all other tenements which Gilbert, father of the said Robert, held of Peter, father of the said Hugh, in the parish of Code[n]ham. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 521.

Bartholomew, son of Roger the smith of Codeham, grants to the church of the Holy Trinity of Gipewic, in frankalmoigne, seven pieces of land in Codeham, paying annually to him and his heirs 26d.; for this grant the said canons gave him 5 marks of silver. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 213.

William, son of Peter de Codeham le Pleydur grants to Ralph Wyslepays two pieces of land in the parish of Codeham, paying annually to him and his heirs 6d.; for this grant the said Ralph gave to him 20s. sterling and made his homage. (c. 1220-30.) [Seal, broken and almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 522b.
John Vaghe grants to Robert Theward one piece of land in Scaldeford meadow in Codeham. (c. 1250-60.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1284.

Geoffrey de Slamundishe grants to Thomas de Kalna, for his homage and service and for 40 marks of silver, all ... of Thomas de
Codenham, with homage, rents, escheats, &c., paying annually 24d. for all services, &c. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 525a.
Thomas, son of Ralph Wigor, grants to William Snod, for his homage and service and for 40s., two pieces of land in the parish of Codeham. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 523.

Juliana .... grants to Richard Sephul and Mabel his sister of Codeham, for their homage and service and for ...., four pieces of land in the villages of Codeham and Creting All Saints. (c. 1270-80.) [Rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 524.

John, son of Ralph Ysly de la Rode, grants to William Snod, Juliana his wife, and to Edmund their son and his heirs, for the term of their lives, for their service and 20s., one piece of land in Codeham, paying annually to him and his heirs one clove at Easter. Dated at the house of the said William the Monday next after the feast of St. Scolastica the virgin, 12 Ed. I. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 525b.

Alice, daughter of Richard de Schaldeforde, widow, grants to Robert, son of Bartholomew de Bucketon, and Sarah his wife, for their service and 30s. of silver, half an acre of meadow in the village of Codenham, and in the field called 'Schaldefordemedwe', and half a rood in the same meadow. Dated in the month of February, 21 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 526.

John de Cranel of Codeham grants to Nicholas Spake of the same place, for his service and 3s. of silver, one piece of land in the village of Codeham. Dated at Le Rode, Whitsunday, 23 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 527.

John, son of John, the clerk of Codenham, grants to William the merchant (mercator) of the same place, for his service and 11s. of silver, one piece of arable land in Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Saturday next before the feast of St. Barnabas, 24 Ed. I. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 528.

Alice Spake of Creting St. Mary grants to Nicholas Spake of Codenham one piece of her land in the village of Codenham. Dated the Sunday next before the feast of St. Matthew the apostle, 27 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 529.

Robert de Vlendene of Codenham grants to Robert Spake of the same place, for his service and a certain sum of money, two pieces of land in Codenham in the field called 'Haylond.' Dated at Codenham the Sunday next after the feast of the Invention of the Cross, 2 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 530.

Mabel, daughter of Matilda Clare (?) of Codenham, remits and quit-claims to Nicholas Spake all her right in certain land called Cokyslond in Codenham. Dated the Wednesday next before the feast of St. Francis, 3 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 531.
Illegible charter, temp. Ed. II, dated at Codenham, [Seal part.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 532.

Margaret, daughter of Roger Dolfin of Cretingges St. Mary, grants to William de Bosco of the same place and Christiana his wife, one piece of land lying in the parish of Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Sunday next before the feast of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist, 4 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 533.

Marieta, who was the wife of Robert Dolfin of Cretingges St. Mary, grants to William del Bosco of the same place and Christine all her right in a piece of land in Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Sunday before the Nativity of St. John the Baptist, 4 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 534.
Walter Bugg of Codenham grants to Nicholas Spake of the same place one piece of land lying in Codenham. Dated the Friday next after the feast of Epiphany, .. Ed. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 535.

Convention made at Codenham the Thursday next after the feast of St. Margaret the virgin, 4 Ed. II, by which Roger le Deneys of Codenham demises at fee-farm to Nicholas Spake of the same place, one piece of land called 'Fleyfordsfeld' (or Fhays..thfeld?) in Codenham, paying annually to the said Robert 14d. [With seal.]
MS. Ch. Suffolk 536.
Charter by which .... grants to Mariota Lewy (?) a messuage in ... Dated at Codenham, 22 May, .. Ed. II. [Almost entirely effaced.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 537.

William de Bosco of Cretingge St. Mary grants to Robert Coleman of Codenham, for a certain sum of money, one piece of his land lying in Codenham. Dated the Sunday next before the feast of the apostles SS. Simon and Jude, 8 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 538.

Edmund le .... of Codenham grants to William Kakestrete and John his son one parcel of pasture .... Dated at Codenham the Friday next after the feast of the Annunciation of the B. V. M., 10[?] Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 539a.

Ralph Sunday of Codinham grants to Nicholas Spake of the same place, and Joan his younger daughter, one piece of land in Codinham. Dated the Friday on the feast of the Epiphany, 11 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 539b.

Mabel, formerly wife of Richard le Flur of Codenham, grants to Robert Spake of Codenham, for a certain sum of money, two pieces of land lying in the parish of Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Sunday next after the feast of the Conception of the B. V. M., 11 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 540a.

Thomas de la Grene of Codenham grants to Robert Spake of Codenham one curtilage with its appurtenances in Codenham. Dated there the Thursday on the feast of the Nativity of the B. V. M., 11 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 540b.

Ralph de Bockyngg grants to John de Ponte of Codenham the whole field of 'Prestefeld' in Codenham. Dated at Codenham .... before the feast of the apostles SS. Simon and Jude, 16 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 541a.

Agnes Bernard and Isabella her daughter of Codenham remit and quitclaim to William Sewyne of the same village all their right in three pieces of land in Codenham, with one pyttel, and rents of 18d, one day's work in autumn, and one hen at Christmas. Dated at Jodenham the Sunday next after the feast of the Purification of the B. V. M., 4 Ed. III. [With seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 541b.

Edward Harneys of Codinham grants to Nicholas Benselyn, chaplain, of the same village, his serf John Stanbowe with all that belongs to him. Dated at Codinham the Sunday next after the Purification of the Virgin, 11 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 542.

Nicholas Bencelyn, chaplain of Codinham, manumits John Stanbowe of the same place, and all his goods, chattels, and whatsoever belongs to him. Dated at Codinham the Sunday next after the feast of the Invention of the Cross, 11 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 543.

Richard de Burghstede, parson of Framelingham at the Castter, grants to Edmund de St. Clauo, son and heir of John de St. Clauo, and Agnes his wife, all his lands, rents, &c. in the villages of Codenham, Croffeld, Creeting St. Mary, Creeting All Saints, Creeting St. Olave, Stonham Earls, Stonham Antegaine, and Stonham Grernegan. Dated at Codenham the Sunday after the feast of All Saints, 11 Ed. III. (Clauo: see MS. Ch. Suffolk 522b, his name occurs frequntly. On 522b and in 635 the name is clearly written "Clavo". In many other deeds it is very uncertain.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 544.

Robert de le Wode of Codenham, chaplain, grants to sir William, vicar of the church of Resshemere, and Hamo Dyke de Wydekeshe, chaplain, certain lands &c. in the villages of Codenham, Creeting St. Mary, and Stoneham Jernegan. Dated at Codenham the Friday next after the feast of St. [Martin] 15 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 545.

John del Wode, chaplain, grants to William, perpetual vicar of Resshemere, and Hamo Dike of Wedekishe, chaplain, all lands and tenements he has in the villages of Codenham and Stonham Antegan, and the hamlet of Croffeld. Dated at Codenham the Friday next after the feast of St. Martin, 15 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 546.

John, son and heir of Robert Coleman of Cretyngge All Saints, is bound to William, vicar of Resshemere, and sir Hamo Dyke, chaplain, in one annual rent of 40s. from lands and tenements in Codenham, Creeting St. Mary, and Creeting All Saints. Dated at Gippewyc the Sunday next after the Epiphany, 16 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 547a.

Edmund de St. Clano of Codenham grants to the prior and convent of the church of the Holy Trinity of Gyppewic', and their successors
and assigns, that they may have a free way with horses and carts and of every kind of animal in the whole of his way which lies before his gate, which extends itself from the tenement of John Wistlepays towards the tenement formerly Ralph Sundai's, without any impediment. Dated at Codenham the Thursday next after the feast of the Circumcision, 16 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 215.

Agnes, widow of Robert le Tailliour of Cretynge All Saints, remits and quit-claims to John de Peckham, jun., all her right in a piece of arable land in Codenham. Dated at Cretyngge aforesaid the Friday next before the feast of St. Margaret, virgin, 17 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 547b.
Grant from William, vicar of Hesshemere to John prior .... of certain tenements ..., dated at Codenham 16 May 21 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 548a.

Joan, daughter of Margery de Gosebek, releases to Joan, who was the wife of Thomas atte Bregge of Codenham, and his children, John, Robert, Osana and Joan, all her right in land called 'Prestesfelde' in Codenham. Dated there the Sunday next after the feast of ... 22 Ed. III. [With seal.]
MS. Ch. Suffolk 548b.
Grant from [certain feoffees] to John del Cros and other of lands etc. in Codenham. Dated at Codenham 23 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 549.

Edmund de St. Clavo of Codenham remits and quitclaims to John, parson of Schelton, William, vicar of Resschmere, and Thomas Struttyng of Gippewic all right in two pieces of land at Codenham, formerly John Whystehpays'. Dated at Codenham, the Thursday next after the feast of St. Petronilla, 23 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 550.

John Wyhestelepays of Codenham grants to John, rector of the church of Schelton, one piece of arable land in the village of Codenham. Dated there the Monday next after the feast of the Invention of the Cross, 23 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 551.

Edmund de St. Clavo of Codenham grants to John, rector of Schelton, and others, one piece of arable land in Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Friday after the feast of St. Augustine of Engl., 23 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 552.

Ralph Spake and 3 others grant to John Parmenter of Stowemarcat and 2 others all the lands and tenements acquired of Alice and Joan Spake in the villages of Coddenham, Creeting All Saints, and Creeting St. Mary, with the reversion of the land held as dowry by Mariota, wife of the late John Spake. Dated at Coddenham, 8 April, 26 Ed. III. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 553.

Indenture for the greater part effaced, to which ... fitz-Stephen and William, William, and John Seynelow are partners. Dated at Codenham, Friday after feast of St. Stephen pope 47 Edw. III. [French] MS. Ch. Suffolk 554.

Peter Dun of Codenham grants to John Goldyng of the same place one messuage lying in the village of Codenham. Dated in Codenham, the Sunday next after the feast of SS. Peter and Paul, 33 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 555.

Charter by which ... vicar of the church of ...., William Reny..de and others grant and quit-claim to [Thomas ?] ....
of Codenham and Joan his daughter all their right in a tenement which was John Thedward's in the village of Codenham. Dated [45?] Ed. III. [Illegible.] [The greater part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 556.

John Schakerys of Harlyston and Angnes his wife grant to William Berrard and John Jaune of Codenham, clerks, all the lands and tenements which were Robert le Dalton's, sen., and Robert le Dalton's, jun., in the village of Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Sunday next after the feast of St. John, evang., 3 Rich. II. [With seal, loose, of Rich. de Bursteele.] (See MS. Ch. Suffolk 569.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 557.

Thomas Dunch of Stonham Antegan grants to William .... of Cretyngge St. Mary two pieces of land in Codenham and Cretyngge All Saints. Dated at Cretyngg aforesaid the Tuesday on the feast of the Purification of the B. V. M., 7 Rich. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 557b.
Illegible grant to John Bron of Codenham and John Sehy.... Dated the Monday in the 3rd week of Quadragesima, [2?] Rich. II. [Mutilated and partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1285.

William Crane of Cretyngge St. Mary appoints Hugh Bugge to deliver to Thomas ate Grene of Creting St. Peter's, and others, seisin of all his lands &c. in Stowe, Creting St. Mary, Creting All Saints, Creting St. Olave, Codenham, and Stonham Jernynggan. Dated at Cretyngge St. Mary the Tuesday next before the feast of St. Peter in Cathedra, 7 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 558.

Charter by which .... of Codenham and Robert Moyse remit and quit-claim to John .... all their right in certain lands in Codenham. Dated the Sunday next after the feast of the exaltation of the Cross, 8 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 559.

John de Westreete grants to John Jaune of Codenham, clerk, an annual rent of 7d. from land in Codenham and the hamlet of Croffeld. Dated at Codenham the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Michael, archangel, 8 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 560.

John Cakestrete of Hommyngston grants to John Jaune, rector of Glemesford, three pieces of land in Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Thursday next after the feast of St. Cuthbert, bp., 10 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 561.

Sir Philip Deneys, kt., remits and quit-claims to John Jaune, parson of the church of Glemsford, all right in land called S(?)...wyshe. Dated at Coddenham, ... after feast of St George, 10 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 562.

Memorandum that at Redelyngfeld Court, held there the Sunday in the feast of St. Luke the apostle, 18 Rich. II, the lady granted to John Jaune, rector of Glemsford, one piece of land lying near Prestlond in the village of Codenham, paying annually for the same 6d., and paid for a fine 2s. MS. Ch. Suffolk 563.

Richard de Mekylfeld grants to John Jaune, rector of the church of Glemsford, 26d. of annual rent from certain lands in Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Sunday next after the feast of St. George the martyr, 13 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 564.

Ralph Spake of Codynham and Margaret his wife grant to John Jaune, rector of Glemsford, 13 pence of annual rent from two pieces of land lying in Codynham and Cretyng. Dated at Codynham the Monday on the feast of St. Mark the evangelist, 13 Rich. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 565.

Release from John Harnays to John Jaune Dated at Codenham ... after Purification of B. V. M. 17(?) Rich. II. [The greater part effaced. No endorsment.] [With seal of "S. Johan Harnays" arms loose.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 566.

Sir Philip Deneys, kt., grants to John Jaune, clerk, three pieces of land in the village of Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Thursday before the feast of St. Martin, confessor, 13 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 567.
Illegible charter, temp. Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 568.

John Jaune, parson of the church of Glemsford, grants to sir Philip Deneys, kt., William Berard, Edmund Drury, perpetual vicar of the church of Eye, and others, all his lands in the villages of Codenham, Creeting St. Mary, Creeting St. Olive, and Creeting All Saints. Dated at Codenham Tuesday after the feast of St. Edmund, king and martyr, 14 Rich. II. [Partly effaced.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 569a.

Gilbert de Debenham confirms to John Jaune, rector of the church of Glemsford, William Deneys, chaplain, and John Chapman of Codenham, seven pieces of land in the village of Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Thursday next after the feast of St. Peter ad vinc., 15 Rich. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 569b.

William Pockam of Creeting All Saints grants to Philip Derebohte of Stonham Earls one piece of arable land in Codenham. Dated at Codenham Friday before feast of Annunciation, 15 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 570a.

Roger, son and heir of sir Philip Deneys, kt., remits and quit-claims to John Jaune, parson of Glemasford, all his right in three pieces of land in the village of Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Tuesday on the feast of St. John ante port Lat., 16 Rich. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 570b.

Simon Skut of Codenham grants to John Wyght, rector of Cretyngge All Saints, Hugh Bugge, and others, all his lands and tenements in Codenham, Cretyngg St. Mary, Cretyngge All Saints, and Cretyngge St. Olave. Dated at Codenham the Monday on the feast of St. Michael, 17 Rich. II. [The object of this conveyance is defined in MS. Ch. Suffolk 581] MS. Ch. Suffolk 571a.

John Flour and John Bolewell grant to John Jaune, parson of Glemesford, two pieces of land in Codenham, which they had from Philip le Deneys, knt. Dated at Codenham the Thursday next before the feast of St. Laurence, 16 Rich. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 571b.

William Deneys, chaplain of Codenham, John Chapman, and two others grant to John Sweyn of Codenham, jun., and Joan his wife, one piece of arable land there. Dated at Codenham the Sunday next after the feast of St. Martin, bp. Conf., 18 Rich. II. [With seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 572a.

John Shyth and Joan his wife grant to Hugh, vicar of Codenham, John Wyght, rector of Cretyngge All Saints, and John Chapman of Codenham, all their lands and tenements in Codenham and Cretyngge, and elsewhere in the hundred of Bosmere. Dated at Codenham on Thursday the feast of SS. Peter and Paul, ... [either 9 or 15] Rich. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 572b.
Robert Morgwele of .... grants to John [Jaune?] one piece of land called Knapelondston. Dated at Codenham Sunday before feast of St. Luke, 8 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 573.

John Jermyn remits to John Jaune, rector of Glemsford, all his right in certain lands in Codenham, which Jaune obtained from sir William Jermyn, knt., father of the said John. Dated at Codenham, 5 February, 2 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 574.

Charter by which .... of Codenham grants to Thomas Havele of Codenham all his lands, pasture, &c. in the villages of Codenham, Creeting All Saints, and Creeting St. Mary. Dated at Codenham the Sunday next after the feast of SS. Tiburtius and Valerian, martyrs, 3 Hen. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 575.

Indenture witnessing that whereas John Ateook infeoffed John Jaune, rector of Glemsford, with a meadow called 'Schaldeford medwe,' as by the charter more plainly appears, nevertheless if the said John Ateook shall pay to the said John the sum of £12 at Codenham on Michaelmas next, then that charter to be void. Dated at Codenham the Sunday next after the feast of St. Michael, archangel, 4 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 576a.

John Germyn, lord of the manor of Gosbak, grants to John Jaune, rector of Glemsford, the whole of a meadow called 'Shaldeforde medwe' in Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Saturday next after the feast of St. Matthew, apostle, 4 Hen. IV. [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 576b.

John Coke appoints John Rushton his attorney to deliver seisin to John Jaune, rector of Glemsford, of a piece of land called Lawns. Dated at Codenham the Saturday ... St. Thomas the martyr, 4 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 577.

John Wyght, rector of Cretyngge All Saints, and John Chapman of Codenham infeoff Thomas Havell and Juliana his wife with certain lands &c. in Codenham, Creeting, and elsewhere. Dated Thursday in feast of Purification B.V.M., 9 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 578.

John Brown of Codenham remits and quit-claims to John Jaune,
jun., all his right in a piece of land called 'Cnapeloundston' in Codenham. Dated the Friday next after the feast of St. Luke the evang., 8 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 579.

Robert Marssche of Cretyng All Saints, grants to William Crane of Codenham one piece of pasture called Batemannyspotts. Dated Codynham the Thursday next after the feast of SS. Philip and James, 10 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 580.

Deed of trust of Symon Skutt of Codynham, conveying his property to John Wyght, rector of Cretyng All Saints, and others, in trust for various legatees; Monday in the feast of St. Michael, 17 Rich. II. [Much rubbed and about half illegible. See MS. Ch. Suffolk 571] MS. Ch. Suffolk 581.

Thomas Aldham and John Styward demise to Roger Fathare of Codenham their tenement called Thedewares and all their other lands &c. in Codenham, Creeting St. Mary, St. Olave and All Saints, and Croffeld, which they, with others, had by feoffment of Robert Dennys, rector of ..., excepting the tenements called Spakes, Besauntes, and Haselyngfeldis. Dated at Codenham, 6 July 9 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 582a.

Simeon Banham, clerk, grants to Bernard de Akynham certain lands in Codenham which he with others held to feoffment of John Jaune, clerk, late parson of the same. Dated 16 July, 12 Hen. IV. [In seal drawer, but without seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 582b.

John Sprot and John Bakere lease to Geoffrey Hefd, chaplain, for his life the tenement called Besanntes and divers pieces of land, as Edward de Wode held of John Jaune, chaplain, to farm in Codenham; with reversion to Simon Felbrigg, knt. and others. Dated at Codenham, 20 July, 13 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 583.

John Germyn, esq., remits and quit-claims to John Bernard of Akenham the whole of his right in all those fields lying in Shaldeford medewe in Codenham, which John Jaune, late rector of Glemsford, held of the gift of John Germyn his brother or William Germyn his father. Dated 5 Nov., 14 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 584a.

Sir George Felbrygge, kt., quit-claims to Simon Felbrygge and Roger Dreury, knts. all his right in certain lands &c. which were lately John Jaune's, parson of the church of Glemesford, in the villages of Codenham, Cretyngge All Saints, Cretyngge St. Mary, and Cretyngge St. Olave, excepting meadows lying in the Great Meadows called Schaldeford, etc.. Dated at Codenham the Tuesday next before the feast of St. Matthew, apostle, 14 Hen. IV. [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 584b.

Sir George Fylbrygge, kt., William Wallere and William Petystre remit and quit-claim to Robert Dennys, rector of Schatesham, all their right and claim in all lands, rents, and services in the villages of Codenham, Creeting St. Mary, Creeting All Saints, Creeting St. Olave, and Croffeld. Dated 26 July, 3 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 585.

William Lexham of Little Walsyngham remits and quit-claims all right in lands &c. in Codenham and Cretyngg, in co. Suffolk, to John Shardelowe, Thomas Songiston and others. Dated 12 June, 10 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 586.
John Wyght, rector of Creeting All Saints, and ... of Creeting aforesaid, grant to Margaret Skut and John her son three pieces of land &c. in Codenham. Dated .... Hen. [VI?]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 587.

John Glemsford, esq., John Baker of Codenham, and John Deye of the same remit and quitclaim to Roger Fathare of Codenham all their right in certain land &c. in Codenham. Dated the Saturday next after the feast of St. George the martyr, 1 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 588.

Sir John Germyk, kt., remits and quit-claims to William Wallker and Thomas Bryd, clerck all his right in lands, tenements, fields, &c. in Codenham, which they held from his father sir William Germyn, knt. Dated at Codenham the Thursday next after the feast of the Nativity of St. J. Bapt., 5 Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 589.
John ...ste of Hemyngston grants to John Skott of Codenham two pieces of land in Codenham. Dated Codenham, Monday in feast of St. Matthias, apostle, 5 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 590.

Power of attorney from WilliamBech and others to John Skutte and John Colman, jun., to deliver seisin to Robert Mersh, Robert Smyth, and Thomas Havell in 3 pieces of land lying in Codenham. Dated 4 November, 14 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 591.

Sir Simon Felbrigge and sir Roger Drury, kts., demise to William Wallere, William Petystre, and Robert, parson of Schatesham, all the lands &c. in Codynham, Creting All Saints, Creeting St. Mary, and Creeting St. Olive, which were lately John Jaune's, parson of Glemsford. Dated at Codynham the Monday next before the feast of St. Gregory the pope, 14 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 592.

John Smyth demises to John Crane, Robert Hotot, and others all his lands &c. in the parishes of Cretynge All Saints, Cretynge St. Mary, Cretynge St. Olave, and Codenham. Dated at Cretynge All Saints ....adie, 24 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 593.
Robert Havell of Nedham Market demises to John Crane and others two pieces of land in Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Friday next after the feast of the Purification, 24 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 594.

Robert Smyth and others grant to John Crane, William Greene, and others three pieces of land in Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Friday next after the feast of the Purification of the B. V. M., 24 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 595.

Robert Crane, esq., grants to William Baldewyn of Codenham and others, a piece of land called 'Snowyscroft' in Codenham, paying 8s. annually for the same. Dated at Codenham on the feast of the apostles Simon and Jude, 9 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 596.

Bond given by Anna Edgare of Codenham, widow of Reginald Edgare, late of Harwyck on £1000 to William Wallere, esq., for fulfilment of certain covenants (endorsement). Dated 4 February, 20 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 598.

Lease from Robert Crane, esq. to John Baldewyn of Codenham of a piece of land in Codenham called Benecroft, etc.; to hold for 20 years at an annual rent of 6/10d.; 21 Apr. 4 Hen. VIII. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 597

Henry Wilbockys, John Hacon, and others demise to sir Humphrey Wingfeld, kt., and others 18 messuages and certain land in the villages of Codenham, Cretyng St. Mary, Cretyng All Saints, Cretyng St. Olave, Crowfeld and Gosbacke. Dated 1 [March?] 25 Henry VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 599.

John and Philip Bore quit-claim all right &c. in a certain lease of lands, &c., made 20 Dec. 19 Henry VIII by Anne Edgare in her widowhood, and before she intermarried with William Waller, esq., deceased, to William Bore, for 30 years, to Edmund Gossenold for the remainder of the term. Dated 14 Feb., 27 Hen. VIII. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 600.

Indenture dated 5 Feb., 29 Hen. VIII, by which sir Humphrey Wyngfeld, kt., demises to Robert Crane, esq., all the lands &c. called Mimotts of the manor of Creting lying in Codenham, for 19 years, paying annually £4 10s. Signed by Wyngfeld. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 601 .

Indenture made 20 November, 38 Hen. VIII, by which John Suthwell of Darham in the co. of Suffolk, esq., sells to Robert Crane of Chilton in the co. of Suffolk, for £392 9s. 10d., his lands, messuages, &c. in the parishes of Codenham, Creeting St. Mary, Creeting All Saints, Creeting St. Olave, Crowfeld, Gosbach and Edmyngston. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 602.

Robert Crane of Chilton, esq., grants and sells to Anne Talmage a close called Bulleyarde in Codenham, with yearly quit-rent of 2d to him and his heirs as lor of the manor of Fladehall in Little Stoneham. Dated 20 January, 2 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 603.

Sir William Brooke, kt., lord Cobham, and others recite an indenture dated 14 July, 28 Elizabeth, and by this present deed at the request of Robert Crane demise to him the said Robert certain lands, tenements &c. called or known by the name of Bacons, Thedwards, Cooks of Cranes' marshes, and Gybbes in the parishes of Codenham &c. within the county of Suffolk. Dated 20 May, 29 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 604.

Augustus Campe of Woodbridge, yeoman grants to John Talemage of Codenham, yeoman for a a certain sum of money a piece of arable land in Codenham. Dated 14 October, 32 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 605.
Rental of Thedwardys, Spakys, and Colmans in Codenham &c. [Signed by 'John Southwell'] [Temp. Henry VIII.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 606.
John Talemach of Codenham, yeoman, remits and confirms to sir Robert Crane of Chilton, kt., certain premises in Codenham. Dated 20 October, 7 James I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 607.

COCKFIELD. Final concord, dated at Weston on the morrow of the Ascension, 33 Ed. I, between Nicholas de Cokfeld, plaintiff, and Robert de Wytheringdenne and Margaret his wife, and John le Rede and Milicent his wife, deforciants, by which they acknowledge the right of the said Nicholas to ten acres of land in Cokfeld, for which the said Nicholas gives 40s. MS. Ch. Suffolk 290.

COMBS, &c. Richard de Boylynd and Matilda his wife grant to Roger fitz-Peter fitz-Roger fitz-Osbert and Sarah his wife 28s. 4½d. of
annual rents arising from lands &c. in Combs ('Cambes') and elsewhere, for the sum of £20. (c. 1280-90.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1286.

CORNARD (Great). John Musket, clerk, and others confirm to William Ive of Little Waldingfield and others, one croft and three pieces of land lying in Cornard. Dated 20 April, 3? Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 291.

John Folour of Sudbury, butcher, Henry Turnour, and 5 others enfeoff John Folour, mercer, Thomas Ayloff, and 6 others with all those lands and tenements in Great Cornard, lately demised to them together with William Skalder and two others. Dated at Great Cornard, 4 September, 16 Ed. IV. [With 4 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1287.

CORTON. John, the abbot, and convent of Leystone indemnify Thomas, bp. of Norwich, and his successors, and the cathedral church of Norwich, by reason of the appropriation of the parochial church of Cortone of the patronage at the abbey for first fruits, an annual pension etc. Dated at Leystone, 10 July, 1367. MS. Ch. Suffolk 222.

Inquisition of the value of the church of Gorton, co. Suffolk, at the command of Henry, bp, of Norwich, which church had been appropriated to the use of the abbot and convent of Leystone; reported to the Bishop by Robert de Suttone, canon of St. Pauls and rector of Eyk. Dated 30 September, 1389. MS. Ch. Suffolk 223.
Illegible grant to Stephen Stares, dated at Corton, in festo Passionis ... 7 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 838.
William Cook of Great Yarmouth grants to John Martyn one piece of land in the fields of Corton. Dated at Corton, 5 May, 16 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 859.
