John Dever... (or Dener...), Richard Prentys, and Richard Ive grant four pieces of land in Corton. [Temp. Hen. VI.] [Decayed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 860.

Richard Wylde of Kessyngland, son of Thomas Wylde, senior, confirms to the said Thomas Wylde of Corton, William Wylde, his brother, and others a messuage, curtilage, and garden in Corton. Dated at Corton, . . . January, 21 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 862.

[Edmund] Jettour of Lowestoft grants to Robert Allen of Lowestoft the whole of that inclosed piece of land &c. lying in Corton. Dated at Gorton, 10 September, 2 or 3 Philip and Mary. MS. Ch. Suffolk 863.

CORTON, BRADWELL, BELTON, and GORLESTON. John Jernegan and others grant to John Jettour and others an inclosure in the parish of Corton, and the said John Jernegan alone grants to the said John Jettour and others all his lands, rents, &c. in Bradwell, Belton, and Gorleston. Dated at Bradwell, 20 August, 20 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 861.

CRANSFORD. John, the abbot, and convent of Sybeton grant leave to John, bishop of Norwich, to constitute a vicarage in the church of Cranesford, Norwich diocese appropriated to them by him, and to have the right of presentation to the same. Dated the 12 Kl. Novemb., 1309. [With seal of the abbey, perfect.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 234.

CREETING ST. MARY, CREETING ALL SAINTS, and CREETING ST. OLIVE. Sir Ralph de Buckyngge, kt., appoints Hamo del Wode his attorney to deliver seisin to William del Wode of Cretyngge St. Mary of one curtilage in the same village. Dated at Assch' near Helmingham the Sunday next after the feast of St. Botulph, 20 Ed. III. [With fragment of seal.] [See Ch. Suffolk 626.]
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1288.

Edmund Langeman of Codenham grants to John Colman, sen., son of John Colman of Codenham, one annual rent of 5s. going out of those lands and tenements in Cretyng St Mary and All Saints. Dated at Codenham the Saturday in the feast of the Translation of St. Thomas, martyr, 9 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1289.

Gerard, son of Arnold de Stanham, chaplain, grants to the church and canons of the Holy Trinity, Gipewic', in frankalmoigne, the whole of his land with messuage and wood and appurtenances in Cretinge and Stanham of the fee of the monks of Bernay, and the whole of his land in Cretinge and Croffeld which he held of Randulf de Braham, and the whole of his land which he held of Gregory Gleau in Croffeld and in Codeham, and the whole of his land in Codeham, Croffeld, and Bosemere of the fee of the monks of Eya, paying annually 6d.; for this grant the said canons gave 20 marks of silver. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 205.
Mutilated and effaced grant to the prior and canons of the Holy Trinity, Gipewic, of certain land in Creeting. (c. 1220-30.) (Witn. apparently the same as to the preceeding.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 209.

An exchange made between the prior and convent of the Holy Trinity of Ipswich, and Adam, son of William de Bolonia of Creating, namely, that the said prior and convent gave to Adam four pieces of land in the parishes of Creating and Codeham for two pieces in Creating. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 211.

Ralph le Cirzi of Stepelcreting grants to Thomas Bresingham and Petronilla his wife, for homage and service and 40s., one piece of land in the parish of Stepelcreting. (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 619.

Roger de Tuskynhed or Tuskynsack (see endorsement) grants to the church of the Holy Trinity, Ipswich, 7s. annual rent in Creting from the tenement held by Richard de Bosemere. (c. 1260-70.) (Partly effaced.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 208.

Philip Sprot of Holebec grants to Robert, son of Alexander de Sponere of Cretinge St. Mary, for 20s. in hand paid, three pieces of land in Steple Cretinge. (c. 1270-80.)
MS. Ch. Suffolk 620.

Geoffrey de Cretinge, chaplain, grants to Margaret, relict of William de Cyrescy, and William de Henleye and Felicia his wife, seven-pence halfpenny annual rents which Margaret held by the name of dower in the village of Cretingge All Saints. Dated at Cretingge St. Olave the Saturday after the feast of St. Barnabas, 7 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 608.

Robert the Shepherd ('Bercarius'), of Cretingges St. Mary, and Joan
his wife, grant to William Wystlepays of Codenham and Atheles' his wife and John their son one piece of land lying in the parish of Cretingges All Saints. Dated at Cretingges All Saints the Thursday next after the feast of St. Mary Magdalen, 8 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 609.

Robert le Talyur of Cretingge St. Olave grants to his brother Ralph le Talyur of Cretingge St. Mary one piece of land in Cretingge All Saints. Dated at Cretingge All Saints the Sunday next after the feast of St. Peter in cathedra, 10 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 610.

John de Lodene, rector of Cretingge All Saints, and Edmund de St. Olavo of Codynham grant to Bartholomew de Cyrsy and Alice his wife of Cretingge aforesaid all his lands and tenements in the villages of Cretingge St. Mary, All Saints, and St. Olave, Stonham Earls, and Codinham. Dated at Cretingge All Saints the Sunday next before the feast of St. Barnabas, 10 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 621.

Roger le Deneys of Codenham grants to Robert Spake of the same place three pieces of land lying in the parish of Cretingge All Saints. Dated at Cretingge All Saints the Wednesday next before the feast of St. Andrew the apostle, 12 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 611.

Bartholomew de Cyrresy and Alice his wife of Cretingge All Saints grant to sir William de Mandeville, chaplain of Cretingge St. Mary, certain pieces of land in the parish of Cretingge St. Mary in exchange for others in Cretingge . Dated at Cretingge All Saints the Sunday next after the feast of the# beheading of St. John Bapt., 12 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 622.

Robert de Bolonya of Cretingge St. Mary grants to William Wystlepays of Codenham one piece of pasture in Cretingge St. Mary. Dated at Cretingge St. Mary the Thursday next after the feast of the apostles SS. Simon and Jude, 17 Ed. II MS. Ch. Suffolk 623.

Robert de Hokfac of Cretingge St. Olave grants to Ralph le Slaughterer of Creeting St. Mary one piece of land lying in the parish of Creeting St. Mary. Dated at Cretingge St. Mary the Friday next before the feast of St. Luke, evang., 17 Ed II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 624.

William de Henley and Felicia his wife of Stonham demise to Richard Miles of Cretyngge St. Olave a tenement in the parish of Cretyngge All Saints, for five years, at an annual rent of 8s. Dated at Cretyngge St. Olave Thursday before feast of ... 19 Ed. II. (Partly effaced.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 612,

Grant from Thomas Sefowl of Cretingge St. Mary to Robert Strotyl and William Crispin, dated at Creeting St. Mary, Sat. in feast Nativ. B. V. M., 4 Ric. II. (For most part illegible.) (See Ch. Suffolk 624.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 613.

Robert ... grants to John de Peekham, jun., certain land in ... Dated at Cretingge the Sunday next after the feast of St. Michael, archangel, 11 Ed. III. [With seal.] [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 625.

Sir Ralph de Bockingg', kt., grants to William del Wode of Cretingge St. Mary one curtilage in the same village. Dated at Asseh' near Helmingham the Sunday next after the feast of St. Botulph, 20 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 626.

Robert del Wode ("de Bosco"), vicar of Ays, near Helmingham, grants to John, rector of the church of Schelton, and Philip Ruffus (?) of [Thornhem Magna?], all his tenements, lands, &c. in Cretingge St. Mary and Codenham. Dated at Codenham the Sunday in the feast of St. James the apostle, 24 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 627.

Amisia, who was the wife of William del Wode (de Bosco), of Cretingge St. Mary, remits and quit-claims to Robert del Wode (de Bosco), perpetual vicar of Assh'e near Helmingham, all right and claim in lands, &c. in Creting and Codenham. Dated at Assh' the Saturday next after the feast of St. Mary Magd., 24 Ed. III MS. Ch. Suffolk 628.

Agnes, daughter and heir of John de Holbat of Cretingge St. Olave, remits and quit-claims to John de Holbat, her father, all her right in a messuage and land in Cretingge St. Olave. Dated there Thursday mext after feast of St Gregory the pope 34 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 633.

Thomas Sefowl, senior, of Cretingge St. Mary appoints John Bugge his attorney to deliver to Robert Strotyl and William Crispin, of Cretingge All Saints, seisin of his lands, &c. in Cretingge aforesaid. Dated at Cretingge the Saturday on the feast of the Nativ. B.V.M., 4 Ric. II [see Ch. Suffolk 613.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 629.

John Pyn, sen., and John Smyth, of Cretingge All Saints, grant to William Crane of Stowmarket and Agnes his wife one tenement with lands and pasture which the grantors had by the gift of Thomas Sefoule in Cretingge St. Mary. Dated at Cretingge St. Mary the Thursday next after the feast of St. Martin, bp., 5 Ric. II MS. Ch. Suffolk 630.

... Neuetone (?) of Ipswich grants to John ... a messuage situated in the village of Cretingge All Saints. Dated at Cretyngge All Saints the Thursday next before the feast of St. Matthew, apostle, 8 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 614 .

John Broun of Codenham grants to Thomas Havele of Codenham one piece of land in the parish of Cretyngge All Saints. Dated at Cretyngge All Saints the Tuesday next after the feast of St. John ante port. Lat., 19 Ric. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 615.

Indenture made between the prior of the Holy Trinity, Gipp', and the convent, of the one part, and William Crane of Creting St. Mary of the other, witnesseth that the said prior and convent have granted to farm to the said William all their lands, tenements, &c. in the villages of Creting St. Mary, Creting All Saints, Creting St. Olave, Stonham Earl, Stonham Antegan, Codenham, and Creffeld, for 12 years, paying annually six marks of silver. Dated the Sunday next after the feast of St. Michael, 21 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 216.

William Crane of Codenham lets to farm to Robert de Bradestrete of Creting All Saints one tenement in the parish of Creting St. Mary called Soherthe..., for 20 years at an annual rent of 40s. and 10d. Dated on the day of the decoll. of St. John Baptist, 8 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 632.

STONEHAM. Grant from John Crane of Cana in Earl's Stoneham; Temp. Hen. IV. [Almost entirely effaced.]
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1031.

John atte Mersshe of Cretyngge All Saints grants to Richard atte Merssh his son and Robert Wighte of Colchester certain lands and tenements, &c. in the parishes of Creeting All Saints, Creeting St. Mary, Codenham, and Crowfeld. [Temp. Hen. IV.] [In greatest part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 616.

Memorandum concerning the tenements of the prior of the Holy Trinity, Ipswich, of the manor of Cretinge. "De tensmentio prioris ecclesie Trinitatis Gippewic' de muneris de Cretinge." Cent. XV [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 217.

John Skut of Stonham Earls grants to John Denny of Stonham Aspall, Thomas Upston, and Robert Thorn, three pieces of land in Cretynge All Saints. Dated at Cretingge All Saints, 21 Dec., 11 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 617.
The will of William Holbat, dated feast of SS. Phil. and James, 1443 (?or 1446). [In greatest part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 634.

Edward and John Crane, gentlemen, remit and quit-claim to William Thomas of Crowfeld and William Cooke of Cretyngge to the use of Robert Crane of Chilton, esq. all their right in lands, &c. in Creeting All Saints. Dated 20 July, .., 23 (?) Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 618.

Indenture dated 19 Jan., 20 Hen. VII, witnesseth that the prior, Rich. Foorthy and convent of Christe Chirche of the Trinite of Gippeswiche have granted to Agnes Crane, widow, their manor called Mynyotts in Creting and Coddenham for 31 years, at an annual rent of £4 l0s. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 218.

CROWFIELD. John Gerbote of Cretinge All Saints grants to John del Wode ("de Bosco") of Croffeld, chaplain, one piece of land in Croffeld. Dated at Croffeld the Sunday next before the feast of St. Peter in Chadthedra, 9 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 635.

CRUCHESTOKE, co. Norfolk. Isabella, daughter of Thomas de Rikinghale, grants to sir John de Valibus (Vaux), son of Oliver de Valibus (Vaux), 16d. of annual rent from a tenement in the fields of Cruchestoke, pad to her by John Herbert, villein of the said sir John; rendering yearly one clove. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1290.

CULPHO. Letters patent of K. Henry VIII, dated 12 May, 32nd of his reign, granting to Thomas Bacon, esq., the manor of Hessett, co. Suffolk, formerly belonging to the abbey of Bury St. Edmund, and the manor of Culpho, co. Suffolk, which belonged to the priory of Leyston, for £249 7s. 11d. MS. Ch. Suffolk 153.

CULPHO and TUDNAM. Indenture made 20 December, 1572, 15 Elizabeth, by which Robert King of Ipswick, in consideration of a marriage between himself and Anne Withepoll and 200 marks, covenants with Edmund Withepoll of Ipswick to assure to the said Anne £20 annually from lands in Culphoe and Tudnam, co. Suff. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1291.

DEBACH. William Gouthe of Cloptone, on the vigil of Easter, 31 Ed. I, grants to John, son of Alexander Norman of Cloptone, one piece of land in the parish of Debach, to the sum of 6s. for four years, paying afterwards one mark annually. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1292.

DEBENHAM. Composition between the prior and convent of Ely as appropriators of the church of Winston of the one part, and the prior and convent of Buttelee as appropriators of the church of Debenham of the other, concerning the right to certain tithes. Dated at Buttelee, 4 June, 35 Ed. III, 1361. MS. Ch. Suffolk 193.

DEBENHAM and ASPAL. Thomas Bedyngfeld, William Pakke of Bedyngfeld, William Revet of Ryshanglys and Robert Chittyng, late of Southall, demise to Robert Lyis of Aspale, Jane Pecot, late the wife of Matthew Pecot, and others, lands, tenements, &c. in Debynham and Aspale. Dated at Aspale, 4 November, 20 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1293.
DENHAM. The inquisition post-mortem on sir Edward Lewknor, kt., taken at Bury St. Edmund 22 January, 3 James I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1294.

DODNASH (Priory of). A fragment of a roll containing seven deeds of lands, &c. in the parish of Dodnash. [Temp. Ed. II, c. 1300.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 195.
(a) Maurice de Dodenach grants the whole of his land of Langelond of the fee of Morrell to Thos. de Dodenach his brother, in exchange for land of the fee of the prior of the Holy Trinity at 'Staresboteswelle.' (b) Maurice de Dodnash grants to Thomas de Dodnash his brother, for his homage and service and for half a mark, the whole of his land called Lagelond of the fee of Morrell, for an annual rent of 10d. (c) Sir Hubert de Briseworth, kt., grants to Thomas de Dodenach the whole of the tenement which he held of Maurice de Dodenach his brother in the village of Bentleye, viz. of Morrell's fee, as is witnessed in the same charter. (d) Wimerus, son of Hervey de Dodenash, grants to Thomas, son of Maurice de Dodenash his uncle, for his homage and service, the whole part of the mill of Dodenash. (e f g) Illegible.

Indenture dated at Dodenasch the Monday next before the feast of St. Michael, 1 Rich. II, by which Roger the prior and convent of Dodnash demise to John Cubbuc (Cukkuc?), sen., and John Cubbuc (Cukkuc?), jun., lands in Matyngstone, Benteleye, &c. for 9 years, paying annually 6s. 8d. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 196b.

DUNWICH. Certificate of the bailiffs John Benifice and Francis Gray and burgesses, of Dunwich given to Thomas Mighells, jun. of Leystoft, (reciting charter of K. John relieving the burgesses of Dunwich from toll, &c.,) and that the said Thomas Mighells is a burgess of Dunwich. Dated 10 Nov., 1678. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1192.

EDWARDSTON, &c. John Adam of Edwardston grants to John Westone of Newetone and Alice his wife all his tenements &c. in the villages of Edwardeston, Great Waldingfeld and Little Waldingield, Meldyng, Grotene, and Meldyng. Dated at Edwardeston the last day of Jan., 15 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 292.

John Schepherd of Great Waldingfeld and Thomas Smyth of Colne grant to Roger Potter of Edwardeston and others all their lands and tenements in the village and fields of Edwardeston and Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Edwardiston the Monday in Easter week, 22 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 293.

John Weston of Newtone grants to John Lynne of Edwardston all lands, rents, and services which he had by feoffment of John Adam of Edwardston in the village of Edwardston. Dated at Edwardston on the feast of St. John Bapt., 8 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 294.
Grant from Thomas Martell, esq. of Boxford, and others, executors of the will of John Lynne of Edwardston to his wife Elen [as in Ch. Suffolk 297]. 22 Jan. 9 Henry V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 295.

John Chilton of Colchester and John Lynne of Edwardston confirm to John Algood of Colchester, Elen Lynne and 4 others all their lands and tenements in the villages of Edwardston, Great Waldingfield and Little Waldingfield, Groton, and Meldynge. Dated at Edwardston, 26 Jan., 9 Hen. V. [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 296.

Thomas Martell of Boxford, esq., Thomas Grygge, parson of the church of Groton and others constitute Richard Crowche and others their attorneys to deliver seisin to Ellen, who was the wife of John Lynne of Edwardston, of all lands, rents, &c. in Edwardston, Great Waldingfield and Little Waldingfield, Groton, and Meldyng. Dated at Edwardston, 22 Jan., 9 Hen. V. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 297.

Walter atte Wode of Edwardston grants to William Groten, son of John Groten, and 3 others, all the lands and tenements, rents and services, &c. which were Thomas Groten's in Edwardston. Dated at Edwardston the Monday next after the feast 3 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 298.

Geoffrey Herry de Fornham All Saints and Peter Gervays of Sudbury grant to John Algood de Colchester and others their whole right and claim in lands, rents, &c. formerly John Adam's and afterwards John Lynne's in the villages of Edwardston, Great Waldingfield and Little Waldingfield, Grotene and Meldyng. Dated at Edwardston, 7 Nov., 4 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 299.

John Potter of Edwardeston grants to John Teryngton, clerk, of Sprouton, and William Englissh the lands and tenements in Edwardeston and Great Waldingfield and Little Waldingfield, which he together with John Ganges and others deceased had by gift by Walter atte Wode, and others. Dated at Edwardeston, 29 July, 10 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 300.

Thomas Appulton and others demise to John Colman and others certain crofts and lands in Edwardston and Great Waldingfield. Dated at Edwardston, 20 May, 15 Hen. VII. [Partly illegible and much rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 301.

Thomas Appulton, gent., and others confirm to John Smyth and others two messuages and two crofts adjacent and one piece of meadow lying together in the village of Edwardeston, on condition of payment of £9.13.4. by instalments. Dated at Edwardeston, i October, 13 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 302.

John Algood of Colchester, Elen his wife, and Peter Creke, clerk, demise to sir Robert Corbet, kt., Thomas Wode, and others, all their lands, rents, &c. which they acquired by the gift and feoffment of John Chilton of Colchester and John Lynne of Edwardston, situated in the villages of Edwardston, Great Waldyngfelde and Little Waldyngfelde, Groten, and Meldyngge. Dated at Edwardston, 29 June, 28 Henry VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 303.

William Baker of Edwardston and others grant to the lady Katherine Colman, late wife of John Colman, and others, certain land called Colman's Crofte in Edwardston. Dated at Edwardston, 27 October, 16 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 304.

Roger Martyn of Long Melford remits and quit-claims to Edward Colman of Little Waldingfield all his right in six messuages and lands in Edwardston, Great Waldingfeld and Little Waldingfeld, Groton, and Meldinge. Dated 1 December, 3 Ed. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 305.
Grant from .... and John son of ... to ... [Almost entirely effaced.] Dated Sunday before feast ... 14 Edward III. [With seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1295.

John Lynne of Edwardleston grants to Thomas Martell, esq., and five others, all his lands, tenements, &c. in the villages of Edwardeston, Great Waldingfield and Little Waldingfield, Groten, and Mildynge. Dated at Edwardeston, 26 August, 8 Hen. V. [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1296.

ELVEDON. Walter, son of Warine son of ... of Elvedune grants to [Peter?] son of Thomas of Elvedene, certain lands for [40s.?] and 3d. paying 4d. annually. [Partly effaced.] (c. 1250-60) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1297.

William de Lerrlinge, rector of the church of Lerlinge, remits and quit-claims to Richard de Lerlinge his son all his right in all lands and tenements which the said Richard holds in Elvedon, which the said William had from William le Parker. Dated at Lerling the after the feast of the Holy Trinity, .. Ed. II. (c. 1308-10?) MS. Ch. Suffolk 794.

William de Lerlingge, rector of the church of Lerlinge, grants to Richard de Lerlinge and William and Robert his sons ("meis"), his messuage in Elvedene. [Temp. Ed. I.] (c. 1280-90?) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1298.
Will in which all the earlier part with name and date is effaced. Apparently dated in endorsment of probate, 11 Oct. 1401. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1298.

ERYSWELL. Agreement between Robert de Tudenham, kt., and John, abbot of Bury St. Edmund, made before the judges itinerant at Catteshel 15 Ed. [I], by which upon certain conditions he renounces all claim and recognises the right of the abbot and convent of Bury to a view of frankpledge for the village of Eryswell. MS. Ch. Suffolk 93.

ESTON. Ralph de Beauchamp confirms to the sick brethren of the hospital of St. Peter without St. Edmund, in frankalmoigne, sixpence from his demesne at Eston for the soul of his wife Agnes etc.; to be paid on the altar of the chapel on the day of her death, viz. 10 March. (c. 1210-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 13.

EUSTON. Edmund Rokewoode of Euston, esq., son and heir of Roger Rokewoode, late of Euston, confirms to master William Fotere, clerk, the whole of his manor of Euston with the advowson of the church. Dated and signed at Euston, 20 August, 5 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1300.

FAKENHAM, &c. An exemplification of a recovery inrolled Easter term, 20 and 21 Henry VIII, Roll 104, by which Richard Candysshe, William Latymer, John Valentyne, Robert Goodwyn, and Robert Dobet impleaded Robert Brounde concerning the manors of Payton hall, Russells in Fakenham, and Russells in Chesylford, with appurtenances, and likewise certain land, brushwood, rent, &c. in Fakenham, Chesylford, Bewedesey, Alderton, Sutton, Shatesham,
Kyrton, Walton, Orford, Whavensden, Sudborn, Rampfold, and Ipswich. Dated at Westminster, 28 April, 21 Henry VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1301.

FLIXTON. John, son and heir of William Fuston, grants to Robert Jetour of Lowestoft and others two pieces of land containing ten acres lying in Flixton, also certain land and a messuage in Flixton. Dated at Flixton on the feast of St. Nicholas, bp., 17 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 864.

Indenture dated 4 April, 18 Hen. VIII, by which Agnes, late wife of Robert Stares of Blundeston, and William Wrentham, executors of the will of the said Robert Stares, sell to John Harvy of Oulton, gent. a close of ten acres called Doles Lombys and a piece of copyhold in Flixton, co. Suff. for £10. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 865a.

Indenture dated 6 April 22 Queen Elizabeth, by which John Jernegan of Somerleyton demises to John Warde one marsh in the village of Flixton for 800 years at an annual rent of 6s. 8d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 866.
William Sydnor of Blundeston and Henry his son grant to Robert Mighells a tenement situated in the village of Flixton. Dated 3 Oct., 30 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 867.

Institution by the archbishop of Canterbury, Whitgift (signed to him) in consequence of a vacancy in the see of Norwich, of Clement Bacon, priest, to the church of Flixton, on the presentation of the Crown by lapse. Dated 25 Nov. 1602. MS. Ch. Suffolk 868.

Indenture made 25 March, 8 James I, by which Clement Bacon, parson of Flixton, leases to John Symonds of St. Stephen's, Norwich his rectory &c. of Flixton for 21 years at an annual rent of l0s. [On paper.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 869.

Edward Elles of Blundeston and Umfrey Croswell of the same place quit-claim to sir John Wentworth of Somerleton, knt. all their right and claim to commonage in Flixton Fermside adjoining to the great common water in Blundeston. Dated 23 December, 5 Chas. I, 1629. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 870.

Indenture made 29 June, 5 Charles I, by which Anthony Wilkenson of Burnam Westgate, co. Norfolk, clerck, demises to Sir John Wentworth the free chapel or rectory of Flixton for 40 years, at an annual rent of one peppercorn if demanded. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 871.

FLIXTON, OULTON, BLUNDESTON, CORTON, and BELTON. Richard Mighell of Lowstofte, gent. grants to Robert Mighell his son, in consideration of a marriage between him and Joan Godding of Gippewic, daughter of Edward Goodding, the manor of Flixton, lands, tenements, rents, &c., lying and being in the above villages. [With seal.] Dated 26 ..., 33(?) Eliz. [In great part illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 865b.

FORNHAM. Richard, son of Anchisis of St. Edmund, quit-claims, in the hundred of Thinghoghe, for him and his heirs, to Thomas the goldsmith of St. Edmund and his heirs, the whole service of William, son of Alric of the monastery, viz. 3s. which was yearly due from him for the whole fee he held in the field towards Fornham, called Clipeshoghe. For this quit-claim
the said Thomas gave 3 marks of silver and one gold coin ("aureum"). (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 15.

Samson, the abbot of St. Edmund, grants to Henry, son of Thurstan, and his heirs, the mill called 'Salemundesforde,' with land and meadows customarily paying an annual rents of 27s., less 2d. to the abbot's hall at Fornham; to hold by free service, for the payment annually at the hall of Fornham of 30s.; also he grants eight acres at 'Hemegrethe' at 2s., annual rent. (1184-1211.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 21.

Samson, the abbot of St. Edmund, grants to Ailmar, son of Ailward de Fornham, the mill which is called 'Ailmeres Heine' at a rent of 30s.; also a little meadow at the head of the mill-pond, [which mill used to pay an annual rent of 26s.] for which he is to render to the hall of Fornham the customary rent of seven ploughshares, with leave to have no ewer free from feldage, to hold the same by heirship. (1184-1211.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 23.

Robert de Livermere, son of Hunfrid of St. Edmund, grants to the church of St. Edmund and the monks there, in frankalmoigne, all the tenements, with messuages &c., which Nicholas, son of Walter his uncle, held of him in the village of Fornham with 2s. annual rent; for which the said Nicholas had from the convent 12 marks, and the said Robert two marks. Witn. Gregory the prior, Stephen Alderman. (c. 1240.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 35

Thomas the goldsmith, of St. Edmund, sells and quit-claims to the hospital of St. Saviour for 3 marks the service &c. of William, son of Elric of the monastery, viz. 3s. from his fee in the field of Fornham, called Clipeshoghem, reckoned at 17 acres. (c. 1240-50.) [Richard de Sexham, warden of the Hospital] [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 49.

John, son of Aluric de Fornham, grants to Peter de Burgo, for his homage and service and for 10s., half an acre of land in Fornham, at an annual rent of 1d. for all services, (c. 1250.) [Small fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 60.

William de Shellond of St. Edmund grants to sir Richard, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund, in frankalmoigne, 6d. of annual quit-rent arising out of five acres of arable land in Fornham formely Ralph Kempe's, for the use of the latter. Dated at St. Edmund the Monday next after the feast of the Invention of the Cross, 19 Ed. II. [With seal.] Witn. John de Synaln and William de Rudham, bailiffs, Richard de Bertone, alderman MS. Ch. Suffolk 101.

John de Flemton, chaplain, grants to the abbot and convent of St. Edmund a messuage and 35 acres and a half of land in Fornham and Symworth for the support of the office of chamberlain. Dated at Fornham All Saints, the Thursday on the morrow of St. Laurence [i.e. the archbishop, nnot the deacon], 29 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 106.

FOXHALL, CODDENHAM, CRETING, and STONHAM. Sir Thomas Pope, kt., for a certain consideration gives seisin to sir John Jermy, kt., the manors of Foxhall, Codenham, Creting, and Stonham, formerly popepions of the priory of the St. Trinity at ... Dated 20 September, 37 Hen. VIII. [On paper.] (Mutilated.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1302.

FRAMLINGHAM. Richard de Swynbume, master of the grammar schools of Framlingham, and Joan his wife, daughter of Geoffrey Dynes, grant to John de Paston of the same place one piece of pasture called 'Herstwelille.' Dated at Framlingham the .... after the feast of the apostles SS. Peter and Paul. .. Ed. III. (c. 1330-40) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1303.

FRITTON. John Pekkere, vintner, of London, remits and quit
claims to sir John Fastolf, knight, John Fitz Rauff, John Fristolf of Offlton, esqs., and John Kyrteling, clerck, all his right and claim to the manor of Freton in Freton called Caldecotes, and to rents and tenements in Freton and Belton. Dated 12 March, 12 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 873.

Indenture dated 1 June, 29 Elizabeth, by which John Kemp of Antyngham, Norfolk, leases to William Sydnor of Blundeston the waters and fishing of the manor of Calcott within the parish of Fritton for ... years, paying annually for the same a certain quantity of eels and roach. [On paper.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 874.

Indenture made 14 James I, between William Sydnor of Blunston, in the county of Suffolk, esquire, and Thomas Kempe and Francis Brewater, being a grant of the manor of Fritton to William Tampon. [Mutilated and in great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 875.
Mutilated and almost entirely effaced agreement between John de Fritton of the one part, and ... [Temp. Hen. III] MS. Ch. Suffolk 872.

GISSING, co. Norfolk. Confirmation by Nicholas the prior and convent of Norwich of a confirmation by Roger bp. of Norwich of a grant by his predecessor John, c. 1200-06, of the appropriation of the church of Gyssing to the monastery of Buttele. Dated 14 kal. Nov. 1266; the bishop's confirmation being dated at Hevenengham. MS. Ch. Suffolk 191.

GLEMSFORD, &c. Robert, son of Walter de Glemsford, grants to Richard, son of Richard the clerk of Crungetorp, for his homage and service and 20s., 2 acres 3½ roods of arable land in Glemesford, paying annually 12d. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 306.

Robert Honden of Glemesford grants to John, son of Richard Aylyth of the same place, and Beatrice his wife, one piece of meadow in Glemesford. Dated at Glemesford ... 9 Ed. II. [Mutilated] MS. Ch. Suffolk 307.

John, son of Robert Honeden of Glemesford, grants to Geoffrey de Heneys and Matilda his daughter one piece of arable land in Glemesford. Dated at Glemesford the Sunday next after the feast of St. Michael, 17 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 308.

Grant from Robert Trigg to John Sutton(?), clerk, Thomas Gonste, John Fuller and Joan Caleys of the manor of Glemysford, Caundyssk, Boxford etc. Glemysford 28 Feb 4 Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 309.

Andrew Atte Fen', Gilbert Chaumbre, and Adam Rande of Glemysford grant to William Atte Fen, son of said Andrew, land &c. lying in Glemsford. Dated at Glemysford, 10 November, 6 Hen. IV. [Much effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 310.
Will of Thomas Caleys of Glemesford, gentleman, made at Storteford, co. Hertford, Sunday, 21 June, 1439, 7 Hen. VI. [A large part entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 311.

Letter of administration by John Lyndefeld, Dean of Arches, and commissary of the archbishop of Canterbury, concerning the will of Thomas Caleys of Glemesford. [Temp. Hen. VI.] [Rubbed adn slightly mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 312.

William Atte Fen of Glemsford grants to John Susanne of the same place the whole of a messuage, garden, and croft, antiently called Boystour Walle, in Glemsford, together with other lands situated in the same village. Dated at Glemsford, 8 July, 29 Hen. VI. (See Ch. Suffolk 320.) [Much rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 313.
William Panell (?) and others demise to John Petywette and others one croft of land lying in the village of Glemsford. Dated 29 April, 21 Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 314.

Walter Caleys, alias Ymworthe, citizen and merchant tailor of London, son and heir of Thomas Caleys, alias Ymworth, of Glemsford, deceased, grants to Walter Cotton of Glemsford and others all his lands, tenements, services, &c., formerly his father's, in Glemsford, Cavendish, Boxstead, and Stonstead. Dated at Glemsford, 4 May, 22 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 315.

Indenture made 2 December, 26 Hen. VI, between Walter Caleys of Glemsford of the one part, and Robert Snowe of Storteford of the other part, witnesseth that whereas the said Walter is bound in a sum of 200 marks by a bond dated as above to Thomas Bawd, squier, and others, payable at Whitsuntide next, upon condition that he shall sue Robard Trygge for all the lands in Glemsford, Milford, Stansted, Bokstede, and Cavendyssh, which the said Walter late made an estate of trust to the said Robard, and that the said lands shall remain to Walter and his heirs, and in default to Robert Snow and Elizabeth his wife and the heirs of the said Elizabeth. In default bond to stand good. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 316.

John Gardyner and Richard Bonys of Glemsford grant to Robert Rote, William Sowhele, John Sowhele, and others, one piece of land called Kyllelond in Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford, 2 November, "s[eptimo?]" Hen. VI. [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 317.

John, son of John Roote of Glemsford, grants to John Skynnere of Glemsford and others two crofts of arable land in the field called Wilwenefeld and four pieces of land lying in the village of Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford, 14 September, 28 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 318.

Walter Whytebred of London quit-claims to John Dalton, clerk, and others, all his right and claim in the manor of Caleys and all that belongs to it in the villages of Glemsford, Cavendish, Boxsted, and Stansted. Dated at Glemsford, 2 March, 26 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 319.

John Susanne of Glemsford, chaplain demises to William Atte Fen and Katherine his wife, and others, a messuage, garden, &c. in Glemsford, and certain land lying within the same parish called 'Boystourwalle.' Dated at Glemsford, 24 July, 29 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 320.

John Skynnere of Glemsford, and John Glemsford, otherwise called John Trokett of Somerton, grant to Robert Warde of Glemsford and others one piece of land in the parish of Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford 14 May, 30 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 321.

Agnes, late the wife of Thomas Boure of Heseth, daughter and heir of Baldwin de Tilney, grants to John Alynton and others all her lands, rents, &c. in Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford, 8 January, 37 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 322.
John Fuller of Glemsford grants to John West, parson of Stansted, and others one piece of land in Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford, 2 October, 38 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 323.

John Fullere of Somerton and Thomas Strut of Glemsford grant to John West, parson of the church of Stansted, and others, one piece of land in Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford, 2 October, 38 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 324.

William ... of Glemsford and John Bakere demise to John atte Hoo and others a messuage and all that belongs to it in Glemsford, called Boystourwall. Dated at Glemsford. 20 January, 38 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 325.

Thomas Goldyng of Glemsford and John Goldyng of the same place demise to William and John Petywatte of Glemsford one croft of land in the street called 'Fremanstrete.' Dated at Glemsford, 30 October, 11 Ed. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 326.

John Clopton, esq., William Chapman, gentleman, William Gemelyn of Glemsford, and John Goldyng demise to Richard Heelys of Glemsford and others a piece of arable land in Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford, 6 April, 13 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 327.

Richard Ward of Glemsford demises to John Golding, clothmaker, William Hyllys, John Petywelle and others all his lands, tenements, &c. in Glemsford and Cavendish. Dated at Glemsford, .. Feb. 18 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 328.
John Clopton and Thomas Strut grant to Richard Ward and others one piece of pasture in the village of Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford, 20 March, 2 Rich. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 329.

Edmund Felton of Sudbury quit-claims to John Goldyng, sen., of Glemsford, all his right and claim in three pieces of arable land in Gravell pette feld in Glemsford. Dated 6 June, 9 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 330.

Richard Warde of Glemsford confirms to William Hillis, John Goldyng, sen., of Glemsford, John Goldyng, sen., of Poslyngforth, Thomas Strut, and John Goldyng, son of John Goldyng of Glemsford, one croft of arable land &c. called Hold Chambyriscroft lying in Glemsford, also one piece of land lying in Pentlow, co. Essex, and he appoints John Cobbe and Richard Greene of Glemsford his attorneys to deliver seisin of the same. Dated at Glemsford, 13 February, 18 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 331.
Memorandum from the court roll, 20 Hen. VII, passing certain land from the lord to John Cobbe and his heirs, according to the custom of the manor. MS. Ch. Suffolk 332.

Indenture made 20 October, 22 Hen. VII, by which Joan Warde, late wife of Rychard Warde of Glemsford, and John Warde her son, agree to pay unto Gilis Elise of Long Melford, clothmaker the rent of a piece of ground in Glemsford that Richard Warde in his lifetime exchanged with Jamys Millis of Glemsford, and since has been sold unto the said Gilis Elise. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 333.

Thomas, son and heir of John Miller late of Glemsford, grants to Giles Elice of Melford, and others, lands, tenements, &c. in Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford, 23 Hen. VII. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 334.

Memorandum that at the court of the manor of Caleis in Glemsford, held there the Friday next after the feast of St. Lucy the virgin, 24 Hen. VII, the lord granted to Walter Soppyng ((?)eoppyng?) one piece of land lying opposite to 'Mille Strete.' MS. Ch. Suffolk 335.

William Hillys of Danbury in Essex, in performance of a certain agreement between him and John Brewster of Glemsford, grants to the said John a messuage, garden, and land in Glemsford. Dated 10 July, 29 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 336.

John Wright of Glemsford quit-claims to Thomas Manwode of Glemsford all his right in certain lands and tenements in Glemsford, which he had in conjunction with John Goldyng, senior and Thomas Strut. Dated at Glemsford, 14 June, 6 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 337.

Memorandum that at a manor court for Medewolds and Wymbolds in the parish of Glemsford, held the Tuesday on the feast of St. Dionisius, 7 Hen. VIII, William Medewold, esq., granted to Margery Jakis, widow, one tenement called Culstons, with a garden &c., by the service of 6s. 8d. annually and one capon. MS. Ch. Suffolk 338.

At a court of William Medewold, esq., held the Tuesday on the feast of St. Dionisius, 7 Hen. VIII, John Hall delivered into the hands of the lord a little "pightell" of pasture for the use of Walter Berdfeld, to hold the same according to the custom of the manor. MS. Ch. Suffolk 339.
John Petywatt of Glemsford, clothmaker, sells to John Holborowe, William Holborowe, and others three pieces of arable land in Glemsford. Dated 31 May, 20 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 340.

Richard Redyngton of Glemsford in Suffolk, kerver, acknowledges to have received of John Smyth of Cavendish, gent., by the hands of Robert Ailmer of Glemsford, five marks sterling in part payment of a greater sum for a tenement lying in Glemsford. Dated 13 January, 23 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 341.

John Goldynge att Angell of Glemsford, clothmaker, in consideration of the receipt of £13 6s. 8d., sells to John Smythe land, tenements, wood, f&c. in the parish of Glemsford. Dated at Glemsford, 2 April, 27 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 342.

John Raye of Denardston, yeoman, quit-claims to Thomas Manwode of Glemsford all right in three crofts, one piece of arable land, and a little grove of wood in the parish of Glemsford, in Fremanstrete which the said John Raye acquired as security for £14 13s. 4d. Dated 20 January, 29 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 343.
The will of John Brewster of Glemsford, clothier, dated 11 October, 1547. Probate attached, dated 21 October, 1547. [With blank fragment of seal.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 344a, 344b.

Memorandum that at the first court of John Alen held for the
manors of Caleis Methwolds, Wymbolds, and Tylneys, 28 July, 11 Elizabeth, it was presented that John Fyrmyn surrendered certain lands into the hands of the lord to the use of George Hicks and his heirs, &c. MS. Ch. Suffolk 345.
Bond whereby John Allen of Glemsford is bound to John Jermyn of Debden in a sum of £700. Dated 29 November, 31 Elizabeth. [With 3 seals, one armorial, another of the staple.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 346.
John Jermyn of Debden, esq., grants to Thomas Banks and Stephen de le P... in Glemsford, Cavendish, Stanstead, and ... Dated 7 October, 32 Elizabeth. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 347

Indenture dated 2 October, 32 Q. Elizabeth, by which John Jermyn sells to Thomas Banks and Stephen de la Prend, of Haverhill, certain lands in Glemsford, for £700. [The greater part illegible.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 348a.
Indenture dated ... Elizabeth by which John and William Allen sell to John Jermyn of Debden certain lands in Glemsford. [Almost entirely effaced.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 348b.
An abstract of the fines and amerciaments held at the court of Glemsford, 27 April, 27 Charles I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 349.

GORLESTON. Joan, relict of William de ... quit-claims to Geoffrey de B... , for a certain sum of money, one plot of land in Gorlestone. Dated at Gorlestone the Saturday next after the feast of All Saints, 8 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1304.

Thomas Kandeler of Gorlestone grants to Richard Cristemesse of Somerleyton and Isabella his wife a messuage with a curtilage lying in the village of Gorlestone. Dated at Gorlestone, the Thursday of St. Faith, 3 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 876.

Reginald Drowrie of Gorleston, butcher, with the assent of Agnes his wife, sells to Thomas Boyse, sen., of Belton, a tenement &c. lying in Gorleston. Dated at Gorleston, 1 June, 5 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 879.
Margaret Oldringe of Gorleston, daughter and heir of Richard Oldringe, grants to Reginald Drowrye one tenement lying in Gorleston. [c. 1600 (date entirely effaced)] MS. Ch. Suffolk 880.

George Harcocke of Haddysco Thorpe, Norfolk, yeoman, grants to James Hubberde, gent., in consideration of a certain sum of money, one messuage and two gardens situated in Little Jernemuth, Gorleston, and Southerton. Dated 17 April, 21 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 881
Nicholas Haverd of Gorleston, yeoman, grants to John Wentworth of Somerleton, esq. a messuage in Gorleston. Dated 21 January, 39 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 882.
William Ward of Kingston on Hull, co. York, grants to William Bradefeild of Gorleston parcel of one tenement in Gorleston called Oldrins. Dated 3 January, 1598. MS. Ch. Suffolk 883.
William Dunston of Bedingfeild, co. Suffolk, yeoman, conveys to John Wentworth, sen., of Somerleyton, esq., a tenement &c. in Gorleston, co. Suffolk. Dated 24 Nov., 2 James I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 884.

GORLESTON, BRADWELL, and GAPTON. John, son and heir of Robert Gappe of Bradwell, conveys to Thomas Banyard, gent., and three others, six pieces of land lying in the villages of Gorleston, Bradwell, and Gapton, also a tenement and piece of land in Bradwell. Dated at Gorleston, 20 April, 20 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 877.

GORLESTON, HOPTON, and GORTON. Indenture dated 20 July, 26 Hen. VIII, by which John Lavyle and Rose his wife, late wife of John Lampet in consideration of marriage to be solemnised between William Lavyle, son and heir of the said John, and Katherine Lampet, daughter of the said John Lambert and the said Rose, enfeoffs them with lands &c. in Gorleston, Hopton, and Gorton, in co. Suffolk. MS. Ch. Suffolk 878.

GOSBECK. Indenture made between Gilbert de [Debenham] of the one part, and John [Jaune, William Deneys, and John] Chapman, of Codenham of the other part, by which ... an annuity of 13s. 4d. from lands &c. in the village of Gosbeck. Dated [Thursday after] on the feast of St. Peter ad vinc., 15 Rich. II. [With seal.] [For the most part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 636.

CRETINGHAM. Richard Flur(?) grants to sir Roger le Denays of Gretingham, the lady Matilda his wife, William le Denays their son and his wife and Roger his son, and others, for 6 marks of silver sterling, certain land in the village of Stepel Creeting(?). [Temp. Ed. I (c. 1260-70).] [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1306.
GROTON. Nicholas Cokerel of Groten grants to Henry Melksop of Melding for 15s. one piece of arable land in the village of Groten. (c. 1270-80.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1305.
Effaced charter, dated 36 Ed. III: a grant to William C... MS. Ch. Suffolk 350.
Edward Appulton grants to Adam Wyntropp a pasture and certain land in Groton. Dated at Groton, 20 June, 2 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 351.

GUNTON. Robert, son of Nicholas le Poor of Goneton, appoints Geoffrey, son of sir John de Askeby, his attorney to receive 2½d. at the feast of St. Michael, (which falls to him by heirship by the death of Robert son of Adam le Poor), from Robert son of Roger de Gonetone for two pieces of land in Gonetone. Dated 15 Ed. [I]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 885.

HADLEIGH. John, son of William Segge of Hadlege, and Agnes, daughter of William son of Wydne, grant to Robert le Ro of Edwardeston, and Matilda, daughter of Thomas le Chalmere of Hadlege, for 20s. the half of a tenement in Hadlege. (c. 1270-80.)
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1308.

Sir Richard Waldegrave acknowledges to have received of John Doyle 20s. as a reasonable aid both for making Richard his eldest son a knight, and for marrying Isabella his daughter. Dated 12 July, 28 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1445
The will of John Doyle of Hadlegh, co. Suffolk, gent., made 15 August, 1483. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1307a.
Probate attached, dated 9 October, 1483. [With seals, seal of arms and fragment of archepiscopal seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1307b.

Sir Henry Wentworth, kt., and others appoint [blank] to receive of Edward Doyle, esq., in their name, seisin of and in the manors of Pondhall and Corsford in Suffolk and other lands elsewhere in Leicestershire, Derbyshire and Northampton. Dated 8 Nov., 12 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1309.

The particulers of the "moneys of the guylds in Hadleygh" [tenants rents?], viz. Trinity guild, Corpus Christi guild, St. John's guild ..., and our Lady guild. [Temp. Hen. VIII.] [Mutilated.] [On paper.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1310.

Bond given by Robert Abbes of Hadleigh, clothier, in £200 for performance of covenants in a certain indenture between him and Roger Rolff of Hadleigh, clothier. Dated 26 May, 4 and 5 Philip and Mary. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1311.

Indenture by which Robert Rolfe of Grey's Inne, Middlesex, gent., son and heir of Roger Rolfe of Hadley, deceased, approves and ratifies to Thomas Atkinson of Hadley all right and title to a capital mansion, &c. in Hadley, which the said Thomas purchased of him and Edward Colman of Great Waldingfield. Dated 28 October, 24 Elizabeth. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1312.

HANFORD. William de Badele quit-claims to the church of SS. Peter and Paul of Gypewic', in frankalmoigue, the gift which Roger de Badele his brother made to them of the half of the mill of Haneford. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 204.

HASELWODE. William Hebbys of Hasylwode grants to John ...kele one piece of meadow lying in the village of Hasylwode. Dated at Hasylwode, 10 Hen. [IV]. [Mutilated, and in great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1193.

HAVERHILL, &o. Thomas Master, clerk, rector of Somerleton, and Roger Page of Bury St. Edmund, grant to John Aleyn and 26 others the whole of the messuage in which the father of the said Thomas lately , with all the lands, &c. to the same messuage pertaining, also all the lands formerly John Kelyng's, also the lands of John Payne which were afterwards the said Thomas Master's in the villages and fields of Haverhill, Kedyngton, Little Wratting, and Bumpsted Helyon, in the counties of Suffolk and Essex. Dated at Haverhill, 21 March, 13 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1313.

Thomas Master, rector of Somerleyton, and Roger Page of Bury St. Edmund, executors of the will of Thomas Master, late of Haverhill, recite the last will (dated 4 November, 1473) of the said Thomas Master, father of Thomas Master, rector of Somerleyton. Dated at Haverhill, 21 March, 13 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1314.

HELMIWGHAM. Thomas de Helmingham, chaplain, grants to sir John de Lampet, chaplain, for his homage and service, one piece of land in the village of Helmingham, paying annually for the same four-pence. (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 637.

HEMMINGSTON. Robert Thedware of Codenham grants to Geoffrey his son, chaplain, five pieces of land in the village of Hemmingestun, for five marks. Dated at Codenham on the day of St. Francis the confessor, 24 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 638.

HENGRAVE. Anselm, the abbot of St. Edmund, grants to Leo and his heirs the manor of Hemegrede in fee and heirship, to hold of the altar of St. Edmund and of the sacristan, to pay on the altar each year at stated times 100s., &c. [With fragment of seal.] (c. 1130-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 2.

HENGRAVE, &c. Chirograph by which Hugh, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund grant and confirm to William, son of Leo, and his heirs after him, the manor of Hemmegredhe; also the whole of the land which his father Leo held in Westleia of the hall of Fornham, and land in Cheventona of the hall of Cheventona, and land which he held in Sexham of the hall of Sexham, &c.; paying 110s. for Hemmegredhe, 4s. at the hall of Fornaham for Westleia, 3s. at the hall of Cheventona for Cheventona, and 12d. at the hall of Sexham. (1157-80.) [Printed in Gage's Thingoe Hundred, 1838, pp. 165-66.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 4.
HENSTEAD. Humphrey Yermouth of Hensted remits and quitclaims to William Sydnor of Blundeston, esq. all causes of action against him. Dated 2 August, 16 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1194.
Bond given by Richard Sallowes of Benacre in £70 to William Sydnor, for the performance of certain covenants. Dated 3 May, 24 Eliz. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1197.
Richard Sallowes, for a certain sum of money in hand paid, grants to William Sydnor of Blondeston a messuage and 16 pieces of land in Hensted. Dated 3 May, 24 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1195,

Edward Fleetcroft of Henstede, husbandman, in consideration of a certain sum of money, grants to William Sydnor of Blundeston two pieces of land in Hensted. Dated at Hensted, 18 November, 32 Q. Eliz. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1196.

HERRINGFLEET. Ralph, son of William de Ferya, grants to the church of St. Olave, Herlingflete, in frankalmoigne, 7d. annual rent, viz. from Hugh, son of Gilbert de Blundeston, and his heirs, 6d. for a tenement in Somerleyton, and 1d. from Hugh de Elmesete for a piece of land in Herlingflete. (c. 1240-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 201.

John Gernegan grants to his father Peter Gernegan and Elenor his wife the moiety of the manor of Somerlestone, with a mill etc. to hold for their lives paying annually 40s. Dated at Somerletone ... (c. 1320-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 202.
The will of the lady Beatrice relict of sir Peter, son of Roger Fitz-Osbert, dated Saturday after feast of St. Hilary, [42 or 52] Hen. III. [Greater part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 200.
Isabella ..., in her lawful widowhood, sells to Geoffrey, son of John of Askeby, the whole of her turbary in Herlingflet. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 886.

William, son of John le Gos of Herlingflet, grants to John de Herlingflet, le taliur, a piece of land lying in the fields of Herlingflet. Dated at Herlingflet, St. Gregory's day, 32 Ed. [I]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 887.

Adam Fairman of Northmersk (?) grants to Richard Cok, burgess of Great Jernemuth and Avicie his daughter a piece of a marsh and a piece of meadow in Herlingflet. Dated at Great Jernemuth, 33 Edw. fil. Hen., without date of day. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1444.

Agatha, formerly wife of Nicholas de Freton, grants to Robert de Eye [her brother?] certain lands, &c., together with 10d. annual rent, in Herlingflet. Dated at Freton the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Lucy, virg., 33 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 888.
Illegible charter. Dated at [Heryngflet, Michaelmas day?], 9 Ed. II. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1315.

Richard Peris of Blundiston and Alicia his wife grant to William, son of Thomas Borel of Herlingflet, one rood of land lying in two pieces in Herlingflet. Dated the Tuesday on the feast of St. Katherine, 12 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 889.

John de la Mers of Heryngflet, grants to Henry de la Hyl of Somerleton and Joan his wife one piece of arable land in the village of Heryngflet. Dated at Heryngflet on the feast of St. Luke the evangelist, 43 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 891.

John, son of Robert Pain of Herlingflet, junior, grants to Richard Stulbere and Margaret his wife one piece of land in Herlingflet. Dated Friday before feast of SS. Simon and Jude, 20 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 892.

Robert Neve of Askeby grants to Simon de Banburgh, parson of Askeby, the half of a marsh in Heryngflet. Dated at Heryngflet the Sunday next after the feast of St. Faith, 48 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 893.

William ... of Somerleton grants to Richard Austyn one piece of land in Heryngfleet. Dated at Heryngfleet the Thursday after the feast of the apostles SS. Philip and James, 21 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 894.

John Andrew, son of the late John Andrew of Heryngflet, grants to Robert ... messuage and lands in Heryngflet. Dated at Heryngflet the Sunday after the feast of St. Mark Evang. 6 Henry IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 895.

Thomas Bawde of Great Chesterforth, Essex, and Cecilia his wife appoint Thomas Eddewyn and Thomas Benet their attorneys to deliver seisin of a certain tenement in Heryngflete called Newtonys to Thomas Belstede of Mulkeberton, co. Norfolk, and Robert Howorth , clerk. Dated 5 Feb., 6 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 896.

John Curlw, clerk, Isabella Curlw, relict of Robert Smyth, William Hay, and Adam Foster of London demise and confirm to John Fastolf of Great Yarmouth all those lands &c. in the villages of Heryngfleet, Haskeby, and Somerleton which they had by the gift of Roger Mettfelde of Menham, William Leons of Castro St. Edmund, and Thomas Fyncham of Norwich. Dated at London on the day of St. James, 10 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 897.

Thomas Banstede remits to John, son of Alexander Fastolf, all his right which he has in certain lands, meadows, and pastures in Heryngflete and villages adjacent. Dated at Heryngflete, 8 February, 2 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 898.
The will of Henry Reppys of Heryngflet. Dated at Heryngflet, 14 Dec., 4 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 899.

Henry atte Mersch, chaplain of Becclys and Richard Cristemasse of Somerleton grant to John Terald of Asby and Richard atte Dole of the same one half acre of land in Haryngflete. Dated at Haryngflete, 20 June, 6 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 900.
Illegible charter, [dated 15 January, 1 Hen. VII?]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 902.

Thomas Deryng and Robert Bugge grant to Robert Curtes Edward his son, and Nicholas Edwardys one piece of land lying in Heringflete called Growelond. Dated at Heringflete, 12 April, 28 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 907.
Thomas Cady of Stoke and Thomas Gooff quit-claim to Richard Jenney, esq., all their right in a messuage &c. in Heryngflete. Dated .. Feb. 16 Henry VIII. [Partly obliterated] MS. Ch. Suffolk 908.
John Mytes of Heringflet sells to John Mellinge a messuage and 8 acres of land in Heringflete. Dated at Heringflete, 30 November, 42 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 909.

HERRINGFLEET and ASKEBY. Robert Stevyn (?)of Halys and John Carable of Horsham, chaplain, grant to John de la Merhs, sen., John de Merhs, jun., and others, all their messuages &c. lying in Herlyngflet and Askeby. Dated at Herlyngflet the Thursday before the feast of St. Margaret, virg., 35 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 890.

HERRINGFLEET, ASKEBY, and BILDESTON. Margaret Freman of Becclys, widow, grants to Robert Manwode, John Fen, and William Symond, all of Becclys all the messuages, lands, &c. in Heryngflet, Askeby, and Beldeston, in the counties of Norfolk and Suffolk, with others as contained in divers writings. Dated 20 May, 10 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 901.

HERRINGFLEET, ASKEBY, and SOMERLEYTON. Henry Ryppes, senior, and Henry Ryppes his son, grant to sir Robert Drury, knight, and Edward Jernegan, esq., all their lands and tenements situated in Heryngflet, Ashby, and Somerleton. Dated 24 day of March, 21 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 905.

Indenture made [9?] March, 21 Hen. VII, by which sir Robt. Drury, knight, and Edward Jernegan, esq., purchase of Henry Reppes, the father, and Henry Reppes his son, all their lands, tenements, rents, and services in Heryngflet, Askeby otherwise called Asheby, and Somerleton. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 906.

Henry Ryppes, senior, gentleman, and Henry his son, grant to sir Robert Drury, kt., and Edward Jernegan, esq., all their lands &c. in Heryngflet, Asseby alias Assheby, and Somerleton. Dated 24 March, 21 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 904.

Sir John Hevyngham, kt., according to the intention of the last will of John Reppys, late of Heryngflet, gent., grants to Thomas Jermy of Stokesby and 5 others those messuages and tenements called Smethes and Newetons in the villages of Heryngflet and Somerleton and Ash[eby?]. Dated at Haryngflet S... 5 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 903.

HEPWORTH. Indenture witnessing that Robert Sutton of Bury St. Edmund, master of the chantry of John Smith, esq., at the altar of St. Mary, and seven others, demise to John Brimdissh, coloper and William his son a parcel of land with a house newly built thereon in the village of Hepworth, for 80 years, at an annual rent of 6d. Dated at Hepworth, 16 March, 24 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 149.

HESSET. Indenture witnessing that William, the abbot of Bury Seynt Edmund, and the convent of the same have demised to Thomas Bakon of Heggesset their manor of Heggesset pertaining to the office of the tresory of their monastery, for 20 years, at an annual rent of £8. Dated 12 Sept., 19 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 137.

Indenture by which William, the abbot, and the convent of Bury St. Edmund have demised to Thomas Bakon of Heggesset their manor of Heggesset, for 20 years, paying annually to the treasurer of the monastery £8. Dated 12 September, 19 Hen. VII. [English] [Marked 138* on the charter but there is no 138.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 138b.

John, the abbot, and the convent of Bury St. Edmund grant to Thomas Bacon of Heggesset called two acres and a half of pasture, part of the common of the manor of Heggesset, with the consent of all their tenants, in exchange for 2½ acres of the said Thomas Bacon's lying in the same village. Dated 5 April, 24 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 148.
BURY. The (long) will of Henry de Heleweton, dated at St. Edmund the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Botulph, 1274. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 75.

HINDERCLAY, &c. Final concord at Cateshull on the morrow of the Ascension of Our Lord, 35 Hen. III, by which Osbert de Thorp and Margaret his wife demise to the abbot and church of St. Edmund 10s. of annual rent which she had as dowry from the abbot in Hyldercle, Rykinghale, and Watlesfeld. For this concession the abbot gave to the said Osbert and Margaret five marks. MS. Ch. Suffolk 50.

HOLBROOK. William Sprot of Holebac grants to Robert le Sponere of Holebac for 20s. one piece of land and one piece of herbage in Stepelcreting. (c. 1250-60.) [A small part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1316.

HOLTON. William de Stanham remits and quit-claims to the lady Petronilla de Nerford all right and claim in John Folke and Geoffrey le Roo of Holton his natives and all that belongs to them, whom he acquired from Robert del Heghe of Wyssete. Dated at Wyssete the Tuesday next before the feast of Pentecost, 5 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1198.

HOPETONE, CUNGESTON, and BARTON. Hugh, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund, grant to Vital and his heirs all the tenures and gifts which abbot O[rding] gave to him, viz. land in Hopeton and Cungeston, and in Bertune, also a toft in St. Edmund, subject to certain services. [With seal.] [c. 1160-70.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 5.

HOPTON. Stephen Boyes of Hopton demises to William Kempe, John Bee, and 2 others certain lands and tenements in Hopton which he, with others deceased, had from John Dunston. Dated at Hopton 8 Jan., 1 Edw. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 910.
Geoffrey Pampyng, burgess of Great Jermmuth, grants to William Bluwet of Hopton his messuage and five acres of land in Hopton. Dated at Hopton, 8 [March?] 2 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 911.
John Goche of Hopton grants to Thomas Crote and others certain land lying in Hopton. Dated 18 March 32 Hen. VI. [Nearly obliterated] MS. Ch. Suffolk 912.

Richard Hopere of Hopton and Thomas Denne grant to Edmund Wydewell burgess of Great Jernemuthe, Hugh at Fenne of London, gent., and Robert Gedge of Jernemuthe two acres of land in Hopton. Dated at Hopton, 24 January, 6 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 913.

John Sparow of Hopton and Henry Bosom, rector of Marlyngforthe, grant to William Davy, Thomas Denne and Clobert Bakon and others a certain messuage in Hopton. Dated at Hopton, 20 Jan., 13 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 914.

Edmund Bee of Hopton and Thomas Aleyn of Lowystoft releases to Henry Bosom, clerk, all their right in a messuage in Hopton. Dated at Hopton on the feast of St. Luke the Evangelist, 7 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 915.
John Jernyngham of Hilderston, Norfolk, releases to William Kempe and John Bee of Hopton all his right in a messuage, lands, &c. in Hopton. Dated 8 July, 4 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 916.

Thomas ... and ... Rollys demise and confirm to Thomas Couper of Hopton and others one piece of land ... Dated at Hopton on the feast of the Rebes [27 Jan.?] Hen. VII. [Mutilated] MS. Ch. Suffolk 918.

Thomas Nutman, burgess of Great Jernamuth grants to Thomas Feltwell, burgess of the same, Joan his wife, and Richard Collet a tenement with a croft in Hopton. Dated at Hopton, 16 June, 22 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 919.
Illegible charter, granting to Thomas Banyard, John Corby and others ... dated at Hopton, 14 August .. Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 917.
William Hall of Hopton grants to John Reddwycke, clerk, one messuage in Hopton. Dated 2 July, 31 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 920.

Indenture dated 18 December, 36 Hen. VIII, by which the dean and chapter of Norwich demise to John Jernegan their manor, church, and parsonage of Hopton, paying annually for the same £6, for a term of ten years. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 921.

William Denete (?) of Hopton, husbandman, and William Westmell of the same, grant to John Blacke (?) of Hopton the whole of a messuage called Hakons in Hopton. Dated at Hopton, 17 February, 37 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 922.

Ralph Parker and Margaret his wife one of the daugters of John Appleton grant to Herman and Cecilia his wife a tenement with a croft called Sheeres in Hopton. Dated at Hopton, 10 November, 8 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 923.

Indenture, dated 20 March, 21 Q. Elizabeth, by which John Jernegan of Somerleyton, esq., demises to William Roberdes of Swynston, Norfolk, gent., all his right and interest for the remaining term of years in the manor and rectory of Hopton, in consideration of a payment of £100. Contains a clause of redemption on payment of the said sum of £100, &c. [English] [On paper.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 924.
John ... and Alice his wife grant to George Farby (?) a tenement with an inclosure in Hopton. Dated at Hopton .. April 17 Q. Elizabeth. [Partly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 925.
John Carpenter of Hopton sells to sir John Wentworth, kt., all his right in a tenement, with a croft adjacent, lying in Hopton. Dated [day left blank] January, 7 Charles I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 926.

Indenture made 4 July, 17 Charles II, by which the dean and chapter of Norwich demise to William Lockier of the precincts of the cathedral, notary public, their rectory, churchyard, glebe, and tithes of Hopton, for 21 years, at an annual rent of 53s. 4d., and certain wheat and malt. MS. Ch. Suffolk 927.
HORHAM. Indenture made 18 Dec. ... [20?] Elizabeth between .... and Elizabeth Wentworth, wife of John Wentworth. [Illegible.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1319.

HORHAM and STONHAM. Sir John Hevenyngham, kt., William Darell of Kent and three others demise to John Jernegan of Somerleton, esq. and Agnes his wife all their manors, lands, and tenements in the villages of Horham and Stonham, and the advowsons of the churches of Horham, Stonham, and Bradwell. Dated at H[orham].... before feast of the Invention of the Cross, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1317.

John, son and heir of Edward Jernegan, esq., grants to Robert Drury, William Waldegrave, and others his manors of Little Horham, Stonham Jernegan, Newton, Gorton, and Lownde, with other lands, to the use of Bridget Jernegan, wife of John, for her life. Dated 10 May, 13 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1318.

HORNINGSHERTH. Thomas le Gaunter of St. Edmund grants to the hospital of St. Peter for the soul of himself and wife Beatrice the whole of a quarter of an acre of land in the fields of Horningeserd in frankalmoigne, paying annually 1 halfpenny to Robert Milun. Withn. master Hervey, Adam de Falekam, provost of St. Eadmund, Wodard son of Elyas alderman (c. 1210-20) MS. Ch. Suffolk 64.

HOWESLEY, &c. Indenture made 20 May, 38 Q. Elizabeth, witnesseth that William Cade of London, gent., has leased to John Hobart of the Middle Temple 40 acres of marsh in Howesley, and lands and tenements &c. elsewhere, as in letters patent, 37 of Q. Eliz., being part of the lands of the dissolved monastery of Butley in Suffolk, for 21 years. MS. Ch. Suffolk 194.

HUNSTON. Richard Appulton, son of Thomas Appulton, grants to William Appulton, son of the said Thomas, and others, his manor of Hunstanhall in ... Dated at Hunston ... 12 January, 1 Hen. VIII. [Partly illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1320.

William Appulton of London, gent., and others appoint John Coket of Ampton their attorney to receive in their name the manor of Hunston Hall in Hunston. Dated 18 January, I Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1321.

ICKLINGHAM. Indenture between king Henry VIII and George Rowse reciting an indenture dated 18 October, 30 Hen. VIII, from the abbot and convent of Bury St. Edmund, of a lease of the manor of Iklyngham, co. Suffolk, for 60 years, at an annual rent of £24, which said lease is surrendered, and another, by the present indenture, granted for 21 years at the same rent. Dated 12 December, 31 Hen. VIII. [With seal of Augmentation Office, broken.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1322.

INGHAM. Lease from Thomas, abbot of Bury St. Edmund, and the convent of the same, to John and William Hegge de Ingham of their manor of Ingham and all that belongs to it, except the advowson of the church, for 70 years, paying annually to the cellarer of the monastery £16. Dated 10 Sept., 1 Richard III. [Roughly altered as a draft for a lease from abbot John to John Playford and John Talbot for 20 years; dated 10 Sept. ... Henry VIII, year not filled in. Abbot John Reeve succeeded in 1514.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 133.

Indenture made 6 Nov., 28 Hen. VIII, by which John, abbot of Bury St. Edmund, demises to Thomas Andrew and Thomas Reve the manor of Ingham, called Ingham Hall, beloning to the office of cellarer, excepting the advowson, for 60 years, at an annual rent of £39. A bond from the lessees in 200 marks is attached. English MS. Ch. Suffolk 150.

IPSWICH. Robert de Buteler of Hemmingestune grants to the house of St. Peter and St. Paul of Gypewic, in frankalmoigne, 6d., of annual rent from an area formerly belonging to Avicia "Tingtraris" (the dyer) in the parish of St. Nicholas, Gypewic. (c. 1250-60.) Witn. Silvester Walkelin, Osbert de Foro, bailiffs of Gippewic MS. Ch. Suffolk 207.

John Clement, burgess of Gypewyc, grants to the canons of the church of St. Peter and St. Paul, Gypewic, 6d. of annual rent for sustaining a light before the altar of the Blessed Virgin. Dated the Thursday, after the commemoration of souls, 23 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 214.

Mutilated bull of Pope Innocent III, dated at Lyons, 15 day of [c. 1200] ... for collections in the dioceses of London, Rochester and Norwich for repair of the church of the Priory of Gippeswic. MS. Ch. Suffolk 206.

Cristiana, formerly wife of Hubert Mory of Branfeld, grants to Costentine Skeith of Ipswich, for half a mark all her right in a piece of meadow, which she has in the name of dowry of Hubert her husband. (c. 1280-90.) [Seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1324.

An order of Thomas, earl of Dorset, admiral of England, Guienne, and Ireland, to Saundre Scot, master of the Mary of Epesvviche, to receive on board and carry into England Guy Corbet and Robert White, esqs., with 10 of their attendants. Dated at Burdeux, 5 January, 14 Hen. IV. [French] [On paper.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1326.

Indenture made at Gyppewic ..., Henry V, between John Pyke, formerly prior of the Holy Trinity, Gyppewyc', and John Odin and Roger Com... of the other part, assigning his manor of Menyotys for a term of years. [Partly effaced.] [John Pyke, elected priory 5 Hen. V] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1325.

Indenture made 16 July, 4 Q. Elizabeth, reciting the bequest of Henry Tooley, and the surrender to the mayor and corporation of
Ipswich, of the lands, <c. given for the foundation of an hospital at Ipswich. [3.5 sheets; mutilated.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1327.
KESSINGLAND. Will of John Gudde of Kessynlond, 7 Nov. 1503. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1333.

Bond in £200 given by Humphrey Seckford of Ipswich, gent., to William Cornwallis, esq., dated 14 Oct., 34 Eliz. [1592] for payment of £100
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1328.

IXNING. Indenture made between Laurence Abbot, citizen and mercer of London, on the one part, and Walter Cotton, citizen and mercer of London, and Richard Sturgeon of the other part, reciting a bond of the 16th November, 15 Hen. VI, in £2000. [Much rubbed and partly illegible.] Dated 20 November, 15 Henry VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1329.

KENTON. Francis Colby of Kenton, esq., remits and quit-claims to Nicholas Garneys of Little Reddesham, and Charles Garneys his son, all his right to the whole of a mansion called Kenton Hall in the parish of Kenton. Dated 27 March, 44 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1330.

Francis Colby of Kenton, co. Suffolk, remits and quitclaims to Thomas Cleere of Stokesby and others, all his right in a capital messuage called Kenton Hall in Kenton. Dated 23 Dec., 45 Eliz. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1331.

KNODISHALL, Robert, son of William, son of Hervi de Rendham, and Christiana his wife, grant to Thomas the cook, of Badingham, for 8s. one piece of land called 'le Heygh' in the village of Cnodeshale. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1178.

Theobald de Leestun, son of William de Leestun, grants to Julian de Braham and Katherine his wife, for 20 marks and an annual payment of two shillings certain lands in the villages of Cnodeshale and Leestun, which William Walmer held of the grantor's father. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1179
Roger Gerard of Leystone grants to William Russe, for 2½ marks, one acre of land in the village of Cnodeshale called Notekynnesacre. (c. 1300-10.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1180.
Richard de Braham grants to Roger de Braham certain land in the village of Cnodeshale, rendering annually one clove. Dated at Cnodeshale on Palm Sunday, 18 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1181.
Richard, son of the late Julian de Braham of Cnodeshale, grants to Robert Reynal and Aldetha his wife of Leystone, one piece of land in Cnodeshale. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1182.

William, the abbot, and the convent of Leystone grant to Thomas ... and [Richolda?] his wife, four pieces of land lying in the village of Knoteshale. (c. 1320-30?) [Mutilated and partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 226.
Christiana, relict of Robert de Rindham, quit-claims to Thomas Cook of Cnodeshale all her right in two pieces of land in Cnodeshale. (c. 1290-1300) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1183.

Aldetha, formerly wife of Robert Reynald of Cnodeshale, grants to William, son of John de Leystone, one piece of land called 'Hennesrode' in Cnodeshale. Dated at Cnodeshale the Wednesday next before the feast of St. Barnabas, 29 Ed. I. (See endorsment.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1184.

Robert, son of Adam Gerard of Leystone, grants to John Peres and Elena his wife of Leystone for the sum of ten shillings one piece of land in Cnodeshale called le Potbrede. Dated at Cnodeshale the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Michael, 31 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1185.

Adam Gerard and Margery his wife of Leystone grant to Robert their son for the sum of twelve shillings the half of one piece of land in the village of Cnodeshale. Dated at Cnodeshale the Sunday next after the feast of St. Andrew, 31 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1186.

Peter Cosyn of Wysete grants to Peter, son of Adam of the Church ("de ecclesia"), the younger ('junior'), one piece of land in the village of Cnodeshale. Dated at Cnodeshale the Thursday next after the feast of St. Walentine, 10 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1187.

Roger Cruke of Knodishale grants to John de Braham and John his son one piece of land lying in the village of Knodishale. Dated at Knodishale the Sunday on the feast of St. Gregory, 11 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1188.

Warin Bygot of Knodeshale grants to Adam de Ecclesia of Knodeshale, William his son, and Alice wife of the said William, one piece of land in the village of Knodeshale. Dated at Knodeshale on St. Luke's day, 1 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1189.
Semman de Resschemere of Freston grants to Matilda his daughter one piece of land in Knodessale. Dated at Freston the Sunday next after the feast of St. Andrew, 14 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1190.

John Jordan of Leyston grants to sir Richard Lealford, clerk, all his lands, &c. in Knodeshale, which he had by demise of Rob. Barfote John Jok and Richard Horn, and they had by the gift of John Skynner. Dated at Leyston, 14 June, 4 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1191.

LAVENHAM. Writ of King Edward III to the bailiff of St. Edmund, reciting a grant to Robert de Veer, earl of Oxford, releasing his tenants &c. of his manor of Lavenham from paying toll throughout the kingdom, and commanding the bailiff (as often before) not to molest or distrain for toll when the said tenants shall come to St. Edmund's. Tested at Windsor, 22 Feb., 4 of his reign. Noted at the foot, "Nota dorsum cedule contra istud breve plane", and on the back is a recital of priviledges granted to the abbey of St. Edmund by Hen. I, to which this writ is said to be contrary. MS. Ch. Suffolk 352.

LEISTON. Theobald, son of William de Leystune, grants to William his brother for the sum of 10s. one acre of land in Leystune, at an annual rent of 2d. (c. 1260-70.) Thomas "Corn de bof" is a witness; the name is afterwards written "Condebof."
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1199.

Confirmation by John [Peckham], archbishop of Canterbury, of the appropriation of the churches of St. Margaret at Lestone with the chapel of St Nicholas at Syswell, St. Andrew of Aldringham, St. Mary at Middleton, and St. Bothulph at Colpho, to the abbot and convent of Leystone. Dated at Buttelee, 4 Kl. Mar., 1280. MS. Ch. Suffolk 220.

John de Braham, and Thomas, son of William Austyn of Donewic, remit and quit-claim to William, son of John de Leystone, all right in lands and tenements in Leystone, Knodeshale, and Buxllyslowe, which they had by the gift of the said William. Dated at Leystone the Tuesday next after the feast of St. John ante port. Lat., 8 Edw. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1200

Grant from William the abbot of convent of Leystone to J... and Richolde his wife for 5 marks and 5 .... of 4 pieces of land which were Edmund the chaplain's in the vill of ...disbroke. [Mutilated and almost entriely effaced.] (c. 1320-1330.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 226.
Adam Hollok of Westylton quit-claims to .... Letewene (?) of Leyston and Roger Pottok all right of action, <c. Dated at Leyston the Friday next after ...., 5 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1201.

Alice de Thorpp, relict of John de Thorpp of Leyston, grants to William Bokele of Leyston and Robert Dersham of Brampton all his lands which he holds in fee simple in the soke of Leiston ('in soka de Leyston '). Dated at Leyston the Friday on the feast of St. Margaret, virgin and martyr, 21 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1202.

Clement, abbot and the convent of Leystone, &c., appoint Richard Robertson and William Styward as their atttorneys to deliver seisin to John Jenney, sen., and William Jenney his son, of certain messuages and tenements in Leystone, Knodeshale, &c. Dated 20 April, 29 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 225.

LOUND. Alice de Lund, daughter of Ralph de Pesehale, grants to Robert, son of Edstan de Caldecotes (Caldecot near Fritton, Suffolk?), ten acres and half a rood of land in Lund some near the way as you go from Lund to Rotepet towards the east, some in Kirkefurlong, some near the way going from the monastery of Lund in boyton to the north, etc.; paying annually 12d., and giving ... (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 928.
Illegible quit-claim, temp. Ed. I. [Almost entirely obliterated; numbered in some old list 164.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 929.
SUFFOLK. Geoffrey, son of sir John de Askeby, grants to Margery and Emma, daughters of the said Geoffrey, certain land in the fields of Lund. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 930.

Henry, son of Warin de Lond, grants to John de Droxton of Somerleton three acres of land in the village of Lond. Dated at Lond the Friday on the feast os St. [Potentiana?] the virgin, 3 Ed. [III]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 931.

John, son of Robert de Lund, grants to Joan and Christiana, daughters of Margery Habreham of Kirk..te, two parts of one messuage with one house built upon it in Lund. Also he grants to Margaret, daughter of the said Margery, the third part of the said messuage with a smaller house. Dated at Lund, 14 Ed. II (no day). MS. Ch. Suffolk 932.

Richard, son of Alam Elflot of Lund, grants to William Poer de Flixton, son of Walter de Flixton, two acres and one rood of arable land in Lund. Dated at Lund the Thursday next before the feast of St. Peter, 6 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 933.

Henry, son of Edmund Poyer of Lound, confirms to Walter de Manthorp of Somerleton two pieces of land in Lund. Dated at Lound the Tuesday next before the feast of St. Peter ad vinc., 15 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 934.

John, son of Adam Westwynd of Kessinglond, grants to Isabel Bonde of Askeby one piece of land, containing 2 acres and one rood and a half, lying in the village of Lund. Dated the Sunday next after the feast of St. Thomas, apostle, 10 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 935.
Illegible grant, from John and Elizabeth ... to Thomas ... dated at Lound the Sunday on the morrow of St. Faith, virgin, 21 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 937.

Adam Poer of Riston remits to Henry de Gunton and Margaret his wife all right &c. in one messuage and in all lands and tenements which the said Henry and Margaret hold in Lound and Askeby. Dated at Lound the Sunday next after the feast of St. Mary Magdalene, 31 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 936.
John de Merhse of Herleyngflet grants to William Hacun of Somerleton one piece of land in Lound. Dated at Lound the Sunday next after the feast of St. Edmund, 35 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 938.
