Henry de Gonton and Margaret his wife grant to Aveline, wife of Richard Power of Lound, one messuage and 15 acres of land in Lound and Askeby for the term of her life. Dated at Lound the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Faith, virgin, 43 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 939.
Fragment of a charter, temp. Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 940.

George de Felbrigge, John de Wolterton, clerk, John de Theluetham and Walter Wyot, clerck and others grant to John de Herlyngges all right which they have in one messuage and certain rents and tenements in the villages of Lound, Hopton, &c., together with the advowson of the church of Lound. Dated at Estherlyngges the Monday next after the feast of the Translation of St. Thomas the martyr, 49 Ed. III. [With 4 seals, armorial.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 941.

Final concord, made at Westminster, on the morrow of St. Martin, 50 Ed. III, between Thomas, son of Henry de Gonton, and Henry Grym, querents, and Henry de Gonton of Lounde and Margaret his wife, deforciants, by which the said Henry and Margaret acknowledge the right of the said Thomas and Henry to messuage 24 acres of land and half an acre of turbary in Lounde for which the latter pay 100 marks. MS. Ch. Suffolk 942.
Duplicate of Ch. Suffolk 942. MS. Ch. Suffolk 943.
Edmund .... of Lound grants to Henry Fairman of Blounston one piece of land in Lound. [Partly illegible.] Dated at Lound, Palm Sunday, 3 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 944.
Thomas Wenon of Somerleton grants to Thomas de Gunton of Lound one piece of land in Lound. Dated the Thursday next before the feast of SS. Simon and Jude, 5 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 945.
Walter Darreys of Lound confirms to William Darreys his son one piece of land in Lound. Dated at Lound on the feast of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist, 18 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 946.
John Gounton of Lound grants to John Ayldre of Heryngflet Roger Phymour and Stephen Key all his tenements &c. in Lound, Hopton, and Askeby. Dated at Lound, 20 Nov., 1 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 947.

Master John Judde, clerk, and 3 others remit and quit-claim to Roger Prymour of Lound, Stephen Keye and John Dunstone all their right in those lands, tenements, &c. which they had by the feoffment of William Ely, formerly rector of Becclys, in the villages of Lound and Askeby. Dated at Becclys on the feast of Saints Processus and Martimen 13 Hen. IV. [With 4 seals, one broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 948.

Henry Webstere of Blumston grants to Robert Andrew of Lound four acres of land in Lound and Blumston. Dated at Lound the Sunday next after the feast of St. Matthias (? Mat...), 3 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 949.

Thomas Curteys of Blundeston and John Curteys of Lound grant to Henry .... of Lound two pieces of land in Lound. Dated at Lound the Thursday next after the feast of St. Matthias the apostle, 4 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 950.

John de Dunston of Hopton grants to Robert Andrew of Lound all those lands &c. which he had by the gift and feoffment of Thomas Fyncham and others in Lound. Dated at Lound the Saturday on the feast of the conception of the B.V.M., 8 Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 951.
Thomas Katys of Lound grants to Robert Andrew of Herlyngflet two pieces of land lying in the parish of Lound. Dated at Lound on the feast of Pentecost, 10 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 952.
Stephen Key of Lound grants to Roger Prymour and others various lauds and tenements lying in Lound. Dated at Lound, 23 Nov., 5 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 953.

John Mayne of Lound grants to Edmund Cadeler of Lound one piece of land of the manor of Lound, in fulfilment of the last will of ... Dated at Lound, 4 Jan., 1 Henry VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 954.

John Dunston of Hopton and Stephen Keye of Lound remit and quit-claim to Roger Prymour of Lound all their right in all the messuages, lands, tenements, &c. formerly Thomas Rose's in the village of Lound, which William Dareys lately deceased and the above named three acquired from the attorneys of William Ely, clerck of Becclys. Dated at Lound on the feast of St. Valentine, martyr, 1 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 955.

Stephen Keye remits and quit-claims to Roger Primour of Lound all right in messuages and land in Lound, which he together with John Bertelot, clerck, and William Leman, both deceased held. Dated at Lound on the feast of St. Valentine, martyr, 1 Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 956.
Andrew Cok of Olton and Thomas ... executors of the will of ... quit-claim to Robert .... and others all right in .... in Lound. Dated 2 April, 15 Henry VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 957.

John Fytte and Margaret his wife of Lound (one of the coheirs of Thomas Manthorpe of Somerleton) remit and quit-claim to John Baker of Somerleton all right in lands and tenements in .... [Partly effaced.] Dated 20 December, 5 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 958.

Stephen Key of Lound appoints Robert his son his attorney to deliver to Thomas Gunton, son of the late John Gunton and 8 others seisin of all his lands in Lound, Hopton, and Askeby, which he, with John Ayldre and Roger Prysnour, deceased, had from the said John Gunton. Dated at Lound, 31 March, 11 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 959.

Stephen Keye of Lound grants to Thomas Gunton, son of John Gunton of Lound, and others (John Donewold, etc.) all those lands &c. in Lound, Hopton, and Askeby which he together with John Ayldre and Roger Prymour both deceased had by the gift of the said John Gunton. Dated at Lound, 30 March, 11 Hen. VI. [See Ch. Suffolk 947.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 960.

John Donewold of Lowystoft and others remit and quit-claim to Thomas Gunton of Lound all their right in lands and tenements in Lound, Hopton, and Askeby. Dated at Lound, 2 June, 11 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 961.

John Grernegon remits and quit-claims to Edmund Atte Welle, clerk, Roger Owdyn of Somerleton, and Roger ... the whole of his claim to a messuage and croft in Somerleton. Dated .... August, 11 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 962.

Alice, widow of Richard Crystemesse of Somerleton, remits and quit-claims to Robert, son of late Roger Prymour of Lound, John Torald of Askeby, and Thomas Gunton of Lound, her right in 2 pieces of land in Lound which they had by the gift of her late husband. Dated at Lound the Saturday next after the feast of St. Cuthbert, 11 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 963.

John Gernegon, esq., Edmund atte Welke, Roger Owdyn, Stephen Kay and Robert Prymour grant to Richard Crystemesse of Somerleton two pieces of land in Lound. Dated at Lound the Friday next after the feast of St. Edmund, king and martyr, 11 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 964.
Ralph Darreys grants to Thomas Rose a curtilage with a certain cottage in .... [Partly effaced.] Dated at the Monday on the feast of St. ... MS. Ch. Suffolk 965.

Henry Crystemesse of Somerleton, William Knyght and John Stalhem demise to John Yve, clerk, and Thomas Kerestere of Somerleton, one piece of land in Lound. Dated at Lound, 28 Nov., 15 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 966.
Illegible grant, dated at Lound, 27 February, 17 Henry VI. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 967.
Robert Sent of Redenhale, Thomas Kemstere and others grant to Robert Key of Lound and others certain lands and tenements in Lound. Dated at Lound, .. April, 18 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 968.
Illegible grant, [dated 19 Henry VI?]. [Totally effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 969.

John Pond of Lound grants to Thomas Gunton the reversion of a messuage and two pieces of land lying in the village of Lound, which he has by the gift of his wife Juliana Pond and Stephen Kemstere. Dated ... November, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 970.

Robert Key of Lound and Stephen Kempstere of Freton demise to Edmund Atte Well, clerk, and three others all those lands &c. lately Stephen Key's in Lound. Dated at Lound, 30 April, 25 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 971.

Indenture witnessing that Thomas Owden of Somerleton demises
to John Bayly of Gorleston and others, certain lands, rents, and appurtenances in Lound, Asskeby, Somerleton, and Blundeston, for a certain term of years. Dated 10 December, 12 Edward IV. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 972.

John Fulborn of Lound and Thomas Nogge grant to Richard Schrympling of Little Jernemouth and others, all their messuages &c. in the village of Lound. Dated at Lound, 3 Nov., ... Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 973.
John Getoure of Leystofte and Thomas Crote of Lound grant to John Baly of Gorleston two pieces of land in Lound. Dated at Lound, 10 Dec., 12 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 974.
Illegible charter, dated 4? Hen. VII. [Entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 975.
William Wrenteham and another grant certain lands in Lound to Henry Jechys, Thomas Cartere (?) and Edward Schrympling. Dated at Lound ... March ... Hen. VIII. [Partly illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 976.
William Prymour of Lound grants to John and Thomas Byrde of Lound a certain messuage and croft called Baldwynes. Dated at Lound, 28 Oct. 20 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 977.
William Smyth grants to Thomas Byrde and Katherine his wife and three others one cottage in Lounde. Dated at Lound, 28 February, 3 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 978.

John Jernegan, esq., patron of the church of Lounde, and Thomas Hoggeson, rector of Lounde, grant (at the special request of the said Thomas) to John Rixton and Edward Schrymplyng the site of the rectory of Lound. Dated at Lound, 10 March, 21 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 979.

Alice Neve, widow, late wife of John Prymour, and John and William Mortoft grant to John Sannowe of Bedyngham and two others all those messuages, lands, &c. in Lound, Blundeston, and Askeby, as by a charter dated 20 Jan., 14 Hen. VII, appears; to be conveyed to the said Alice on her marriage to William Colandour (?). Dated at Lound, 20 May, 12 Hen. VIH. MS. Ch. Suffolk 980.

Thomas Hodyson, clerk, rector of Lound, at the instance of certain inhabitants of Lound grants to John Warde a messuage and a croft and six pieces of land in Lound and three pieces in the fields of Askeby. Dated 28 April, 38 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 981.
Thomas Spycer of Lowystoft grants to Thomas Jecks, husbandman, all his lands and tenements in Lound and Hopton. Dated at Lound, 16 January 3 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 982.
Robert Bugge sells to sir John Jernegan, knight, a tenement called Guntons, with all meadows, lands, pastures, &c. in Lound, Askeby, and Blondston. Dated 10 ... 37 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 983.

Thomas Jeckys of Lownde, son and heir and executor of the will of Henry Jeckys of Kyrsted, sells to George Jernegan two pieces of land lying in Lownde. Dated at Lownde, 7 March, 1 Ed. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 984.

Joan Bukmonger of Lownde, widow, grants to George Jernegan, esq., one piece of land containing by estimation half an acre in Lownde. Dated 2 Ed. VI. [Mutilated and partially illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 985.

William Starys sells to Thomas Jecks of Lound one piece of land containing by estimation 4 acres, and another piece lying in Lound called le Hedstrych. Dated at Lound, 31 Jan., 3 Ed. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 986.
George Jernegan of Lound grants to Thomas Hogeson, clerk, all his lands &c. in Lound. Dated 30 Dec. 1? Ed. VI. [Partially illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 987.

An indenture by which John Jernegan and Katherine his wife of Somerleyton demise to James Towne of Lownde a tenement called Guntons, containing 15 acres, for 77 years, at an annual rent of 56s. 2d. Dated 20 October, 16 Q. Elizabeth. [English.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 988.

Indenture of agreement made 8 April, 23 Elizabeth, made between Roger Castell, esq., to sir Will. Brook, lord Cobham, John Brooke alias Cobham, his brother, and Edmund Bedingfield, esq. by which R. Castell undertakes to infeoff the said John Brooke alias Cobham and others, of and in the manor of Stallams in Lownd, and of and in the advowson of the parish church of Lownd, with all lands and tenements in Lownd, and in Blundeston, Heringflete, and Hopton, which were of the inheritance of one John Jernegan of Somerleyton, to hold the same to the use of Katherine, wife of the said John Jernegan, for her life, and at her decease for the use of the daughters of the said John. [Slightly mutilated.] [English] [On paper.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 989.

Katherine Jernegan, widow, late wife of John Jernegau, sells to John Wentworth the whole of the manor of Stalhams in Lownde, with the advowson of the church of Lownde, also all lands belonging to the said manor situated within the parishes of Blundeston, Heryngfleete, and Hopton. Dated and signed, 22 May, 41 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 990.

Katherine Jernegan, widow of John Jernegan of Somerleton, in consideration of a certain sum of money in hand paid, confirms to John Wentworth, son and heir apparent of John Wentworth, esq., the whole of her messuage, lauds, &c. in Lounde, late in the occupation of James Towne. Dated (and signed) 22 May, 41 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 991.

John Wentworth of Somerleton discharges Katherine Jernegan, widow of John Jernegan of Somerleton, from all suits during her life upon a bond given for the performance of certain covenants by her third daughter Katherine wife of Wymond Carey, esq. respecting the manor called Stalhams in Lound. Dated 2 Nov., 41 Q. Eliz. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 992.
LOWESTOFT. John Lacy of Lowystoft grants to John Mark of the same place two pieces of his brushwood, with one piece of turbary. Dated MS. Ch. Suffolk 993.

Alice, formerly wife of Thomas Moryng of Lowystoft, and William Scarlet grant to Adam Moryng one piece of land, with a certain piece of brushwood. Dated at Lowystoft the Sunday next after the feast of Easter, 7 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 994.

Simon Reynals, John Wrighte, senior, and Richard Wyard of
Lowystoft, grant to William Parkere of the same place one piece of land called 'Grymeslond.' Dated at Lowystoft, 20 October, 12 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 995.
John Getour and Robert Getour of Lowestoft grant to Milo Kerech, clerk, of Blundston, one piece of land in Lowestoft. Dated at Lowestoft, 20 Jan., 22 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 996.
Andrew Teo of Sybbeton (?) grants to Thomas Aleyn of Lowystoft and others a certain piece of land in Lowystoft. Dated at Lowystoft, 4 June, 38 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 997.

Richard Smith, alias Glover, and Henry Feete, both of Lowystoft demise to Alexander Steyngate, Will. Parker, John Jetour and John Conbylday a messuage or parcel of land in Lowystoft. Dated at Lowystoft, 5 July, 10 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 998.

Geoffrey Fordele of Wrox .... remits and quit-claims to John M .... of Lowestoft all right in three pieces of land in Lowestoft, in the field called Southfield. Dated on the vigil of St. James, apostle, 4 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 999.

Indenture dated 14 Nov., 12 Hen. VII, by which John Cowper, carter, of Lowestoft, sells to William Cowper his son, for a payment of £22, "hys place as it [is] sette in the Southende". [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1000.
John Andrewys of Lowestoft grants to Milo Kerech of Blondston, clerk, three roods of land in Lowestoft. Dated at Lowestoft, 20 Jan., 22 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1001.

Alice Halys(?) executrix ... remits to William Hadlays Robert Grosse, John Jatour, sen., and John Andrews all her right in one acre of land in Lowestoft. Dated at Lowestoft 5 April .... Hen. VII. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1002.

John Boffe of Lowystoft, gent., John Murdok, gent., and three others grant to Robert Hoddys and three others one piece of land containing 2 acres, in the field called Northfeld, also 2 acres of brushwood in Lowystoft. Dated at Lowystoft, 30 June, 23 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1003.

William Cook of Little Lynsted and others demise and confirm to William Marche and Geoffrey Cook certain lands, rents, and tenements in Lowystoft and Oulton. Dated at Lowystoft, 10 October, 3 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1004.

Bond given by Matthew Burward, dated 3 ... 30 Elizabeth, for conveyance of property in Lowestoft and Gunton to Anthony Hutton(?) and his wife Audrey. [English] [Partly illegible] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1005.
Extract from the manor court roll of Lowystoft. Temp. Jac. I. [Illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1006.

Humfrey Yermonth, gent., of Blondyston, co. Suffolk, leases to John Everarde of Lowestoft, mariner, a messuage called Wyatts &c. in Lowestoft, for 10 years, at an annual rent of 2os. Dated 26 Sept., 27 Hen. VIII. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1007.

Richard Mighell of Great Jernemuth one of the sons of James Mighall, deceased, sells to John Cooke of Gunton for £9 one acre of land in Lowestoft, in the field called Northfield. Dated at Lowestoft, 1 May, 1 James, 1603. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1008.

Final concord, dated on the octave of St. Michael, 21 James I, between John Utber, gent., plaintiff, and Philip Hayward, gent., and Gislaham Wolhowse, gent., and Elizabeth his wife, defendants, concerning 80 acres of land and two acres of pasture in Lowstoft, for which the plaintiff gives them £100. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1009.

Ellen Peereson of Great Yarmuth, co. Norfolk, spinner, sells to Thomas Harman of Mutford, gent., and Hubert Cruxe the whole of a piece of land containing three roods in the village of Leystoft. Dated at Leystoft, 14 April, 1624. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1010.
MANTHORP. Geoffrey, son of Roger Burkard of Manethorpe, grants for 12d. to John, son of Robert de Manethorpe, one acre of land in Manetorpe. (c. 1250-60.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1447.
MELDINGE. Gilbert Page of Meldinge grants to Thomas ...dringe land in Meldinge. Dated at Meldinge the Thursday next after the feast of St. Martin, bp., 15 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 353.

MELFORD. At a court held at Melford the Monday next after the feast of H. Trinity, 2 Hen. VIII, the abbot of Bury St. Edmund admitted Roger Marten and Richard his son to one meadow at a rent of 7s. 1d. MS. Ch. Suffolk 142.

MELLS. William Godinhale of Vycham, chaplain, grants to William, son of Thomas Gordan, 12d. of annual rent which the said Thomas was accustomed to pay to the said William for one piece of land lying between certain boundaries. Dated at Melles on the day of the Nativity of St. John Baptist, 26 Ed. I. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1203.

MENDLESHAM. William, priour of Mendlesham, grants to Robert Dunken of Wedringset one piece of land lying in Mendlesham. Dated at Mendlesham the Sunday next after the feast of St. Peter ad vinc., 27 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 227.

MENDHAM. Indenture made at Mendham abbey (sic), 9 September, 2 Henry VIII, between Thomas Bullok, the prior of the house of our lady of Mendham and the convent, of the one part, and Robert Flouere, "syngilman" of the other part, by which the prior and convent demise a close called Denson's to the said Robert. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 228.

Writ addressed by king Hen. VIII to the sheriff of Suffolk, to the effect that sir Humphrey Wyngfeld, kt., and others, have recovered in the king's court at Westminster the manors of Mendham and Kyngeshall, with other rents and lands elsewhere, against Thomas, the prior of Mendham. Dated at Westminster, 18 November, 26 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 229.

Indenture made 7 December, 3 Charles II, that Thomas Freston of Mendham, in consideration of the receipt of £7. 3s. 3d., and an after-payment of £500, releases and confirms to Richard Freston of Mendham, esq., the tithes of the parishes of Mendham, Metfield, and Nedham appertayning to the late dissolved monastery of Mendham. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1347.

MANTHORP. Grant from Roger, son of Roger Burkard of Manethorp to John son of ... Manethorpe, for nine shillings, of one rood and a half of his land in Manethorpe, paying (c. 1250-60) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1334.

Grant from Roger Burgard of Manethorpe to John, son of Robert de Manethorpe, for half a mark, of a piece of his land in Manethorpe containing six score and ten "pedum hominum" in length and six feet in breath, paying annually one halfpenny. (c. 1260) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1335.

Quit-claim from Katherine, formerly wife of William de Colekyrke to William, son of Robert de Manethorpe of the moiety of the acre and a half in Manethorpe, which she claimed by de recto in name of dowry. (c. 1260-70) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1336.
Grant from ... to Alice her sister of three roods of land in Manthorpe. (c. 1250-60(?)) [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1337.
MELDING. Grant from Peter de Denardistone to James de Mottislo of two crofts in Meldinge, one called Mecreseynes and the other Blakeleye Pychtel. [With seal.] (c. 1260-70) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1339.

MELTON. Grant from William Reve of Wadeh... (?) and William Bisse (? Lisse) of Sumerletune to William Cook of Melton, of ... Dated at Melton 12 March (?), 16 Hen. VI. [In large part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1340.

Grant from Sarra formerly wife of Thomas Algerkyrke to John Olwy, parson of the church of Salle (Norf.) and Gilbert Warfat of Wadebrigge, of two messuages in Meltone. Dated at Meltone Monday after feast of St. Bartholomew, 7 Rich. II. [Partly defaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1341.

MENDHAM. Indenture between Edmund Jetterre of Lowestoft, gent., and John Flower of Mendham, yeoman, by which the former, for the sum of six (?) pounds, sells to the latter lands in Mendham and other places. Dated last day of Febr., 3 Eliz. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1343.

Fine by which Richard Fore and Margaret his wife convey to John Whitinton for the sum of £40 a garden and orchard in Mendham. Westm[inster] 3 Eliz. [English] [In duplicate.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1344. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1345.

Conveyance by Robert Berney of Langley, Norfolk, gent. to John Duke of Workingham, Suff., esq., Thomas Freston of Mendham, gent., and Robert Harper of Mendham, yeoman, of his manors etc. of Meastham and other towns adjoining in Norfolk and Suffolk, in trust for himself and his wife Mary. 22 Oct., 20 James [I] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1346. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1347.

Indenture between John Hearinge son and heir of John Hearinge of Mendham, deceased, and Thomas Freston of the same, esq., conveying to the latter certain messuages, etc. to hold until William Hearinge come to the age of 21, on consition of his undertaking the sole executorship of the will of the said John Hearinge, deceased. Dated 30 Sept. 6 Charles [I], 1630. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1348.

Extract from the roll of the fifth court of Sicily Baxter, widow, of the admission of Thomas Freston to four pieces of land and one pictall in Mendham which John Hering had had. Thursday after feast of St. Faith, 12 Charles [I], 1636. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1349.

Conveyance by Robert Greene of Mendham, yeoman, to John Hobart of Weybred, Thomas Foreston and William Heringe of Mendham, and Thomas Greene of the parish of St. James South Elmham, of the messuage called Brevetts or Bruetts late of Nicholas Greene, deceased, father of the said Robert, for the term of 60 years, in tust for payment of rents, repairs, and debts now owing, and for the use of the said Robert and Mary his wife. 11 Dec. 14 Charles [I]. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1350.

MENDLESHAM. Lease from Edward and John Crane, gents., to Margery Blomfyld of Little Stonham, and Robert her son of twelve acres of land in Mendylsham, for twenty years, at a yearly rent of 13/4d. 20 May, 27 Hen. VIII. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1351.

Grant from Robert Crane, son of John Crane late of Little Stoneham, esq., deceased, to Thomas Parker, rector of the church of Little Stoneham, Robert Blomffeld, of the same, yeoman, and Thomas Blomffeld of a pasture in Mendelysham called Lytylhane. 27 Sept. 10 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1352.

METTFIELD. Deed of sale by Robert Scarlett of Starston, Norf., yeoman, to Thomas Freston, of Mendham, esq., of the messuage in Mettfield called Bees or Dukes, and the pightell or piece of land in Mendham called Spinkes pightell, etc. 7 April 3 Charles [I]. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1353.

MICKFIELD. Richard Wodeward grants to Gilbert Ffeldgate of Stonham Aspale and three others one inclosure, with the site of a tenement called 'Olyves,' in Mekefield. Dated at Mekefield the Thursday next after the feast of St. Faith, virgin, 27 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 639.

Indenture between Robert Harpeley, esq., and John Northhawe of Wynston, by which the said Robert grants to the said John lands called Bakonys &c. in the villages of Mekylfeld, Debenham and Stonham Aspal, for twenty years paying yearly for four years 8 marks, and for 16 years 8 marks 6s. and 8d. Dated the Friday on the feast of St. Bartholomew, 37 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 640.

Indenture made 26 Sept., 26 Hen. VIII, by which Edward and John Crane demise to Jone Benight of Mickfield, widow and her eldest son William, certain parcels of land in Mickfield, for 20 years, paying annually for the same 33s. 4d. [Mutilated.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 641.

MIDELTON. John Laur... grants to Roger, son of John of the bridge "de le Pont" of Middilton and to Basilia daughter ... Dated Sunday after ... 18 Ed. II. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1204.

MILDENHALE, &c. Chirograph by which Samson, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund grant to Ralph de Colum their servant certain lands and rents in Mildenhale. (1182-1211.) [Almost entirely effaced.] [Colum (see endorsment of Ch. Suffolk 26 where he is also a witness)] MS. Ch. Suffolk 19.

John de Bradmer grants to William his nephew, son of Adam Spyle and Beth , sister and to Edmund de Elwedon, chaplain, one messuage and certain lands in Mildenhale, and rents in Barton and Herningewelle, to provide two chaplains to celebrate divine services for his soul and all the faithful, &c. in Mildenhale, viz. the said William and Edmund, and after their deaths succession. (c. 1260-70.) [One of the trustees, Robert, prior of St. Eadmund, was prior from c. 1257 to 1280.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 27.

Samson, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund confirm to Ralph, son of Lambert, certain land in fee in the village of Mildenhale, which Ulfkoteke the priest held; by the service of 10s. annually. (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 24.

Samson, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund confirm to Nicholas de Geddinges 42 acres of arable land with one messuage and 4½ acres and half a rood of meadow in the village of Mildenhale, which he held from year to year in the time of Richard de Clere, but now may hold in heirship at an annual rent of 12s. (c. 1190-1200.) [Robert, prior, witness, d. in 1210] MS. Ch. Suffolk 25.

Samson, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund grant to Benedict de Mildenhale a messuage and land in the said village of Mildenhale for an annual rent of 6s. (c. 1208-1210.) [Partially illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 20.
Endorsement. Gilbert de Derham grants to the church of St. Edmund one croft in Mildenhal. Dated Ed. [I]. [Illegible, almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 88.

Gilbert de Derham grants to William de Newenham, almoner of the church of St. Edmund, for 5 marks, one croft called Bertonecroft in Mildenhale, to hold for 5 years from Mich. 8 Ed. I. [See Ch. Suffolk 88.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 92.

Simon Greswelle of Bury St. Edmund grants to William Galyon of Mildenhale and others one messuage in Mildenhale at 'le West rowe' called 'Brounstere' with a croft and meadow. Dated at Mildenhale the Saturday next after the feast of St. Leonard, abbot, 4 Hen. V. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1448.

Thomas Chylderston and Robert, son of the late William Sygo of Mildenhale, grant to William Childerston of Mildenhale and 4 others five acres of land lying in the fields of Mildenhale. Dated at Mildenhale, 14 June, 14 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1359.

John Morley of Mildenhale grants to William Childreston of Mildenhale one meadow called 'Brownysyerd.' Dated at Mildenhale, 1 October, 3? Hen. VII. [Mutilated and partly effaced.] (see Ch. Suffolk 1360) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1355.

William Pope(?) of Mildenhale, esq., John Grene, chaplain, and others, enfeoff John Childreston of Mildenhale, John Benne of the University of Cambridge, clerk, John Coole, and others, in a messuage &c. in Mildenhale. Dated at Mildenhale, 26 March, 21 Ed. IV. [Slightly mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1357.

Robert Lute, parson of the church of Delton Terryng(?) next Mildenhale, Robert Jervys, and others, demise to William Soper a meadow for 14 years. Dated Ed. IV. [In great part effaced.] [English]
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1358.

Robert Childreston of Mildenhale, son and heir of John Childreston, deceased, grants to Agnes Fletcher of Bury St. Edmund, Thomas Childreston, and others, a meadow with buildings erected thereon and three roods of land in Mildenhale, at Westrowe adjoining the meadow of the chantry of Edmund [Mildenhale]. Dated at Mildenhale, 15 June, 3 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1360.

Robert Chylderston of Westrow, in Mildenhale, son and heir of the late John Chylderston, grants to Nicholas Palton all the lands &c. in Mildenhale which were William Chylderston's, his grandfather, excepting a tenement and land granted to his wife Agnes for her life, before their marriage. Dated at Mildenhale, 24 June, 37 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1361.
The will of Robert Chestun of Mylldenall, in the county of Suffolk, made 3 May, 38 Hen. VIII, 1546. [English] [A small part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1362.

Thomas Larke of Myldenhall and Thomas ...scote grant to John Barrett, senior, a messuage and tenement situate in the West Rowe of Myldenhall, together with certain land there, part of the possessions of Edmund Myldenhale's Chantry. Dated at Myldenhall, 26 June, 4 Ed. VI. [Slightly mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1356.

Grant by Q. Elizabeth to sir Nicholas Bacon of certain stock "or stawre" of the manor of Mildenhale, co. Suffolk, formerly demised by the abbot and convent of Bury St. Edmund to Robert Clerk, the said Nicholas paying to the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, to which the manor of Mildenhale is lately annexed, £54 10s. 4d. Dated 24 Nov., 3 Q. Elizabeth. [With seal.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 171.

Condition of a mortgage to Oliver Morden of Earswell, gent., in consideration of the receipt of £104, by Richard Childerston, alias Cheston, gent., certain messuages, orchards, dove-house, 25 acres of land, &c. 14 May 1623. [English] [On paper.] [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1363.
MUTFORD. Extract from the manor court roll, dated 1628; relating to land in Carleton formerly of the priory of Bronholme. [For the most part illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1364.

Memorandum from the court roll of 14 James 1, respecting the admission of Robert Battelye and Ann his wife to the to the land in Carleton formerly of the priory of Bromeholme, lately held by the said Robert alone. Partly effaced.
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1365

NEDHAM. Roger de Bevilers, son of Warren de Bevilers, grants to the hospital of St. Peter without the village of St. Edmund, in frankalmoigne, two acres of arable land, less one rood, lying in the field of Nedham. (c. 1180-90.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 3.

NETTLESTEAD. Sir Richard Wentworth, kt., grants to Edward White , esq., for his good counsel to the said sir Richard and to his son Thomas, an annuity of 26s. 8d. charged on his manor of Nettlested in Nettlested. Dated 25 March, 11 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 642.
NEWTON. Effaced, except in a few words; temp. Edw. III. The name of Bryan occurs. MS. Ch. Suffolk 354.

William Stonherd of Neutone grants to James his son one piece of a curtilage lying near his curtilage. Dated at Neutone the Tuesday next after the translation of St. Thomas the martyr, 18 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 355.
Effaced charter dated ... September 36 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 356.

Indenture made 16 July, 2 Henry VIII, between dame Anne Arundell of the one part, and Robert S... of Great Waldyngfeld, of the other part, by which the said dame Anne sells to the said Robert a meadow in Newton. [Only partially legible.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 357

Indenture made 3rd day of November, 30 Hen. VIII, by which the lady Margaret, countess of Salisbury, demises to William Alston of Newton, in the co. of Suffolk, her manor of Newton, alias Newton Hall, for 21 years, he paying an annual rent of £19 12s. 0½d, and gathering and paying over other rents and . [English] MS. Ch. Douce 31

NORTHALES. Henry Dobson of Northales, John Gybson, and Robert Baker of the same confirm to Thomas Doget of Northales Thomas Mason and John Poleyn, of the same certain lands, houses, &c. in Northales for £8 payable by instalments. Dated at Northales, 10 March, 14 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1366.

OULTON, &c. Thomas de Dool of Flixton grants to William Edrich of Olton one piece of land in the village of Olton. Dated at Flixton the Sunday next after the feast of St. Mark, evang., 5 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1011.

John Aleys of Olton and John Oldryng of Carleton Colvile grant to John Seynt, John of Olton, Robert his brother of Ryngelond, and others, one acre of land in Olton. Dated at Olton, 12 February, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1012. [Partially illegible.]

Robert Palgrave of Gunton grants to Walter Eton, esq., Henry Yernemouth and others, one meadow in Olton called 'Olton medowe'. Dated at Olton the Saturday next before the feast of St. Nicholas, 7 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1013.

Thomas Edrych of Olton grants to John Gernegen, esq., and others, all his lands, rents, &c. in the villages of Olton, Flyxton, Lowystoft, and Becclys. Dated ..., Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1014.
John Fuston, son and heir of Richard Fuston, late of Olton, grants to ...holas Huson one piece of land in Olton. Dated at Olton, 10 Henry VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1015.
William Herman of Olton grants to Nicholas Huson of Lowestoft, Robert Jetour, and two others, one piece of land in Olton. Dated at Olton, 21 May, 15 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1016.

Richard Kerych of Olton, John Fuston and others grant to William Jetor and others a messuage in the village of Olton and a piece of land called 'Piswellisacre,' with other land which they had by charter dated 26 November, 16 Hen. VII. Dated 26 March, 19 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1017.
Indenture made 6 May, 3 and 4 Philip and Mary, by which Humphrey Yermouth of Blundeston sells to Humphrey Brewster of Cordoke five pieces of land in Olton. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1018.

PAKEFIELD, CARLETON COLVILE, &c. John Bery of Pakefeld and Edmund Ponszere of the same place grant to Simon Fowler certain lands and tenements in Pakefeld, Carleton Colvile, and Geslyham, which they had by a deed dated 16 Feb. 30 Hen. VI. Dated at Pakefield, 20 August, 21 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1367.

PAKENHAM, BERTON, and ROUGHAM. Thomas, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund agree with sir Edmund de Pakenham concerning the rents of certain lands in Pakenham, Berton, and Rughham. Dated ..., 1308. [Greater part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 96.

PEASENHALL. An inhibition from Roger Radclyff, dean of arches staying the presentation of dom. Thomas Braycrofte to the church of Pesenak by the bp. of Norwich, on the representation of the abbot and convent of Sybeton, pending an appeal Dated at London, 2 Kl. June, 1466. MS. Ch. Suffolk 237.
PEYTON HALL, manor of. Extracts from a court roll held at Peyton Hall the Friday on the morrow of St. John Baptist, 13 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1368.
PLAYFORD. Original will of dame Elizabeth Felton of Playford, co. Suffolk, dated 8 July, 1639. [On paper.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1369.

PORINGLAND (Little). Copy of the register of the chamberlain of Bury of lands in Little Porynglond, with a charter of abbot Samson's grant to Roger de Gessynges. (Temp. Hen. VII.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 132.
RUMBURGH (?). Partially illegible grant to John Qwedok(?) of land in Rum.... Dated at "...bure predicti" the Monday next after the feast of the Epiphany, 36 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1370.

REDGRAVE. Final concord made at Oxford the Monday next after the octave of the Purification B.V.M. next after Louis, king of France, came to England to St. Thomas, by which William Oligrant quit-claimed to the abbot of St. Edmund all right in 40 acres of land in Redgrave, for which the said abbot gave him 20s. (1180.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 8.

Sampson the abbot of St. Edmund grants to Walter de Broch two acres of meadow in the village of Regrave, in the meadow called Dammes; paying 12d. yearly. (c. 1200-10.) [With small fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 9 .

William Staniland acknowledges that he owes to the lord abbot of St. Edmund at his court of Redgrave annually the following customs and services, viz. in each week from the feast of Michaelmas to the
gule of autumn, i. e. Aug. 1, one half day's work before dinner, finding his own food, and from the gule of autumn to Michaelmas day in each week two whole days' work and food from the lord, and two hens at Christmas and eggs at Easter and 4s. per annum, and for hidage 16d., and five seams of oats and seven teams at the ordering of the bailiffs of the abbot, and a fine for his daughters, and aid and tallage as his fellows, &c. (1235-1248.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 38.

Symon, abbot, and the convent of Bury St. Edmund grant to the five chaplains the chapel of St. John the Baptist within their manor of Palgrave, in frankalmoigne, one messuage in the village of Redgrave in perpetuity, paying annually for the same 6d. (c. 1270.) [Fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1443.

Robert, son of Henry de Pulham, commonly named Tweteshale, quits to Symon, the abbot, and his successors of Bury St. Edmund all his claim in a messuage and 16 acres of land in Redgrave which he had from his father; not withstanding a fine and a bond "ad sedem extrahendum ab huchia domini Regis". (1257-79.) [With part of seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 55.

Walter Oligrant of Redgrave grants to John, the abbot of Bury St. Edmund, and his successors, 16 pence of annual rent (from certain persons), for which concession the said abbot gave to the said Walter nine shillings and 8d. of silver. (c. 1290-1300.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 74.

RIKINGHALE, &c. Final concord, Mich. 9 K. John, by which John, son of William de Costantin, acknowledges that no acres of land in Rikingehale is the right of Samson, the abbot, and church of St. Edmund, for which concession the abbot re-granted to the said John 41 acres of the said land, (in several defined portions) also other land, and a messuage in the wood of 'Cumbhage,' at an annual rent of 12d. MS. Ch. Suffolk 16.

Adam, rector of the church of Richinghale, grants to St. Edmund and to sir Robert the Chamberlain of the same, sixpence of animal rents which Nicholas, son of Elias de Watlesfeud, gave to him. (c. 1220.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 36.
Ralph Banecroft of Rykinghale grants and quit-claims to Henry, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund one acre of arable land in Rykinghale in the field called Wyndhel. (1234-1248.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 42.

Geoffrey, son of Gilbert, son of Aylmer de Rykinghal, grants and quit-claims to Henry, the abbot of St. Edmund, the whole of the land under the wood of the said abbot called Swineffrith, which land is called 'Wodhangestoft,' for which the abbot gave him two marks. (1234-1248.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 43.

Roger the Welshman, brother of Stephen the Welshman, grants to Henry, the abbot, and the convent of St. Edmund all the tenements he has in St. Edmund and Rykinghale, and elsewhere of the fee of St. Eadmund. Dated at St. Edmund, 12 Kl. Oct, 21 Hen. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 44.

William Cokerel grants to Eadmund, the abbot of St. Eadmund, and his successors, in frankalmoigne, the whole tenement which he held by the gift of Hugh, son of Robert Leffled de Torp, in the villages of Rikinghale and Redgrave, and which the said Hugh gave to the abbey. (c. 1248-1257.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 52.

Hugh, son of Robert Leffled of Thorp, grants to Eadmund, the abbot
of St. Eadmund, in frankalmoigne, one messuage and 2½ acres of land, a green way, and 5 acres of wood lying in the villages of Rykinghal and Redgrave, for their lease marks paid him by the abbot. (1248-56.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 53.

Alexander, son of Walter de Rikinghale, grants and quit-claims to Eadmund, the abbot, and the convent of St. Eadmund in the village of Lower Rikinghale, in the field called Suthwork, for ten marks paid him by the abbot. (1248-56.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 54.

Henry de Tifteshal grants to Eadmund, the abbot and convent of St. Edmund, in frankalmoigne, a messuage in the village of Redgrave, and twenty acres of land lying near the same, and also another acre lying there and a meadow in Rikinghale, and 6d. annual rent in Glendrave and in Rikinghale. (c. 1248-57.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 73.

Hugh, son of John of Rikighal, grants to John, the abbot of St. Edmund, one wind-mill in the village of Upper Rikinghale, with the site and land adjacent. For this charter of donation the said abbot gave to the said Hugh 20 marks and 2 pieces of land as 3 acres at Redgrave. (c. 1260-90.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 86.

Bartholomew, son of Augustine de Walsyngham, remits and quitclaims to Richard, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund, all right in one messuage, lands, and tenements which were Augustine's, the father of the said Bartholomew, in the villages of Lower Rikynghale, Watlesfeld, and Hildercle. Dated at St. Edmund, 21 June, 18 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 99.

RISEBY, &c. William, the abbot of St. Edmund of Bury, grants to the prior and convent of St. Edmund certain lands, tenements, and rents in the villages of Rysby, Lacforde, and Flemtone which were formerly sir John de Rysby's, kt., to the office of the cellarer for the purpose of keeping an anniversary each year to the memory of the said William. Dated at St. Edmund the Sunday next after the feast of All Saints, 31 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 107.

ROUGHAM. Indenture witnessing that William, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund, have demised to John Bacun of Hessett their manor of Hessett, with two parts of the manor of Chanets in Rougham, for 6 years, from Michaelmas, 18 Rich. II, paying annually for the same £11. Dated at Bury St. Edmund the Thursday before the feast of St. Michael the above year.
MS. Ch. Suffolk 107.

RUMBURGH. Indenture made 20 December, 11 Q. Elizabeth, by which Thomas duke of Norfolk grants to John Hollande, gent., the remainder of a term of lease granted to Chandler, together with an additional 21 years, of the manor and parsonage of Rumburgh, and all that belongs to it, he paying annually to the duke or his assigns £40.
MS. Ch. Suffolk 26.
SANDCROFTE. The will of William Todd of Sandcrofte, dated 2 Sept., 1545. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1372a.
SAXHAM. Manumission by Robert the abbot and convent of St. Edmund of John Paman, a native of their manor of Saxham Magna. Dated 16 January, 11 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 124.

SCITFORNAHM. Geoffrey, son of Luke of St. Edmund, grants for 18 marks to the hospital of St. Saviour nine acres of arable land in the fields of Scihtfornham, paying annually for the same 9d. (c. 1215-20.) [With fragment of seal.] [T. de Walsingham, warde of the Hosp.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 48.

SNAPE. Indenture made 1 March, 9 Q. Anne, by which sir Henry Johnson of Friston Hall, Suffolk, knt., demises to Robert Hayward of Snape certain land in Snape for 6 years, at an annual rent of £35. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1371.

SOMERLEYTON, &c. Ralph, son of Ivo de Sumerletune, grants to John, son of Robert de Manithorpe, for his homage and service and 2 marks of silver, two pieces of land in the parish of Sumerletune, paying annually one halfpenny, (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1019.

William, son of Pagan, grants to Roger, son of Osbert, for his homage and service and 4 marks of silver, the whole of a piece of land in Sumerletun, to hold the same by the free service of 6d. annually. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1020.

Robert Snelling of Manethorpe grants to John, son of Robert de Manethorp, for his homage and service and 9s. of silver, one rood of land in the field of Sumerletune. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1021.

Robert Snelling grants to John, son of Hugh Quintin, for his homage and service and 12s. of silver, one rood of land in Sumerletune, paying annually for the same 2d. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1022.

Peter, son of Roger, son of Osbert, grants to Adam, son of Stephen Gurle of Manethorp, 1½ acre of marsh in the village of Sumerletun, saving pasture in the said marsh to him and his heirs, in exchange for half a mark and another piece of marsh in the same village. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1023.
Illegible charter. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1024.
William, son of Henry de Sumerletun, grants to John, son of Robert de Maniethorp, certain land in Sumerletun at an annual rent of twopence. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1025.

Roger Burkard grants to John de Manthorp for the sum of 20 shillings half an acre of land lying in the parish of Sumerletun, paying annually to him and his heirs two pence. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1026.

John Stede of Blundistun grants to Robert Eysman, for his homage and service and 4½ marks sterling, two acres of his land in the fields of Sumerletune. (c. 1250-60.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1372b.

William, son of Adam Gurle of Mantorpe, grants to Robert Assheman and his heirs for 30 shillings one piece of land lying in Sumerletun: rendering yearly one halfpenny. (c. 1280-1290.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1449.
Letters patent of King Edward I, dated at Morpath, 9 May, 31st of his reign. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1027.
Ralph de Sumerletun grants to John, son of Robert de Manethorp, for 6 shillings, a piece of land in Sumerletun. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1028.

Robert Snelling of Manthorp grants to John, son of Robert de Manthorp, for 16 shillings, ½ an acre of land lying in the field of Sumerletune, paying annually two pence. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1029.
Richard Waderduale of Sumerletun grants to Robert, son of Reginald Hesman, a rood of marsh in the parish of Sumerletun, for 2 shillings. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1030.
William de Legesteyn of Sumerletone grants to Robert, son of Reginald Eysseman, two pieces of marsh in the said village, paying annually for the same one penny, (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1031.

Fulke, formerly "messor" ("Fues") of Sumerletone, grants to Robert Asman of Little Gernemut sixpence of annual rent which Adam, son of Geoffrey, son of the chaplain of Flixton, and Juliana his wife were accustomed to pay him for two pieces of land in Sumerletune. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1032.

John de Manethorp grants to Robert Esseman of Little Gernemut, in consideration of the receipt of 36s., the whole of his marsh lying in Somerleton, at an annual rent of ijd. (c. 1260.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1033.

Matilda, formerly wife of Robert le Blowere of Sumerletun, grants to sir Peter, son of Roger, son of Osbert, all her right by name of dower in the whole of the lands and tenements with their appurtenances in Sumerletun which were the said Robert le Blower's her husband. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1034.
Robert, son of John de Manethorp, grants to John .... certain land in Sumerletun. Dated at Sumerletun on the feast of St. Michael, 6 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1035.

John, son of Ralph Nunoion, kt., grants to Peter Gernegan the whole of his hereditary ("propartem") part of the manor of Somerleton, with the advowson of the churches of the said manor with Bradewelle, with the patronage of the priory of St. Olave, and with the 3 mills belonging to the said manor. Dated at Stoneham Gernegan the Sunday next after the feast of St. George the martyr, 15 Ed. II. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1036.
Geoffrey son of ...ston of Somerleton grants to John his brother certain land lying in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 9 Ed. II. (no date of day) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1037.

Writ of Edw. III addressed to T. de Hindryngham, sheriff of Suffolk, and by him to the bailiff of Lutth[inglond], reciting a fine levied 12 Edw. [II] between William, son of Michael de Dol, plaintiff, and John, son of William de Dol, defendant, concerning lands, &c. in Somerleton, Blundeston, and Herrynflet acknowledged to be the said John's. Date effaced; but Thomas Hindringham was sheriff 1 Edw. III and again 5 Edw. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1038.

Robert, son of John de Manthorp in Somerleton, grants to John, son of Robert Aysheman of Somerleton, half an acre of land in the fields of Manthorp. Dated at Somerleton on the feast of St. Edmund, king and martyr, 14 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1039.

John de Rymerstone and Margaret, his wife, daughter of Robert Reed, of Somerleton, grant to Robert Gele of the same place one plot of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday next after the feast .... [First part effaced.] [3 Ed. III?] [Effaced] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1040.

Convention made the Friday after the feast of the nativity of St John B. 13 Ed. III, between Peter Gernegan on the one part, and William ...less... of the other part, concerning lands in Sumerletun. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1041.

John, son of Thomas de Manthorp of Somerleton, grants to Walter his brother one piece of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Saturday next after the feast of the Annunciation, 11 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1042.

William de Cotisbroe and Margery his wife of Somerleton grant to Walter de Manthorp one piece of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Friday next after the feast of the Nativity of St. John Bapt., 16 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1043.

Thomas Gernegan, parson of the church of Stonham Gernegan, Peter de Belhagh, parson of the church of Huntyngfeld, and Alexander, parson of the church of Horham, grant to Peter Gernegan and Ellen his wife and John their son the half of the manor of Somerleton, with the advowsons of the churches of Somerleton and Bradewell. Dated at Somerlytone the Sunday on the feast of the Holy Trinity, 16 Ed. III. [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1044.

John de Manthorp of Somerlethon grants to William de Manthorp his brother the half of a messuage in Somerlethon, with the reversion of the whole, with one piece of land adjacent. Dated at Somerleton the Monday next after the feast of the translation of St. Thomas, archbp., 21 Ed. III. [With seal] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1045.

John, son of Peter Gernigan, grants to Henry de Soturton, parson of the church of Somerletone, Alexander, parson of Horham, Robert Dorstun (?), parson of Wokefeld (?), Peter Osborn, vicar of Horne and seven others the half of the manor of Somerleyton, with the advowsons of the priory of St. Olave and the churches of Somerleton and Bradwell. Dated at Somerleyton the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Petronilla virg. 23 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1046.

Thomas, son of John Mersman(?) of Somerleton, grants to Thomas, son of John de Dol, his saltmarsh in the parish of Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton Friday after the feast of St. Barnabas, 22 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1047.

Katherine, formerly wife of John Perel of Somerleton, grants to William her son two acres of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Thursday next after the feast of the assumption of the B. V. M., 23 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1048.

Henry, son of Thomas Colle of Little Gerremut', grants to Ralph Dareys of Lound and Thomas Wasseleyn of Somerleton the whole of his messuage, houses, &c. in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Monday next after the feast of the Nativity of the B. V. M., 25 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1049.

Thomas Ayssman of Somerleton grants and quit-claims to sir Henry de Suthirton, rector of [Somerleton], all demands upon his marsh in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Wednesday on the feast of St. James the apostle, 26 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1050.

Richard Roger de Blundeston and Euphemia his wife release to Richard Draper of Somerleton all their right, &c. in one messuage and 3 acres of land in Somerleton, which he acquired from Walter de Manthorp. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday next after the feast of St. Mark the evang., 27 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1051.

Ralph Darreys of Lound grants to William, son of Robert de Broxton of Somerleton, a messuage and a croft in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 30 Edw. III. [In great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1052.

Thomas, son of Robert de Westgate of Somerleton, grants to Roger the smith of Heringfled the whole part of his marsh which he has in the village of Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton on St. Ambrose's day, 31 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1053.

John de Westone, chaplain, grants to Richard le Smith of Blundeston one messuage called Swyfts in Somerletone. Dated at Somerletone the Thursday next after the feast of St. Ambrose the bp., 35 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1054.

Robert Austyn of Somerleton grants to Richard Draper of the same place one rood of land in the village of Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday after the feast of St. Valentine, martyr, 38 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1055.

Robert ... of Somerleton grants to Thomas Wellyng (?) of the same place one piece of land lying in the village of Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the day of the translation of St. Thomas the martyr, 40 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1056.

William Salyour of Blundyston remits and quit-claims all his right &c. in 5d. annual rent from two pieces of land in Somerleton. Dated at Blundyston the Friday on the feast of St. Barnabas, 41 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1057.

Richard Smyth of Blundeston grants to John de Benacre of Somerleton one piece of land lying in the street ("vice") called Manthorp. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday after the Annunciation, B.V.M. 49 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1058.

Richard Maddyssone of Somerleton grants to William Coke of the same place one piece of land abutting on the way leading from Pokyslane towards Dool. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday next before the feast of St. Hilary, 1 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1059.

Illegible grant by Richard ... to William, son of ... of a messuage with appurtenances called Swyfts in Somerletone. Dated at Somerletone after the feast of Edward, king and martyr, 1 Richard II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1060.

Richard Maddisson of Somerleton grants to John Candeler of the same place one piece of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Monday on the feast of SS. Peter and Paul, 12 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1061.

Walter Fleur of Somerleton grants to Amicia, formerly wife of Richard Smith, one piece of land in the field of Somerleton. Dated the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Laurence the martyr, 12 Richard II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1062.

... Weffon and ... of Somerleton grant to Ralph Weffon one piece of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Andrew the apostle, 16 (?) Richard II.
[Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1063.

John Beverlee grants to John Jaruyngan one piece of land in Somerleton (in which Hugh Fastulf, sir John Fastulf, his son, William Boyton and others were concerned). Dated at Somerleton the Sunday next before the feast of St. Andrew the apostle, 14 Richard II. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1064.

John Thurberne quit-claims to Richard Dowe, rector of the church of Somerleton, and others all right in one piece of land in Somerleton between the rectory on the north, and the way called Pokyslane on the west. Dated at Somerleton, after feast of ... 17 Richard II. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1065.

Edmund Dool and Henry Dool grant to Edmund [Bonk?] of Ashby a parcel of land called Flyxtonescroft in Somerleton, with a marsh called Netheremerssh there. Dated at Somerleton the Friday next after the feast of the apostles SS. Peter and Paul, 18 Richard II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1066.

Indenture made between sir William Burgate, kt., and others of the one part, and John Gernegan of the other part, being a lease of lands, rents, and services in Somerleton to the latter for 5 years, at an annual rent of £20. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday next after the translation of St. Thomas the martyr, 1 Henry IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1067.

Elyzota de ... de grants to William Dareys of Lound and Margaret his wife a small close in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton on the feast of St. Wolstan the bp. and confessor, 21 Richard II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1068.

Illegible (for the most part) grant of a plot of land in Somerleton to Henry de [Guorton?] of Lound. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday on the feast of St. Margaret, 5 Henry IV. (St Margaret's day (20 July) fell on Sunday only in 5 and 12 Hen. IV) [One half effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1069.

Elizabeth Broxton grants to Stephen de Starys of Blundeston a piece of land lying in the village of Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Saturday on the feast of St. Agatha the virgin, 2 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1070.

Thomas Weffon, otherwise called Thomas Wevon, burgess of Great Gernemuth, son and heir of Ralph Weffon, grants to Thomas Oueyn (Oudyn?) three pieces of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 5 May, 25 Hen. IV. [Thomas Wevyn witness Ch. Suffolk 1075] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1071.

John atte Gappe of Great Jernemuth and others infeoff Thomas de Gunton of Lound in one messuage and six pieces of land in Somerleton and Lound. Dated at Somerleton, 5 Jan., 3 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1072.

Henry Sekysteyn of Blundiston grants to William Wulmere of Somerleton and John Wolmere of Letton one piece of arable land lying in the field of Somerleton, "in stadio qui Beltoft". Dated at Somerleton the Sunday next after the feast of St. Augustine, bp. and apostle of the Angles, 5 Hen. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1073.

Indenture dated at Somerleton the Monday next after the feast of St. Faith, 8 Hen. IV, by which Alice, who was the wife of John dil Grene of Somerleton, grants to John Boof of Lowystoft and Joan his wife the whole of her messuage with lands, marshes, &c. in the villages of Somerleton and Blundeston. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1074.

Katherine, formerly wife of John Pondele of Butele, grants to William Smyth, glover, of Somerleyton, one piece of land in Somerleyton. Dated at Somerleyton on the feast of the Assumption of the B.V.M., 8 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1075.

John Colles of Somerleton remits and quit-claims to John Wevoth all his right and claim to a messuage in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Saturday on the feast of St. Laurence, 10 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1076.

Indenture made at Somerleton the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Matthew, 11 Hen. IV, between Richard Crystemesse and others of the one part, and Henry Cablowe of Lound of the other, of the conveyance to the latter of a messuage with a garden, &c. in Somerleyton. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1077.

Gilbert Debynham, John Rokewode, and William Bacoun, clerk, demise to Margaret, who was the wife of John Gernegan, the whole of their manors of Somerleton and Horham, with the foundation of the priory of St. Olave etc. Dated at Somerleton ... February, 12 Henry IV. [The greatest part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1078.

Gilbert Debenham, John Rokewode, and William Bacoun grant to Margaret, who was the wife of John Gernegan of Somerleton, their manors of Somerleton and Horham, with the foundation of St. Olave's priory, Heringfleet ... in Somerleton, Blundeston, Lound, Askeby, Heringfleet and elsewhere in the hundred of Lothynglond, which they lately had by feoffment of John Gernegan, &c. Dated at Somerleton, 2 Feb., 12 Henry IV. [Partly effaced.] [Another copy of the Ch. Suffolk 1078.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1079.

Stephen Keys and William Clerk of Lound grant to Richard Cristemesse of Somerleton one piece of land and one inclosure in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton on the feast of St. John the Bapt., 1 Hen. V. [The lands of Ralph Wefhon and John Wefhon are among the boundaries. In 1082 they become Wefham] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1080.

Indenture between sir John Hoioun, knt. and Peter [Gernegan] respecting various houses and buildings etc. Dated at Somerleton, Wednesday after feast of St. Andrew, 12 Edw. III. [The greater part effaced.] [French] [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1452.

John Dunston of Hopton, Stephen Keye and Roger Prymour of Lound, grant to Richard Crystemas of Somerleton land in Somerleton, paying 2d. yearly. Dated at Somerleton on the feast of the Nativity of St. John the Bapt., 1 Hen. V. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1081.
Elizabeth Broxton of Somerleton grants to Roger Primour of Lound one acre of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton on the feast of St. Bridgid, virgin, 3 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1082.

Leticia Boston of Somerleton remits and quit-claims to Robert Qwhyte, esq., and Thomas Belstede all right in a messuage in Somerleton called Cokys, and in certain arable land. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday next after the feast of the Epiphany, 4 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1083.

John Booff, esq., of Somerleyton and Richard Cristemasse, and two others grant to Robert White, esq., and Thomas Belstede the whole of a messuage in Somerleton called Cokys, with certain land which they acquired of Leticia Boston. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday next after the feast of the translation of St. Thomas the martyr, 5 Hen. V. [With 3 seals, one armorial.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1084.

John Smyht of Mateshale, brother and heir of Richard Smyht chaplain late of Somerlaton grants to Oliver Cristemesse and Elizabeth his wife of Somerleton one messuage and 8 acres of land in Somerleton and Askeby. Dated at Somerleton, 20 Feb., 9 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1085.

John Jarnyngen grants to sir William Burgate, kt., Gilbert Debenham, John Rukwode, John Bartlot, clerk, and William Bacoun, clerk, all his manors of Somerleton and Horham, with the foundation of St. Olave in Heryngflete, together with the advowsons of the churches of Somerleton, Horham, and Bradwell, together with all his lands &c. in Somerleton, Blundeston, Lound, Askeby, Heringflete, Bradwell, Horham, Redlyngfeld, Alyngton, Wilbeigh, and Stradebrook. Dated at Somerleton ... transl. of Thomas mart. ... 1 Hen. [IV]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1086.

... of Somerleton grants to Robert Wever (?) Thomas ... and Andrew a piece of land in the village of of Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Augustine, bp., 2 Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1087.

Alice Grene of Somerleton, widow, grants to Roger Owdyn a messuage and a croft in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton on the morrow of St. Valentine, 2 Hen. VI. [In great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1088.

John Gernegan quit-claims to sir William Burgate, kt., Gilbert Debenham, John Rukwode, John Bartlot, clerk, and William Bacon, all his right in the manors of Somerleton, Hopton, &c. Dated at Somerleton the Wednesday next after the feast of St. James 2 Hen. [IV]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1089.

John Bakere of Somerleton remits and quit-claims to Oliver Cristemesse of Somerleton and Elizabeth his wife all right in lands and tenements which he has in Somerleton and Askeby. Dated at Somerleton, 26 December, 2 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1090.

Thomas Edwyn of Harringeflete, Oliver Cristemasse, and Thomas Kempster of Somerleton infeoff Roger Owden of Somerleton in one piece of land in the field of Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton on the feast of the Annunciation B.V.M., 4 Hen. VI. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1091.

Robert White, esq., remits and quit-claims to Thomas Belstede all his right in certain land called 'Cokys' in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the ... next after the feast of St. ..., 5 Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1092.

William, son of Andrew Barbour de le Southtoun, and Isabella his wife, remit and quit-claim to John Gernegon of Somerleton, esq., and Robert Banyngham of the same place, all their right in two pieces of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Wednesday next after the feast of the Nativity, of B.V. Mary 6 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1093.
John Bakere, parson of Somerleton, grants to Robert ....lyng, John Jernyngham, and others, a messuage in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 1 May, 7 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1094.
John Cristemesse grants to Richard Cristemesse, John Jetour, and others three acres of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 7 May, [5?] Hen. VI. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1095.

Robert Nikell of Pakefeld and Margery (?) ... quit-claim to Robert Banyngham and others all right in certain land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 24 February, 10 Hen. VI. [Great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1096.

John Wevon of Somerleyton grants to ... P... , burgess of Great Yarmouth, one piece of land lying in ... Dated at Somerleton, 14 November, 7 Hen. VI. [Decayed.] [With armorial seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1097.

Andrew Cok of Olton grants to John Gernyngham of Somerleton and Thomas Bolle, clerk, a certain meadow or marsh in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Thursday on the vigil of the Assumption B.V. M., 10 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1098.

Andrew Cok of Olton grants to William Knyght and John his brother a messuage and eleven pieces of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Monday next before the feast of the apostles SS. Simon and Jude, 11 Hen. VI. [Great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1099.

John Bakere, clerk, Henry Webster, and William Deryng, of Somerleton, grant to Robert Skarlet of Askeby, clerk, one inclosure with five acres of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton on the feast of All Saints, 12 Hen. IV. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1100.

John Curteys of Lound grants to Alice, who was the wife of Richard Cristemesse, and to John Cristemesse, of Somerleton, one piece of land containing 3 acres in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 20 June, 13 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1101.

John Yve and Thomas Bolle, clerks, demise to John Gernegon of
Somerleton, esq., and Margaret his wife, their manor of Somerleton, with the priory of Heringfleet and the advowson of the churches of Somerleton and Braddell, with lands in Somerleton, Blundeston, Lound, &c. ated 10 August, 14 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1102.

John Webstere of Somerleton, Isabella his wife, and Thomas Kempstere grant to Thomas Colyn of Lound three acres of land inclosed in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 20 April, 17 Hen. VI. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1103.

Thomas Wevon of Somerleton grants to Thomas Owdon and John Todynham one piece of arable land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 20 Jan. ... 8 [Edw. IV] [With seal.] [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1104.

John Jernegan, Richard Good and Thomas Kepstere grant land &c. in Somerleton to John Ive, clerk, Edmund Steyngate, and Thomas Wewyn. Dated 21 [?] September, 20 Hen. VI. [In great part illegible.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1451.

John Gernegan of Somerleton, esq., grants to sir John Hevenynghain, kt., John Darell, John Fastolf, William Darell, son of the said John and others, all right to the manor of Somerleton and the priory of Heryngflete, &c., &c., which had by charter been conceded to the said John Gernegan and Margaret his wife by John Yve and Thomas Bolle, clerks. Dated at Somerleton, 20 June, 18 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1105.

Sir John Hevenyngham, kt., and others (as in Ch. Suffolk 1105) demise and confirm to Henry Gray of Keteryngham and others the whole of the manor of Somerleton, together with the foundation of the priory of St. Olive of Heryngflet, the advowson of the church of Somerleton, and all the lands in Somerleton, Blundeston, Lound, Askeby, Heryngflete, and Bradewell. Dated at Somerleton the Thursday next after the Invention of the Cross, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1106.

Thomas Wewyn of Somerleton grants to John Yve, clerk, Thomas Wewyn, senior, and Edmund S... of Great Yarmouth one piece of land in the field of Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Saturday next before the feast of St. James the apostle, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1107.

Robert Primour of Lound revokes his appointment as a feoffee, with John Gerregan and others, as in a charter of Richard Cristemesse is expressed, for a certain piece of land containing 5 acres in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 10 Dec., 26 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1108.

Elizabeth, formerly the wife of Oliver Cristemesse of Somerleton, demises to Richard Hakon of Somerleton John Nodde and John Getour a messuage and eight acres of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 10 June, 32 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1109.

Thomas Owdene of Somerleton, John Cristemesse of Gorleston,
Stephen Hall (?), and ... Gunton of Lound, grant to Thomas Colyn of Lound one piece of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Thursday next after the feast of St. Mary Magdalene, 28 Henry VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1110.

Robert Pampe of the parish of St. Giles without Crepilgate, London, remits to John Cristemesse of Gorliston, late of Somerleton, all his right in three acres of land which he had by the gift of John Curteys of Lound. Dated 4 May, 25 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1111.

John Jernegan, esq., remits and quit-claims to John Ive, clerk, all right and claim in a messuage and croft adjoining in the village of Somerleton, which he, with Thomas Bolle, clerk, deceased, had from Edmund atte Welle, clerk, Roger Owdyn and Robert Prymour by deed dated 30 Sept. 12 Hen. VI. Dated 10 March, 38 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1112.

John Jernegan, esq., and 2 others quit-claim to ... all right in a messuage, croft, and land in the village and field of Somerleton, which they had by demise of John Matson and others, 26 Hen. VI. Dated 10 March, 38 Hen. VI. [With 3 seals.] [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1450.

John Jernegan, senior, esq., grants to sir John Hevenyngham, kt., and others, his manor of Somerleton, with the foundation of the priory of St. Olave of Heryngflete and the advowson of Somerleyton, together with all rents, services, &c. in the villages of Somerleyton, Blundeston, Lound, Askeby, Heryngflete, and Bradwell. Dated at Somerleton the Sunday next before the feast of St. Gregory, pope, 49 Hen. VI, and 1st of his readeption of his power. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1113.

Illegible grant of land in Somerleton. [Temp. Hen. IV?.] [Almost entirely effaced, but endorsed "Carta ... messuagium in Somerleton quondam Roberti Davy", and in a later hand "Boys in Somerleyton"] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1114.

John Jernegan of North Cove, esq., in accordance with the will of John Grene of Somerleton, demises and confirms to John Ivys of Somerleton and James Cobald of Becclys, clerk, certain lands &c. lying in Somerleton, Blundeston, and Heryngfleet. Dated at Somerleton, ... June, 1 Ed. IV. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1115.

John Jernegan, esq., demises to John Ive, clerk, his meadow or marsh in Somerleton which he acquired with John Festall of Olton and Thomas Belle, deceased, of Andrew Cok of Olton, by deed dated Thursday in vigil of assumption B.M.V. 10 Hen. VI. [With seal.] Dated at Somerleton, 10 March, 38 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1116.

Deed specifying the conditions of a charter of enfeoffment, dated ... June [18?] Ed. IV, of the manor of Somerleton and the church of Bradwell, &c. granted by John [Jernegan] to Thomas Bryan, knt. and others on the occasion of his being about to .... , mentions his wife Isabel. [Partly effaced.] [English] [It was in 1475 that Edw. IV made his French expedition.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1117.

John Yve of Somerleton grants to John Lodge of Somerleton, Thomas Lodge his father, and Thomas Deryng, one piece of land which he, in conjunction with Roger Owdyn, had granted to them by Thomas Dunnyng of Blundeston. Dated at Somerleton, 9 Sept., 4 Ed. IV. [See endowment.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1118.

Thomas Owden and Robert Cook of Somerleton grant to sir John Hevyngham, kt., John Jernegan, senior, esq., Osbert Jernegan his son, Henry Fen, and others, two pieces of land in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 16 January, 7 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1119.

Thomas Nodge of Somerleton and Robert Cook grant to sir
John Hevenyngliam, kt., and John Jernegan, sen., esq., Osbert Jernegan etc. the whole of ... in Somerleton which they had in conjunction with John Yve deceased. Dated at Somerleton, 16 January, 7 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1120.

Richard Cristemesse and others confirm to Henry ... a messuage and garden in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Matthew the apostle, 11 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1121.

Thomas Owdene of Somerleton grants to Henry Smyth of Somerleton, otherwise called Henry Page, Thomas Nodge and John Tudenham certain messuages, lands, &c. in the villages of Somerleton, Askeby, and Blundeston, which he, with Edmund Waryn and John Barkere, deceased had from John Ive, late rector of Somerleton, deceseased. Dated at Somerleton, 9 April, 12 Ed. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1122.

William Chirche of Langle and Joan his wife grant to John Veytone of Somerleton, John , and two others one acre of land in the same village. Dated at Somerleton, 26 June, 12 Ed. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1123.

Thomas Wretham of Blundeston Alice, his wife and others grant to Richard Cristemesse of Somerleton John Nodge and Richard Jetour and others one piece of land in Somerleton containing half an acre. Dated at Blundeston [22. Sept. ?] 18 Ed. IV. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1124a.

Thomas Owdyn of Somerleton, Thomas Knyght and Thomas Deryng demise to John Norman of Somerleton a certain inclosure called Howson's. Dated at Somerleton, 8 November, 19 Ed. IV. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1124b.

John Norman of Somerleton grants to Richard Hacon, alias Crystemes, of Somerleton, and John Nodge, Henry Page and others, six acres of land called Howson's in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 9 Nov., 19 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1125.
The will of Richard Hawkyn, otherwise Crystmas, of Somerletown, dated [30?] Jan. 1490. [A large part effaced.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1126.

Richard Crystmes and Thomas Deryng of Somerleton grant to William Meyer and Mariona his wife all their lands and tenements in the villages of Somerleton and Heryngflete, which they had by grant (dated 5 Aug. 38 Hen. VI) of Robert Cook, Edmund Waryn, and John Todynhem, together with John Veydon and Thomas Nodge, deceased. Dated at Somerleton, 6 Sept., 1 Rich. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1127.

John Nogge of Somerleton, John Dobyldaye of Lowestoft, and Richard Cristemas of Somerleton, grant to John Boys of Somerleton, jun., John Boys of Broxton, sen., and Peter Nabbys certain lands and messuages in Somerleton and Blundeston or elsewhere in the half hundred of Lothynglond, which they had by grant of Richard Wuley of Becclys and others, 12 March 19 Edw. IV. Dated at Somerleton, 8 Oct., 1 Ric. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1128.
John Nodge of Somerleton grants to John Baker of Gorton certain lands lying in the fields of Somerleton, formerly John Kechyn's. Dated at Somerleton, 10 October, 2 Ric. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1129.

Indenture made at Somerleton, 8 September, 1485, between John Jernegan, esq., of the one part, and Gyelys Brewes, gentleman, of the other, being a grant to the said John Jernegan of a tenement in Askeby called 'Bukmongere's' with 32 acres of land. [English] (See MS. Ch. Suffolk 756.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1130.

Thomas Wewan of Somerleton grants to Thomas Owdon, Roger Todnam, and Edmund Hustyng of Coston 2 acres of land in the field of Somerleton which he (with them?) had by deed dated 15 Dec. ... Hen VII. Dated at Somerleton, 15 December, 14? Hen. VII. (Date entriely doubtful.) [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1131.

Thomas Knyght of Somerleton Thomas Owdene and John Nodge grant to John Jernegan, esq. one acre of land in Somerleton, which they had from Thomas Wewan by deed dated at Somerleton 15 Dec. Hen. VII. Dated at Somerleton, 26 March, 5 Hen. VII. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1132.
Illegible charter. [Temp. Hen. VII] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1133.

Sir Henry Bryan, kt., sir John Hevyngham, (sic) kt., and others, demise and confirm to John Jernegan, esq., the manor of Somerleton, with the advowsons of the churches there, the foundation of the abbey of St. Olave, and the patronage of the church of Bradwell; also the manors of Stonham Jernegan and Wathall. Dated 2 November, 7 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1134.
Thomas Skeyth and others grant to Edward Jernegan and others certain lands, tenements, &c. in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton Hen. VII. [In great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1135.

Thomas Molister grants to Agnes Hakon, alias Crystemesse, widow, of Somerleton, Simon Hakon, her son, John Jetour, and others, two pieces of land lying separately in Somerleton and Askeby. Dated at Somerleton, 28 ..., 7 Hen. VII. [In great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1136.
Attested copy of the will of Thomas Owden of Somerleton, gent., dated 8 October, 1505. [On paper.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1137.

Simon, son of Richard Crystemasse of Somerleton, and others, demise to John Hervy of Worlyngworth William Carre and Robert Stanton of Wylbey, and Richard Love of Westale six pieces of land, containing by estimation 4 acres 3 roods, in Somerleton and Blundeston. Dated at Somerleton, 12 October, 21 Hen. VII. (See MS. Ch. Suffolk 1468) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1138.

John Hervy of Worlyngworth and others demise to Simon Hacon, alias Crystmesse, and others, a messuage called 'Veydons' and four pieces of land and a marsh lying in Somerleton and Heryngflete, and another messuage in Somerleton called Sexteyns. Dated at Somerleton, 12 October, 23 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1139.

Thomas Knight of Somerleton and John Boys grant to Margaret Knight, wife of the said Thomas, late the wife of Thomas Smyth of Burghcastell, and others, a messuage called Sexteyns formerly belonging to Richard Sexteyn and five acres of arable land in Somerleton. Dated 22 July, .. Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1140.
Illegible grant by John Hervy to Simon Hacon, alias Cristemasse, of Somerleton, William ..., and others. Dated at Somerleton, .. October, 23 Hen. VII. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1141.

Humphrey Wyngfeld, esq., and John Bowde grant to sir Thomas Tirrell, kt., and others, the manors of Somerleton, Blundeston, Flixton, and Sadhall, with the advowsons of the churches of Somerleton and Blundeston, &c. Dated 26 Feb., 1 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1142.
Edward Jernegan, esq., grants to John Broun and William Jakson certain lands in Heringflete, Somerleton, and Askeby. Dated at Somerleton, 20 Feb., 5 Hen. VIII. [Much rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1143.
Illegible charter of Thomas Smyth of Becclys, dated ... Aug. 14 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1144.

John Jetour, junior, of Lowestoft, John Bowde of Gunton and John Staunton demise to John Jernegan of Hatfeld, esq., and others, messuages, lands, and tenements,
&c., in the villages of Somerleton, Lound, Askeby, and Blundeston, which were Robert Owden's, late of Somerleyton, in fulfilment of his will. Dated at Somerleton, 11 April, 15 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1145.

Indenture made 1 July, 23 Hen. VIII, by which Thomas Jermyn, esq., of Rushbrok, binds himself in a sum of one hundred marks to sir William Kyngeston, knyght, and dame Mary his wife, to observe the covenants contained in a lease of the manor of Somerleton for the payment of the yearly rent of £54. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1146.

Sir John Jernegan, kt., of Somerleyton, grants to Edmund Jernegan, son of lady Mary Kyngeston two annual sums of £5 and 33s. 4d. charged upon lands in Heryngflete, Somerleton, Ashby, and Bloundiston, in pursuance of a covenant with William Kyngston, knt. and his wife Mary formerly wife of Edward Jernegan, the gather of the said John. Dated 22 June, 26 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1147.

William Heyward of Blundeston and Thomas Carter of Olton demise to Humphrey Yermouth, Robert Brecoster, Humphrey Brewster his son, and others all their lands, &c. in Somerleitown and Blundeston. Dated at Somerleitown, 15 September, 26 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1148.
Humphrey Yermouth and Humphrey Brewster grant to John Jernegan and others two pieces of land in Somerleton. Dated 16 June, 27 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1149.

Thomas Smith of Becclys, sadler, and others, demise and confirm to sir John Jernegan, sir John Wyseman and another, knights, a piece of land in Somerleyton. Dated at Somerleyton, 20 October, 27 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1150.
Humphrey Yermouth sells to John ... a marsh called 'Benakers'. Dated at Somerleton .. May, ... Hen. VIII [In great part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1151.
