Indenture made 26 September 30 Hen. VIII, between John Hacon, alias Crystmas, of Somerleton, clerk, and John Jettour, being a sale of certain lands, woods, &c. in Somerleton to the said John Jettour. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1152.
John Swetall of Somerleton grants to John Christmes, alias Hacon, clerk, rector of Summleytown, certain land in Somerleton. Dated . . February, 34 Hen. VIII. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1153.
Bond in £20 from John Ufflett of Somerleton to John Jernyngham, to secure an exchange of lands. Dated 15 March, 3 Q.Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1154.

Final concord, made at Westminster, ... of St. [Marz]ion 39 Elizabeth, between John Wentworth, esq., plaintiff, and William ...ster and Agnes his wife, Roger Shere, and others, defendants, concerning 2 messuages, 2 gardens, with land in Somerleton and Kessinglond, and certain other land in Askeby. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1155.

John Gouldsmithe, senior, of Wilbye, yeoman, grants to John Jernegan of Somerleton, esq., an annuity or annual rent of 10 issuing out of the manor of Somerleton. Dated 8 October, 15 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1156.

Indenture made 11 September, 13 James I, by which John Wentworth of Somerleton grants to William Southwell of Darsham the office of steward, coroner, and clerk of the market within the liberties of .... [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1157,

William Stanton of Somerleton, in consideration of the receipt of £594, grants to sir John Wentworth, kt., a messuage and lands in Somerleton. Dated at Somerleton, 30 Jan., 1628. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1158.

William Stanton of Herringfleete, yeoman, quit-claims to sir John Wentworth, kt., lord of the manor of Somerleton, all his right in lands in the said manor. Dated 10 January, 1629. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1159.
An acknowledgment that Lambart Cook has received of John Wentworth of Somerleton, esq., £500, which sum the said John was bound for. [Temp. Charles I.] [Mutilated.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1160.

SOMERTON (West). Copy kept by the prior and convent of Norwich of the composition between the prior and convent of Buttele and master John de Thweyt, rector of the church of Wynterton, concerning the tithes of West Somerton, with the consent of the Robert Clere. Dated 12 March, 1342, at Norwich. MS. Ch. Suffolk 192.

SOUTHWOLD. Anthony Allen of Southwold, gent., sells to his son Robert Allen all his goods and chattels of every kind as well in Southwold as elsewhere in England. Dated 4 Feb., 44 Elizabeth. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1206.

STANHAM. Master Symon, son of Bartholomew de Stanham Lambert, grants to the church of the Holy Trinity of Ipswich (Gypeswic), in frankalmoigne, 6d. rent from land in Stanham, called Slohescropht. (c. 1240-50.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 212.

STANSTEAD. William le Folyur of Glemisford confirms to Walter his son and Alice his daughter, for their homage and service, and for 20s. in hand paid, a messuage with a meadow in the parish of Stanstead, paying annually to Walter, son of Walter de Tilneye, 21d., with a dinner of the lord, or to have one penny each. (c. 1270-1280.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 359.

STANTON. Katherine Busshop, lately the wife of John Busshop of Stanton, deceased, grants to Edmund Man of Stanton, John Shepherd of Bredgeham, and John Fyce of Stanton, a messuage and land called Tabbards in exchange for one piece of land of 8 acres and one rood lying in Stanton. Dated at Stanton, 9 March, 9 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1373.

STOKE (Priory of). Hamo Pecche ("Peccatum"), son of Gilbert Peccatum, remits to the prior and convent of Stoke all his right in the tithes of his lordship of Gestinget. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 231.

STOKE NAYLOND. Indenture made 5 February, 3 Ed. VI, by which the right to the presentation of the vicarage of Stoke Naylond is adjudged to belong to William, bishop of Norwich, and acknowledged by Thomas Throughgood of London, gentleman, between whom an action concerning the right to the same had been instituted, and by Thomas Ruddock, vicar of Stoke Naylond. MS. Ch. Suffolk 360.

STONHAM ASPAL. William Feldgate of Stonham Aspal and others grant to John Crane(?) and others a messuage in the village of Stonham Aspal. Dated at Stonham Aspal, 15 October, 19 Hen. VII. [Much rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 643.

Robert Crane, esq., and others grant to William Wareyn of Stonham Aspall and two others, a messuage and croft called Smethis in the village of Stonham Aspall, in trust for William Wareyne. Dated at Stonham Aspall, 10 October, 4 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 644.

STONHAM EARLS. Henry Bruse grants to Richard le Wyte and Beatrice his wife, for five marks one piece of land in the parish of Stonham Earls called 'Gatherdesaker.' (c. 1240-60.) (See MS. Ch. Suffolk 1031) MS. Ch. Suffolk 645.

Richard le Hotot de le Percis(?) grants to William de Henleye and Felicia his wife, certain land in Stonham Earls. Dated at Stonham Earls the Wednesday on the vigil of the Epiphany, 5 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 646.

John le Qwyte of Stonham Earls remits and quit-claims to John de Mundeford, chaplain, all his right in a piece of land in the village of Stonham Earls called 'Gatrysaker.' Dated at Stonham Earls the Sunday next after the feast of St. Peter in Cathed., 6 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 647.
Illegible charter. MS. Ch. Suffolk 648.

Robert Godewyn and two others grant to John Crane, esq., and three others certain lands and tenements in Stonham Earls, which they had by grant of William Thorpe, son and heir of Thomas Thorne. Dated at Stonham Earls, 16 June, 1 Rich. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 649.
Robert Ive, esq., grants to John Buxton certain rent in the village of Stonham Earls. Dated ... Jan. ... Hen. VI. [With seal.] [For the most part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 650.

STONHAM EARL, CREETING ST. MARY, and CREETING ST. OLAVE. Indenture made 28 Jan., 21 Hen. VII, by which Charles Knevett, esq. of Stonham Gernegan lets to farm to Philip Gyssyng of Stonham County, two tenements in Stonham Cunti and Creeting St. Olave, called Thornys and Brydnellys, and a close lying in Stonham Cuntti and Creting St. Mary called Norwey; for 30 years, paying annually 20s. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 651.
STONHAM JERNEGAN. John Bissop grants to John, the chaplain of Stanham, for his homage and service and 10s., half an acre, of land in Stanham Gernegan. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 652.
William Oslard (Oltard?) grants to Alice de Derham (?) for half a mark one rood of land in Stanham Gernegan, which she held of the grantors father Robert. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 653.
John Cordebof grants to William, son of William de Ceresi, the whole of his land in Little Stanham to hold the same by the payment of 3s. per ann. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 654.
Richard, son of Walter the Smith of Stanham, quit-claims to William de Cyresi, son of William all his right in a piece of land in Little Stanham. (c. 1270-80.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 655.
Walter Marie grants to John de Pinkeney and Luciane his wife, for 20s. one acre of land in the village of Little Stanham, paying annually two pence. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 656.

Thomas Crowe(?) of Stanham Gernegan grants to William de
Hendleye and Felicia his wife one piece of land lying in Stanham Gernegan in exchange. Dated at Stanham Gernegan the Sunday next after the feast of the purification B.V.M., 33 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 657.

William de Hodleye and Felicia his wife grant to Margaret de Cyresy, for the term of her life, one piece of land in the parish of Stanham Gernegan. Dated at Stanham Gernegan the Sunday next after the feast of St. Valentine, 33 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 658.

John Brouse, son of Henry Brouse, remits and quit-claims to Felicia, widow of William de Hendleye, all his right in certain lands in Stonham Gernegan. Dated at Stonham Gernegan on the feast of St. Gregory, 7 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 659.

Philip Deneys, "chivalier", Edmund, parson of Mikelfelde, Thomas Cordewaner, clerk, and William Fysshe of Nedham grant to sir William Elmham, kt., and 6 others, the tenements called Stubbyngges, Horshawe and le Rodehous in Stonham Jernegan, Cobbescroft in Stonham Earls, and Jokenenaker in Cretyngge All Saints. Dated at Stonham Jernegan the Thursday on the feast of St. George, 6 Rich. II. [With 5 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 660.
Robert Ive, esq., grants to John Crane one piece of land in Little Stonham, containing 24 acres. Dated 16 August, 1468. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1453.

Thomas Sengylton of Mendelysham remits and quit-claims to Robert Crane all his right, &c. in the manor of Flede in Little Stonham, and in all lands, &c. in the hundred of Bosmere. Dated 1 Nov., 16 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 661
Agnes Crane of Little Stonham and others are bound to Agnes Paston in a sum of ten marks, payable at the feast of St. John the Baptist, 1451. Dated 18 June, 27 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 662.

Robert Crane, esq., and Robert Crane his son and heir, grant to Robert Blomfold, sen., two pieces of land, parcel of the manor of Waltonhall, and lying in Little Stonham, co. Suffolk. Dated at Little Stonham, 20 March, 31 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 663.
STRATFORD. John Chyrchawe and John ...ell demise to John Leech of Stratford a certain tenement in the village of Stratford. Dated at Stratford, 8 May, 3 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1374.

SUDBURY (College of St. Gregory at). Bond given by the warden and brethren of the college of St. Gregory at Sudbury, to pay to Henry, bp. of Norwich, and his successors, an annual pension of two marks, for the first fruits of thier church. Dated at Norwich on the feast of St. Luke, evang., 1381. MS. Ch. Suffolk 232.

John Cordebef, chaplain, master of the college of St. Gregory, Sudbury, and the brethren there are bound to the prior and convent of the Holy Trinity, Norwich, in a certain annual pension of 5s. on account of the foundation of the college. Dated in the college, 8 Kl. Feb., 1375. [With seal, inscr. broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 233.

SUDBURY. William de Grey of Cornerte remits and quit-claims to John Carbonel all his right of communication with a meadow of the aforesaid John's called 'Chiltonmedewe,' near Subir'. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1454

Robert de Halsted remits and quit-claims to John Carbonel all his right in the meadows of the said John called 'Chiltone medwe' near Subir' avout which there was a suit in the king's court between Robert Carbenel, father of the said John and William Elys and others of the burg of Subere. Dated at Subir' the Wednesday on the feast of the Nativity of our Lord, 9 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 361.

John Reneshale and John Wisebeche grant to Simon Herde two curtilages, which were formerly John Waryn's, below the bridges of Sudbury, paying annually 30s. of silver. Dated below the bridges aforesaid, 14 Feb., 48 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 362.
Illegible writ of K. Rich. II to the sheriff of Suffolk. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 363.
William de Grey of Cornerth remits and quit-claims to John Carbonel all right of common in carbonel's field called Chiltone medwe near Subyre. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 364.

Gilbert de Grangia of Great Waldyngfeld remits and quit-claims to sir John Carbonel, kt., all his right in the marriage of Simon, son and heir of Simon de Berton de Subery. Dated at Subere on Saturday the morrow of the feast of the Conversion of St. Paul, 31 Ed. I. [Mutilated.] [With seal.]
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1228.

Bond given by ... of Boxford and Robert Rudlond to .... Holmes, widow, and William Holmes in a sum of £40 to abide a certain award. Dated 31 March, 27 Hen. VIII. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 366.

John Grene of Sudburgh and Isabella his wife grant to Thomas Grene their son and Elizabeth his wife, their water-mill in Sudburgh and 3 pieces of land and one piece of meadow in Sudburgh. Dated at Sudburgh, 7 Oct., 14 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 367.

John Woode of Sudbery, cordwainer, grants to Walter atte Woode of Edwardston, fuller, Will Rodelond and Thomas Aldows, a messuage in Sudbery, in the parish of All Saints. Dated at Sudbery, 27 Jan., 24 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 368.

Alice Rogerys of Sudbury, late wife of Thomas Grey, Thomas Ayloff, mercer, and others demise to Robert Halghton of Sudbury and others, two messuages in Sudbury in All Saints' parish. Witn. Thomas Long, bailiff of Sudbury, etc. Dated at Sudbury, 14 Jan., 2 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 369.

John Shipley of Sudbury remits and quit-claims to Robert Fynche, clerk, Richard Dawson and Joan his wife, and others all his right and interest in two messuages with gardens in the parish of All Saints, Sudbury. Dated 30 Sept., 12 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 370.

John Wyner of Sudbury, draper, and Thomas Loveday of the same, carpenter, demise to Robert Ffynch of Bulmer, Essex, clerk, and Joan Dawson of the same, widow, two messuages with gardens in Sudbury. Dated at Sudbury, 22 May, 18 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 371.

Indenture made 2 June, 10 Hen. VIII, by which Thomas Stenyson of Sudbury, tailor, agrees to pay to Jone Wenden and Felicia Holden, her daughter, of Bury St. Mary, £4 by yearly instalments. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 372.

John Wyna of Sudbury, draper, and Thomas Loveday, carpenter, demise to Robert Finch of Bulmere, Essex, clerk, and Joan Dawson, widow, of the same place two messuages in Sudbury. Dated 22 May, 18 Hen. VII. [With 2 seals.] [John Levyng, mayor of Sudbury and Thomas Raynold, chamberlain] MS. Ch. Suffolk 373.

Indenture made 4 March, 1527, by which Robert Crane of Chilton, esq., demises to Wylliam Manwode of Sudbury, mercer, a piece of arable land containing 11 acres in Sudbury for 21 years, at an annual rent of 16s. 6d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 374.

Indenture made 31 Dec., 1529, by which Robert Crane, squyer, lets to Alexander French of Sudbury a limekiln ("lymekelle") and a house with 2 pieces of land for 21 years, at an annual rent of 23s. 4d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 375.

Indenture dated 8 Jan., 20 Hen. VIII, by which Robert Crane of Chilton, esq., demises to Wylliam Gardener of Sudbury certain pieces of land with a hill called Bromehill for 21 years, at an annual rent of 24s. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 376.

Robert Burtham of Lavenham, "cobbeler", remits and quit-claims to William Fuller of Sudbury, draper, all his right, &c. in a messuage and garden in Sudbury, in Freristrete in the parish of All Saints. Dated 25 August, 30 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 377.

Indenture made 16 September, 2 Ed. VI, by which Robert Crane of Chilton, esq. demises unto Thomas Fennyng of Sudbury, tailor, three pieces of land in Sudbury for 16 years, paying annually .... 1548 [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 378.
William Ruggull(?) of Sudbury grants to John Letche a messuage in Sudbury. Dated at Sudbury. 30 October, 3(?) Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 379.
John Innold and Margaret his wife, for a sum of £28 (£21?), grant to Robert Crane, esq., and Joan his wife, a toft ... Dated 6 June, 25 Hen. VIII (See MS. Ch. Suffolk 505.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 380.

SUFFOLK. John Cordebuf, son of Hubert Cordebuf, remits and quit-claims to Odo Morcoc, Robert Dun, and Robert Fittulf, all the service, &c. which they and their ancestors formerly were accustomed to make. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1215.

Geoffrey, William, and Adam, sons of Richard Fayrman of Quethacre, grant to Robert son of Osbert the whole of Hernaldesholm, namely in turbary, rushes and herbage, which lies between the marsh of Reginald Haggird and the marsh of John de Dale. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1216.

Convention between Hugh Gernegan of one part and Ralph 'le petit' of the other, by which the said Ralph grants to Hugh the half of the acquisitions which he is able to acquire upon the land of Walter de Watham by writ of right, the said Hugh paying all the cost, and Ralph making no agreement without his consent, under mutual penalty of ten marks, and (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1217.

SUFFOLK (?) or NORFOLK (?). Record of proceedings on the morrow of the translation of St. Benedict (year not given) in the church of Bramford before the subprior of Bresde, canon J. de Mendham acting for the prior of Gipiswic, and Roger de Tudeham, in a cause between the prior and convent of the Holy Trinity at Norwich and sir Robert de Carcon, knt. (c. 1230-40). Partly effaced. MS. Ch. Suffolk 210.

Thomas, son and heir of Ralph de Grotene, remits and quit-claims to John de Bousser, archdeacon of Essex, all his right in a certain
annual rent of , £10 of silver from certain lands and tenements in the county of Suffolk, which Richard de Talworth granted to the said Ralph de Grotene. Dated at Wrottynge, Talworth, the Sunday next before the feast of the Nativity of St. John, 13 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1218.

SUFFOLK. Grant from Henry Latimer to Gocelin de ... Pueronum and Richard his brother, for 20s., of the half of his marsh of To... Herk... below Kersh and the water running from Gernemuth to Becks, paying annually four pence. (c. 1240-50) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1332.

Fragment [being one half] of a license in mortmain for grant of land to the priory of [Little Horleston] dated 20 May, 2 Rich. II. [See Calendar of P. Rolls of Rich. II, 1895, p. 344.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1219.

John Russo of Leyston grants to Thomas Bedyngfeld, knt. and Adam Russe all his messuages, lands, and tenements in the county of Suffolk. Dated the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Thomas the apostle, 11 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1220.

William de la Pole, marquis and earl of Suffolk and of Pembroke, grants to Adrian Spierins, clerk, in consideration of his work certain mines of gold and silver and other metals, all the " wasshe and slagges" that come from the mines, for a term of 16 years without any payment, and also an annuity of £20 until he be preferred to a stately benefice of holy church fitting his degree. Dated 3 Feb., 26 Hen. VI. [With autograph signature.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1221.
Bond given to John Clerk by ... and [William Rose?]. Dated 21 Dec. 33 Hen. VIII. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1222.

John Jernegan of Belton, esq., grants to John Wentworth of Somerleytowne, gent., all his swans and 'aieres of swannes' in the counties of Suffolk and Norfolk. Dated 26 May, 25 Elizabeth. [Signed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1223.

Exchequer constat (acquittance), dated 43 Q. Elizabeth, to John Wentworth, esq., collector of the fifteenths and tenths for the hundreds of Loes, Carleford, Colnes, Thredlinge, &c., &c., in the county of Suffolk. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1224.

Mandate from king James I to sir William Wentworth, kt., late sheriff of Suffolk, to deliver up his office, with the rolls, &c. belonging to the office of sheriff, to sir Henry Northe, kt. Dated at Westminster, 8 Nov., 17 James I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1225.

A dispensation from George, archbishop of Canterbury, to sir John Wentworth, kt., sheriff of Suffolk, and his wife, for the eating of flesh on feast days on condition of giving 13/4d. to the poor of his parish. Dated 17 February, 1618. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1226.

Appointment by James, earl of Suffolk, lord lieutenant of the counties of Suffolk and Cambridge, of Thomas Mighells , gent., as lieutenant of a company of horse raised in the county of Suffolk. Dated 29 May, 1680. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1227.

SYBETON (Abbey of). A confirmation by Henry, bp. of Norwich, of the privileges of the abbot and convent of Sybeton at his visitation, they having exhibited their muniments, &c. for the appropriations of the churches of Sybeton with the chapel of Pesenhale, Cranisford, Rendham, Westleton, and Tunstall. Dated 22 January, 1394. [Copies of both Ch. Suffolk 235 and 236] MS. Ch. Suffolk 235.

Certificate of Peter Schelton, LL.B., commissary of Alexander, bp. of Norwich, that at a visitation held 24 November, 1408, in the parish church of Frostenden, the abbot and convent of Sybeton pro
duced evidences of the appropriation of the church of Sybeton with the chapel of Pesenhale annexed, and also of the appropriation of the churches of Rendham, Cranisford, Westleton, and Tunstall, and repeated at a visitation held in Beccles ("Bekkelys") church 18 June, 1413. [Original of the first.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 236.

Certificate from William Woode, commissary of James, bp. of Norwich, that the abbot and convent of Sybeton exhibited their muniments, &c. concerning the appropriation of the half of the church of Sybeton with the chapel of Pesenale, the parish churches of Rendham, Cranesford, and Westleton, and of Tunstale, at a visitation held at Ipswich 11 October, 1474. MS. Ch. Suffolk 238.

THEBERTON. Sir Ralph Wigor, kt., grants to John de Norwic the manor of Thebirton in Suffolk. Dated at Thebirton the Sunday on the feast of St. Cuthbert, 5 Ed. I. (The feast of St Cuthbert, 20 March, was on Saturday in that year.) [With seal of arms (a cross) and name.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1207.

John de Leyston grants to William and Hugh his sons 6s. of annual rents from land in the fields of Theberton and Middilton. Dated the Monday after the feast of St. Luke, 28 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1208.

Appropriation of the church of Thebirtone to the abbot and convent of Leystone, Suffolk, by Henry, bp. of Norwich and Nicholas, the prior, and chapter of Norwich; the old abbey having been destroyed by an inundation of the sea and the new having been burned excepting the charters. Dated 1 May, 1380. MS. Ch. Suffolk 221.

An agreement for the securing to the cathedral church of Norwich an annual pension of 4s., from the church of Thebirton, appropriated to the abbot and convent of Leystone. Dated at Leystone 15 April, 1381. MS. Ch. Suffolk 224.
Grant in large part effaced, from John Jetty and ... to William Everard, dated at Theberton, Tuesday after Nat. of Jo. Bapt. 5 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1209.

Edmund Jenney, esq., and William his eldest son grant to John Baker of Theberton, junior, three acres and three roods of land in Theberton. Dated 1 October, [12?] Hen. VII. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1210.

THEDWASTRE. Indenture dated 5 November, 30 Hen. VIII, by which John, the abbot, and convent of St. Edmund demise to John Freer of Wychamsketh their hundred of Thedwastre, with the whole of their rents, &c., for 40 years, at an annual rent of £19 8s. 4d. MS. Ch. Suffolk 152.

THORNHAM. John Abot of Hachetune and Agnes his wife grant to Hubert, son of Richard Bern of Brisewrd, for his homage and service and for 15 marks of silver, three pieces of land with a messuage in Great Thornham, rendering annually one clove. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1376.

Richard Frere of Mendham, esq., and William Freston, citizen and grocer of London, remit and quit-claim to Thomas Wyseman, esq., all their right to rents and services issuing out of the lands, &c. of the said Thomas in Thornham or elsewhere in the county of Suffolk. Dated 30 December, 38 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1377.

THWAITE. Augustine de Theyt grants to Manser de Holegat of
Wykham, for his homage and service and 2s., one piece of land in the parish of Theyth in a field called Suthfelt, rendering annually three half-pence. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1378.

THWAITE and ALEBY. Fine made at Westminster the 15th day from the feast of the Holy Trinity, 16 Ed. I, by which John, son of Robert de Weyton, and Sarah his wife acknowledge the right of Matilda, formerly wife of Andrew de Branton, to 23 messuages, 130 acres of land &c. in Thwaite and Aleby. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1379.

WALDINGFIELD (Great and Little), &c. Robert le Engleys of Great Waudigfeud remits and quit-claims to John de Hudebovil all his right, &c.in a tenement in Great Waudigfeud and Little Waudigfeud for which the said John gives him half a mark. (c. 1240-50?.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 381.

Roger le Engleys ("Anglicus") and Lauretta his wife grant to John de Hudebovill' all his right to the patronage of the church of Waldiggefeld. For this donation the said John gave ½ mark of silver. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 382.

Lauretta (?), daughter of William, son of ..., grants to John Hudebovill all her right in the church of Waldiggefeld. For which grant the said John gave her half a mark of silver. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 383.

STANFORD, NORFOLK. Humphrey, son of Herbert de Waldingefeld, with the consent of Ida his wife, grants to Matilda, daughter of Alan de Chastillun, for her homage and service and 4s. 8d., one piece of his land to inclose and build upon, paying annually to him and his heirs 1½d. (c. 1224-30.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1455.

John, son of Nicholas de Wygeberthe, remits and quit-claims to William, son of Alan de Goldingham, as his chief lord, for forty shillings all right and claim in a tenement which Walter of the marsh ("de marisco") of Westorpe held of the said John to his ancestors in the same village, also in two tenements in Waldyngfeld held respectively by Will. de Feypo and Rich. son of Matthew de Subire and 3s. annual rent from the latter. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1456.

Gilebert de Little Waldingefeld grants to Adam de Brantistune, clerk, the whole of a meadow in the village of Little Waldingfeld. For this charter of confirmation the said Adam gave 12d. (c. 1260-70.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 385.

Humphrey of the church ("de Ecclesia") grants to Nicholas, son of Roger de Subir', for his homage and service and eight pence, one piece of land lying in Waldingefeld. (c. 1250-60.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 386.

William de Feypo, senior, grants to sir Robert Carbonel, son of sir Geoffrey Carbonel of Great Waldigfeud, for his homage and service and three marks and a half of silver, 3½ acres of arable land in Great Waldigfeud. Witn. sir John de Hodebovile, sir Hugh Thalemascha, etc. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 388.

William de Feypo, junior, grants to sir Robert, son of sir Geoffrey Carbonel of Great Waldingfeld, for his homage and service and 4 marks of silver, 3 acres of arable land in Great Waldingfeld, adjacent to the land bought of Will. de Feypo, his father. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 389.

Gilbert Infang of Little Waudinggefd grants to sir Robert Carbonel
the homage and service of Alexander Martin of Great Waudinggefd and an annual rent of two capons, which he was accustomed to pay, for a piece of land in Little Waudinggefeld. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 390.

Richard Talemache and Robert de Aketon, chaplain, grant to Thomas Carbonel and Elizabeth his wife two parts of the manor of Great Waldingfeld with the advowson of the churches of Chilton and Great Waldingfeld, also a third part of the manor held by sir Robert de Bosco and Christiana his wife, as dowry of the said Christiana. (c. 1275.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 391.

Andrew Gunel, merchant, grants to John, son of Geoffrey de Heldrake [or Sheldrake?] of Little Waldingfeld, one acre of land and a messuage in Little Waldingfeld. (c. 1250-60.) [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 392.

Thomas Carbonnel grants to Richard Thalemach and Robert the chaplain of Aketon two parts of the manor of Great Waldingfeud and all lands, &c. in the village of Neuthon and the advowson of the churches of Great Waldingfeud and Chilton. Dated at Great Waldingfeud the Sunday next after the Epiphany, 3 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 393

Robert Patheles of Great Waldingfeld grants to Adam Gouthmound of Little Waldingfeld a messuage, &c. in Great Waldingfeld. Dated ... 20 (?) Ed. I. [Nearly illegible, almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 394.
Robert Cral, junior, grants to Robert Cral his father one messuage and one in Great Waldingfeld. Dated ..., 20 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 395.

John, son of Nicholas de Wygeberthe, remits and quit-claims to William, son of Alan de Goldingham, all right in a tenement that Walter of the marsh of Westorp held of his ancestors in the same town, also of certain other tenements and rent in the town of Waldingfield. (c. 1260-70.) [With seal "S' Joh'is fil' Nicolai".] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1456.

Roger de Stoke, Alan de Rokwode, and Geoffrey de Lees grant to Robert Cralle of Great Waldingfeld for the term of his life, and for half a mark of silver in hand paid, one piece of arable land lying in a croft called Hanecroft, at an annual rent of 20d. Dated the Saturday next after the feast of All Saints, 24 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 396.

Matilda, daughter of John Herberd of Little Waldingfeud, grants to John, son of Amicia Althot of the same place, for 14s. in hand paid, a messuage with a house in Little Waldingfeud. Dated the Sunday next before the feast of St. Barnabas the apostle, 26 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 397.

Elyzabet, relict of Alan de Rocwod, confirms to Robert Cralle of Great Waldingfeld, Isabella his wife and Robert their son, one piece of arable land lying in Hanecroft, which they had from her deceased husband. Dated at Aketon on Palm Sunday, 27 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 398.

Robert Scheldrake grants to Robert de Bures and Alice his wife,
for a certain sum of money in hand paid, two pieces of land containing about two acres in Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld on the morrow of St. Martin, bp., 34 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 399.

Robert de Bosco and Christiana his wife, who was the wife of sir John Carbonel, kt., attorn to Thomas Carbonel and Elizabeth his wife the third part of the manor of Waldingfeld, Neutone, and Chiltone, which they hold in dowry during their lives. Dated at Waldingfeld the Sunday next after the feast of the Nativity of St. John Bapt., 3 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 400.

John Ga...] grants to Adam Guhtmund of Little Waldingfeld and .... his wife, for a sum of money in hand paid, a messuage and meadow with a pasture lying in Great Waldingfeld. Dated on Whitsunday, 9 Ed. II. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 401.

Richard del H... grants to sir Andrew de Bures, kt., and Alice his wife, and many others, in Great Waldingfeld and Little Waldingfeld. Dated at ... March Ed. III?. [In the greater part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 402.

Peter Gauge of Little Waldingfeld remits and quit-claims to sir Robert de Bures, kt., and his heirs, all his right to certain lands and tenements in Great Waldingfeld and Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Aketon the Monday next after the feast of St. Andrew, apostle, 18 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 403.

Peter Wulnard of Little Waldingfeld grants to sir Andrew de Bures, kt., and Alice his wife, the homage, rents, and services of sir William Germye, kt., and Ellen his wife, sir Peter de Denardeston, Guido de St. Clare, Thomas de Tendryngg, sir Pagan, rector of Meldyngg, John le Neve, John le Ingluss, Robert Godwete, John Page, sen., William Catel, John Davy, Alexander Bryan, John Page, jun., Symon Page, Agnes Page, Thomas Terri, Simon Brid, and six others, for lands held of the said Peter in Little Waldingfeld and Meldyngg, and elsewhere in the county of Suffolk. Dated at Bures St. Mary the Sunday on the feast of the translation of St. Thomas the martyr, 10 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 404.

John, son and heir of Thomas de Aldham of Little Waldyngfeld, remits and quit-claims to Geoffrey Calle and Matilda his wife all his right and claim in a piece of land called 'Padebroklound' in Little Waldyngfeld. Dated at Little Waldyngfeld the Saturday next after the feast of St. Valentine, 10 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 405.

Thomas de Aldham of Little Waldingfeld grants to Robert de Ewelle (?) of the same place one piece of arable land in Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Augustine, bp., 14(?) Ed. III. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 406.

Roger le Parker of Great Waldyngfeld grants to Geoffrey le Bakere of Waldingfeld, chaplain, and John Aldith of the same place, one messuage and three pieces of land, &c. in the village of Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld the Sunday on the feast of St. Boniface, bp. and martyr, 19 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 407.

Sir Robert de Peyton, kt., grants to Roger le Parker of Great Waldingfeld one piece of meadow in the village of Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld the Sunday after the feast of St. Augustine, bp. , 19 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 408.

Hugh Calle of Waldingfeld grants to Geoffrey Calle his brother and Robert Pr... all his lands, &c. which he had by the gift of William Calle his father in Great Waldingfeld and Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld the Friday next after the feast of the Purification B.V.M., 23 Ed. III. [Partly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 409.

Robert Cral of Great Waldingfeld grants to John Aldith and Benedict Edward a certain messuage with a croft in the village of Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfield the Thursday next after St. Petronilla the virgin, 23 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 410a.

John ... and Gilbert ... grant to Roger ... and Juliana his wife certain land in Great Waldingfeld. Dated there .... St. Peter ad vinc., 21 (!) Ed. III. [With two seals.] [Almost entirely obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 410b.
Indenture made ...,26 Ed. III, witnesseth that sir Andrew ... grants to Robert ... 2 acres of land in Waldingfeld. [Almost entirely obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 411.
Illegible charter, dated at Waldingfeld, 26 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 412.

Indenture made at Aketon the Tuesday in the feast of St. Michael, archangel, 29 Ed. III, by which sir Andrew de Bures and Alice his wife let to farm to John de Sydhay of Great Waldingfeld five acres of land and of a pasture called le Hethfeld in Great Waldingfeld. [French] MS. Ch. Suffolk 413.

Walter de Aldham and his wife Rosia grant to sir Andrew de Bures, kt., all their lands and tenements in Great Waldyngfeld and Little Waldyngfeld. Dated at Little Waldyngfeld the Sunday next after the feast of St. Michael, 30 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 414.

Sir Andrew Bures, kt., appoints sir Richard Tappell (?) of Wykk his attorney to give seisin of certain land in Great Waldingfeld to ... [Entirely effaced!] Dated at Aketon ..., 31 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 250.

Roger Parkeyr of Great Waldingfeld grants to Gilbert Welbe of Aketon two pieces of meadow lying in the village of Waldingfeld. Dated at Waldingfeld the Sunday next after the feast of St. Augustine, apostle of England, 34 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 415.
Illegible charter, 34 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 417.

Ralph, rector of Chilton, and Walter Daggerd of Great Waldyngfeld grant to John Cral and Christiana his wife all the lands and tenements
they acquired of the said John by a charter of feoffment in Waldyngfeld aforesaid. Dated at Great Waldyngfeld the Sunday next before the feast of St. Thomas apostle, 35 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 416.
Illegible charter, dated [38?] Ed. III. [Wholly obliterated.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1381.

Indenture witnessing that Thomas Celyng and Agnes his wife grant to farm to Deonisia, mother of Agnes, all their lands, &c. in Little Waldingfeld for the term of her life. Dated at Colchester the Thursday next after the feast of the Exaltation of the Cross, 43 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 418.
Manor court roll, held the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Lucy, virg., 4 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 419. (Apparently re-referenced as Rolls 33.)

James ... grants to Adam Gauge and Juliana his wife of Great Waldingfeld one croft and a way in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 2 January, 7(?) Rich. II. [In part obliterated.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 419b.
Margaret Botiller is bound to sir Thomas Mortimer, William Forde, clerk, and Robert Hethe, in a sum of £40. Dated ..., 12 Rich. II. [Partly obliterated.] [French] MS. Ch. Suffolk 420.

Richard Rethold (?) and Isabella (?) his wife grant to John Apilton and others a messuage and lands in Great Waldingfield and Little Waldingfield. Dated at Little Waldingfield, 25 Sept., 23 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 421.

Robert Peyton, Gilbert Depenham, John Rokewode, Will Rokewode, John Aleyn, and James Grotene, rector of the church of Great Waldyngfeld, grant to Andrew Botiller, knt. and Katherine [his wife], daughter of Will. Phelyp, sen., esq. the manor of Great Waldingfield with the advowson of the churches, to hold to them and the heirs male of the said Andrew and Katherine. Dated at Great Waldingfield the Thursday next after the feast of St. Leo, pope, 2 Hen. IV. [4 seals, two armorial and broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 422.

Robert Peyton, Gilbert Depenham, John Rokewode, and John Aleyn appoint William Rokewode and James Grotene, rector of Great Waldingfeld co-feoffees, to deliver seisin of the manor of Great Waldingfeld, with the advowson of the churches to sir Andrew Botiller, kt., and Katherine, daughter of William Phelyp, esq. Dated the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Ambrose, bp., 2 Hen. IV. [With 3 seals, two armorial.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 423.
Illegible charter, 4 Hen. IV. Indenture between Thomas Ma... and ... Theoraton of Waldingfeld. MS. Ch. Suffolk 424.
John Rokedew of Illegh grants to Thomas Malcher one acre of land in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld the Sunday before the Nativity of St. John Bapt., 6 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 425.

John Mot and John Smethe of Neuton grant to Thomas Boneyt of
Waldyngfeld and two others one croft of land called Wodeshed in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldyngfeld, 16 Nov., 6 Hen. IV. [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 426.

Simon Aylof and Thomas Colman of Great Waldingfeld grant to Hugh Frere of the same place and Juliana his wife a messuage and land in Great Waldingfeld, they paying to the said Simon and Thomas £15 16s. 8d. by 24 yearly payments of 13s. 4d. Dated at Great Waldingfeld the Sunday after the Conception B.V.M., 8 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 427.

Gilbert Depenham and John and William Rookwode demise to Andrew Botiller knt. and Katherine his wife and their heirs the manors of Great Waldingfeld and Chylton in co. Suffolk, with the advowson of the churches of the same, which they had with others by the gift of the said sir Andrew Botiller, kt. Dated at Waldingfeld, 10 Oct., 1 Hen. V. [With the Rockwode seal of arms, and fragment of another.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1380.

Sir Andrew Botiller, kt., grants to John Howard, William Phelippe, John Phelippe, knts. and others, his manors of Great Waldyngfeld, Chilton, and Neweton in Suffolk, with the advowson of the churches of Waldyngfeld and [Chilton]. Dated at Great Waldyngfeld, 6 June, 2 Hen. V. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 428.

Sir John Howard, kt., and 9 others, remit and quitclaim to sir Andrew Botiller, kt., all their right in the manors of Great Waldingfield, Chilton, and Newton, and in the advowsons of the churches of Great Waldingfeld and Chilton. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 1 May 5 Hen. V. [With 4 seals, of which 3 are armorial.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 429.

John Gauge of Sudbury and Adam atte Wode of Great Waldyngfeld grant to Simon Calle of Little Waldyngfeld and Agnes his wife and others a garden, two crofts, with a certain way adjacent in Little Waldyngfeld. Dated at Little Waldyngfeld, 6 Dec., 8 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Suffolk 430.

Thomas Alhoot of Great Waldingfeld William Alhoot of Kersey his brother, John Pondare, John Roodland, and John Cobbe of Great Waldingfeld, all his lands and tenements in Great Waldingfeld. Dated the Monday next before the feast of the Annunciation B.V. M., 3 Hen. VI. [With seal] MS. Ch. Suffolk 431.

Walter and Thomas Cotton, John Ansty, sen., and Richard Sturgeon, grant to Robert Jurdon a certain tenement in Great Waldingfeld called Barrereves, for an annual rent of 2s. Dated at Great Waldingfeld the Monday next after the feast of St. James, 9 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 432.

Sir William Phelip, kt., remits and quit-claims to sir John Howard, kt., sirs Richard Waldegrave, sen. and jun., kts., Thomas Sampson and Guy Corbet, esqs., and John Coo all his right in the manors of Great Waldingfeld and Chilton, and the advowson of the church of Chilton. Dated 1 July, 9 Hen. VI. [With seal of arms, broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 433.

John Ansty, sen., appoints Gilbert Clerbek his attorney to deliver seisin of a tenement called 'Bernerews' in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Waldingfeld the Monday next after the feast of St. James the apostle, 9 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 434.

Richard Rysyng of Little Waldingfeld grants to Thomas Appulton of Little Waldingfeld and Margery his wife and others all the lands, tenements, &c. formerly Richard Ball's in Little Waldingfeld, as well as other lands, &c. in the said Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, 6 November, 10 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 435.

William Ryngefeld of Little Waldyngfeld grants to John Apilton, jun., and others, all his lands and tenements in the villages of Great Waldyngfeld and Little Waldyngfeld called 'Holbrokes.' Dated at Little Waldyngfeld, 14 March, 12 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 436.

Robert Parker of Great Waldingfeld demises to John Heriet of Waldingfeld, John Arnold (?), tiler, of Sudbury, Robert Glasewright, William Maughen, and Roger ..., all his lands, tenements, &c. in Great Waldingfeld. Dated 20 Nov. (?), 13 (?) Hen. VI. [For the greater part obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 437.

John Dander and Robert Middleton demise to Richard Thurston of Great Waldingfeld and others, one croft in Great Waldingfeld called Smythecroft. Dated at Waldingfeld, 20 February, 17 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 438.

James ..., Thomas Alloet, John Alloet, and William Alloet remit and quitclaim to John [Glase]wryte all their right in a messuage, buildings, and lands lying together in Waldingfeld. Dated at Waldingfeld, 4 June, 14 Hen. VI. [Partly mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 439.

John Appilton of Little Waldingfeld grants to John Appilton his son and Margaret his wife a tenement with a garden and certain land lying in Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, 6 April, 15 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 440.

John Monk of Little Waldingfeld infeoffs Thomas Prat, Matilda his wife and 2 others in one tenement and eight acres of arable land in Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, 10 May, 20 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 441.

Robert Wellyng of Lavenham Richard Risynge and John Bury demise and confirm to John Appilton and others a tenement called 'Smythis,' with a garden and two crofts of land in Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, 8 May, 20 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 442.

John Pondere of Great Waldingfeld grants to John Laggard of the same place, one messuage and one croft for the term of his life in the same village. Dated at Great Waldingfeld .. Dec. 21 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 443.

William Clopton of Melford ... and John Cobbe of Great Waldingfeld grant to John ... and Robert Pondere of Great Waldingfeld, one croft of land in Great Waldingfeld aforesaid. Dated at Great Waldingfeld the Friday ... 23 Hen. VI. [Partly mutilated and effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 444.

Simon Calle, Agnes his wife, and others grant to John ...., James Rodelond of Little Waldingfeld, and others, a croft and a little wood in Little Waldingfeld. Dated .... 32 (?) Hen. VI. [For the greater part obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 445.

Thomas Cobbe and others grant to ... a messuage and a ... in Great Waldingfeld. [Almost entirely obliterated by impress of another deed on it.] Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 446.

... of Great Waldingfeld grants to John Glasewright, John Rodelond, and Thomas Rodelond, a garden and croft called "Paddebrook" in Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, 4 November, 24 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 447.

Robert Wellyng of Lavenham, esq., John Glaswright, John Rodelond, and others, demise to Roger Morell of Melford and others, a messuage with a garden and croft in Waldyngfeld, conveyed to them by John Cobbge and others 8 June 14 Hen. VI. Dated at Great Waldyngfeld, 4 July, 26 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 448.

Richard Colman of Little Waldyngfeld (son of Alice, daugther of Rob. Aldham), Richard Alexander of Monks Illyghe, and Alice his wife (daughter of Joan, daughter of Robert Aldham), demise to John Appilton, sen., of Waldyngfeld, and others, two pieces of laud within the parish of Little Waldyngfeld. Dated at Little Waldyngfeld on the feast of St. George the martyr, 28 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 449.

John Heryet of Great Waldingfeld, fuller, remits and quit-claims to John Sydey of the same place, all his right, &c. in a piece of land in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld 9 May, 29 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 450.
An account of a sum of £6 of the earl of Oxford. [Nearly obliterated, all but one line and a half.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 451.

Henry Fynyngleeesq., John Clopston, esq., and others demise and confirm to John Sake and others half an acre of wood in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 20 January, 30 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Suffolk 452.

Ralph West of Sudbury and others confirm to sir Thomas Waldegrave, kt., and others, all the lands and tenements in the villages of Great Waldingfeld and Chilton which belonged to John Sydey, sen. husbandman. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 30 July, 1 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 453.

Margaret Hyne of Brent Illygh ["I. conbust."], widow, remits and quit-claims to Alexander Cressener, esq., and others, all right and claim in two closes lying in Great Waldyngfeld and Little Waldyngfeld, called Grendlye. Dated 7 July, 2 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 454.

John Coupere of Illygh grants to Alexander Cressener, esq., and others, two closes of land in Great Waldingfeld and Little Waldingfeld called 'Grendlye.' Dated at Waldingfeld, 1 July, 2 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 455.

Robert Smyth of Great Waldingfeld, Richard Sydey and Robert Clark demise to John Glasewright, sen., one close called Cobbysmersch in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 17 November, 3 Ed. IV. [With 3 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 456.

John Sake of Great Waldingfeld grants to Robert Deen of Newton, and others, a messuage, called Beleports, ½ an acre of wood, and certain lands, &c., lying in the villages of Great Waldingfeld, Aketon, and Melford. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 10 April, 6 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 457.

John Appulton and William .... Ryngham grant to Alexander Cressener and others one messuage, 3 crofts, &c. in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 16 Jan., 7 Ed. IV. [Partly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 458.

William Cros, son and heir of Thomas Cros of Edwardeston, grants to sir Robert Chamberleyns, kt., and others, all those lands, rents, &e. in Little Waldingfeld which were formerly Rosia Calle's. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, 16 March, 7 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 459.

Benedicta Reygnerham of Great Waldingfeld, widow, remits and quitclaims to Alexander Cressener and others all her right in a tenement, three crofts and a pasture in Great Waldingfeld formerly Thomas Reygnehem's. Dated 18 Jan., 7 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 460.
Illegible charter, dated .. Dec. 8 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 461.
Illegible charter about lands at Waldengfield formerly John Appulton's. [Temp. Ed. IV.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 462,

George Prentis of Sudbury, Richard Rysyng of Little Waldingfeld, William Yve, and John Rodelond grant to John Sydey of Great Waldingfeld and others, all lands, &c. which were formerly John Sidey's of Great Waldingfeld, fuller, lying in Great Waldingfeld, Nebton, and Chilton. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, last Feb., 11 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 463.

William Colman, chaplain, and William Slough demise to Robert Crane, esq., and Isabella his wife, a grove of wood with a certain way in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 12 May, 13 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 464.

Alexander Cressener, esq., John Clopton, esq., and others, grant to Robert Crane and the lady Anne his wife, the manors, lands, &c. of Great Waldingfeld and Little Waldingfeld, Chilton, &c., which they hold by charter of feoffment, dated 6 October, ... Ed. IV. Dated 10 December, 15 Ed. IV. [Partly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 465.

Robert Smyth of Great Waldyngfeld and others grant to Robert Crane, esq., and the lady Anne his wife, half an acre of wood in Great Waldyngfeld. Dated at Waldyngfeld aforesaid on the feast of St. Andrew, 15 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 466.

Richard Risyng, sen., and others, remit and quit-claim to John Baker of Little Waldingfeld all right in certain lands and tenements in Little Waldingfeld, which were John Norfolk's. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, ... October, 15 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 467.

John Syday of Great Waldingfeld and others demise and confirm to John Syday of Stow-market and others, certain lands in the parish of Great Waldingfeld which were formerly John Syday's, clothmaker. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 20 June, 19 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 468.

John Glasewright of Great Waldingfeld and others demise to Richard Martyn of Melford and others, one messuage with a garden and croft in Great Waldingfeld, as conveyed to them 1 June 14 Edw. IV. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 12 October, 20 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 469.

Indenture by which Thomas Asshford, citizen and woodmonger of London, lets to farm to Robert Crane of Great Waldingfeld certain pastures, services, &c. in Moche Waldingfeld, Chilton, and Acton. Dated 4 June, 22 Ed. IV. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 470.

John Glasshwryght of Great Waldingfeld and others demise to Richard Martyn of Melford and others, a close of pasture in Great Waldingfeld called Pynde. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 25 September, 22 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Suffolk 471.

Roger Martyn of Long Melford in Suffolk (being with others seised of three pieces of land in Little Waldingfeld) demises the same to Humfrey Wyngfeld and others for the use of Edward Colman. Dated 10 July, 24 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 472.

Alexander Cressener, esq., John Appulton of Great Waldingfeld, sen., and Richard Rysing of Little Waldingfeld demise to Thomas Appulton and Margery his wife and others, two closes of land in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, 21 .... 1 Rich. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 473.

John Syday late of Stow-market, dyer, and others, grant to John Apylton, jun., of Great Waldingfeld, lands, rents, and tenements lying in Great Waldingfeld, Newton, and Chilton which were conveyed to them 20 June 19 Edw. IV. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 18 Nov., 1 Rich. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 474.
John Syday of Chilton demises to ... thirty acres of land in Waldingfeld. Dated at Waldingfeld, 3 August, 1 Hen. VII. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 476.

Ralph Barton, clerk, James Rutlond of Sudbiry, and others, demise to Isabel Rutlonde, Roger Ponder and James Rutlonde of Waldyngfeld one piece of pasture in the village of Great Waldyngfeld. Dated at Great Waldyngfeld, 19 Sept., 2 Henry VII. [With two seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1382.
Indenture of lease from Rob. Crane and the lady Anne his wife to ... Baker at a yearly rent of five marks, made 3rd day of ... [More than half of the deed effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 478. [English]

John Goldyngham, esq., grants to Robert Crane, esq., and the lady Anne his wife, and George Crane, certain rents of lands in Great Waldingfeld and Edwardston. Dated 20 July, 5 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 479.
Charter by which .... John Appulton. [Almost entirely obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 480.

Indenture made 10 Jan., 6 Hen. VII, by which Robert Crane, esq.,
sells to John Colman of Little Waldingfeld for £4, certain tenements, and rents and services amounting to 3s., in Moche Waldingfeld and Edwardston. MS. Ch. Suffolk 481.
John Clopton, esq., grants to Katherine ..., formerly wife of John Syday, certain lands in Great Waldingfeld. Dated 18 (?) October, 10 Hen. VII. [Mutilated and partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 482.

Richard Ree of Little Waldingfeld and Joan his wife, daughter of John Baker, grant to Thomas Hobart of Hadlegh and 3 others, a messuage, garden, and land, in Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, 21 April, 11 Hen. VII. [With 2 seals, on armorial.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 483.

John Hert, the elder, of Waldyngfeld sells to William Lambe all the house and lands and cattle which the said John holdeth in Waldyngfeld; for provision of meat, and clothing for him and his wife for thier lives and remission of a debt of 20s. [Temp. Hen. VII.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 484.

John Syday of Great Waldingfeld and 2 others grant to John Syday, "le clerk", and 3 others, a messuage in Great Waldingfeld of old called Beleport, formerly John Sake's, sen., also certain parcels of land in Aketon and Melford. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 12 January, 12 Hen. VII. [With 2 seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 485.

Joan Brokford of Little Waldingfeld, relict of John Baker, remits and quit-claims to Thomas Hobart and others all her right in a messuage lying in Little Waldyngfeld. Dated 23 April, 11 Hen. VII ["ondecime"]. MS. Ch. Suffolk 486.

John Sake of Aketon, sen., son and heir of John Sake, grants to John Syday, bailiff of Robert Crane, and others, a messuage called Beleport in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 26 October, 12 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 487.

Thomas Spryng of Lavenham and William Park of Sudbury demise to John Londe, alias John Heryot, jun., of Great Waldingfeld, Ralph Londe, alias Heryot, clerk, and others, a tenement and land in Waldingfeld. Dated at Waldingfeld, 10 November, 14 Hen. VII. [Much rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 488.

John Sydey of Great Waldingfeld and others infeoff John Sydey and others in a messuage and certain land in Waldingfeld. Dated there [16?] Hen. VII. [Partly illegible, in large part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 489.

Roger Ponder and James Rutland demise to William Halman of Little Waldingfeld and others, a piece of pasture in the village of Great Waldingfeld called 'Wombisley', formerly Thomas Reynham's. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 8 October, 16 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 490.

The executors of the will of John Sydey deceased, viz. John Chestur and Christiana his wife, and others, grant to John Sydey, Robert Sydey, and others, one croft of land containing about three acres in Great Waldingfeld. Dated 12 (?) August, 19 Hen. VII. [In large part effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 491.

John Wynkell of Little Waldingfelds and others grant to Thomas
Appulton and Margery his wife, and others, a messuage, three crofts, and land in Little Waldingfeld. Dated at Little Waldingfeld, 24 October, 19 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 492.

Robert Appulton of Little Waldingfeld, Robert Waynflete, alias Pyper, of Great Waldingfeld, and others, demise to Roger Ponder of Great Waldingfeld, and others, certain land and one croft in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 16 May, 21 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 493.

John Appultonof Great Waldingfeld, husbandsman, son of Alice Appulton daughter and heir of Thomas Maleher grants to Robert Glasewright, clothmaker, of Waldingfeld and others a piece of arable land in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 30 July, 21 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 494.

John Appulton of Great Waldingfeld, husbandman, son and heir of Alice Appulton, daughter and heir of Thomas Malehere grants to Robert Parker and others one croft of arable land called Vpstrete croft, &c. in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 31 December, 23 Hen. VII. [Much rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 495.

William Herward of Sudbury, fuller, grants to John Sidey of Great Waldingfeld, fuller, John Rotelond, John Glasewryte, and others a croft called 'Wodeshed' in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 21 April, 24 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 496.

Indenture dated 24 Jan., 12 Hen. VIII, witnesseth that John Syday of Waldyngfeld the More, laborer, having borrowed of Robert Crane of Chilton, esq., 40s. to be paid at the feast of All Saints next, binds himself and his heirs, in case of default, to make over to the said Robert his house in Waldyngfeld. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 497.

Thomas, the son and heir of Thomas Cobbe of Great Waldingfeld, husbandman, demises to Robert Glasewright and 5 others one close called 'Cobbysmersch' in Great Waldingfeld, which he with others deceased, had from John Hale of Waldingfield by deed dated 14 Oct. 16 Hen. VII. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 16 August, 13 Hen. VIII. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 498.

Ralph Rudland of Great Waldingfeld Rob. Parker, and others demise to William Wystew of Sudbury and others one rent ('rentare') in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 24 June, 17 Hen. VIII. [Much rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 499.

Robert Glaswright of Great Waldingfeld and others demise to John Innold and others all their lands, &c. in Great Waldingfeld which were lately John ..., deceased. Dated at Great Waldingfeld, 4 Sept., 17 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 500.

William Holmes of Great Waldingfeld, John Sidey le Clerk of the same village, and John Rodeland, late of the same place, and now of Monks Illeigh, feoffees together with Robert Parker by the grant of John Appulton dated last of Dec. 23 Hen. VI (Ch. Suffolk 495) as now, at the bequest of the executors, of the last will of the said Robert Parker, late of Waldingfeld, in consideration of a sum of money paid by Robert Crane, sell to the said Robert and John Waspe 12 pence of annual rent charged on a croft and close in Great Waldingfeld. Dated 7 September, 18 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 501.

William Holmes and others, feoffees, under the will of Robert Parker, confirm a sale of one croft of land, called Upstretecroft , with a toft or garden within the same in Great Waldingfeld, which the executors of Robert Parker had made to Robert Crane, esq., and John Waspe. Dated 6 Sept., 18 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 502.

John Button, rector of Chilton, and Geoffrey Platfote of the same village, demise to William Wystewe and others an acre of pasture lately John Syday's of Great Waldingfeld, dyer. Dated at Chilton, 11 August, 21 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Suffolk 503.

Indenture dated 16 Sept., 24 Hen. VIII, witnesseth that Robert Rudlond of Marsey, Essex, hath bargained and sold to Richard Dogett and Edmond Tod lands, pastures, and woods called Wombysley in Great Waldyngfeld. [English] [Much rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 504.

John Innolde of Sudbury and Margaret his wife, in consideration of the receipt of £21, bargain and sell to Robert Crane, senior, and Joan his wife a tenement called 'Lagardes' and 'Chapmans' with two closes and croftes, paying annually to the lords of Waldingfeld halle 5s. 3d. Dated 6 June, 25 Hen. VIII. (See MS. Ch. Suffolk 380.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 505.

Indenture made 16 Sept., 24 Hen. VIII, by which Richard Dogett and Edmund Tod purchases from Robert Rudlond of Marsey certain lands, pastures, and woods in Great Waldingfeld. [Another copy of Ch. Suffolk 504, mutilated and rubbed.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 506.

John Springe of Hecheham, esq. demises to Robert Crane, sen., esq., sir William Waldegrave, kt., and others, one field of arable and pasture land called Upstrete crofte in Great Waldingfeld. Dated at Waldingfeld aforesaid, 12 March, 25 Hen. VIII, and signed by Spring. MS. Ch. Suffolk 507.

Indenture made 20 January, .. Hen. VIII, between John Innold of Sudbury of the one part and Robert Crane of the other, witnesseth that in consideration of the sum of £20 the said John sells to the said Robert certain land in Great Waldingfeld. [English] [Nearly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 508.

Grant by sir William Drury, kt., and others to Felicia Peyton, widow, an annual pension of 22 marks, arising from the manor of Peyton Hail and Baddelees in Great Waldingfeld. [Copy, Temp. Hen. VIII, date omitted.] [Paper.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 509.

Indenture made 1 September, 34 Hen. VIII, by which Robert Crane of Chilton, in consideration of the receipt of £32, grants to John Wyncoll of Little Waldingfeld a messuage, &c. in Great Waldingfeld. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 510.

Indenture made 1 August, 37 Hen. VIII, by which John Innold, in consideration of the receipt of £8, sells to Robert Crane of Chilton his lands, tenements, &c. in Moche Waldingfeld. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 511.

A lease made 15 April, 7 Ed. VI, by which Robert Crane of Chilton, esq., grants to John Kendall of Moche Waldingfeld, clothmaker, a close and croft in Great Waldingfeld for 10 years at an annual rent of 53s. 4d. [Copy on paper.] [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 512.

Indenture made 7 December, 3 Edward VI, by which Edward Colman of Waldingfeld, gent., for certain considerations, sells unto William Cordell of Long Melford, gent., certain houses and lands lying in Great Waldingfeld and Little Waldingfeld and Edwardeston. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 513 and
Memorandum of payment of £200, 23 Nov. 4 Edw. VI [Endorsed on MS. Ch. Suffolk 513.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 513a

Indenture dated 28 November, 3 and 4 of Philip and Mary, by which Robert Crane of Chilton, lessee of lands under the seal of the dissolved house of Crutched Friars, London, demises to James (?) of Moche Waldingfeld a piece of pasture and wood in Moche Waldyngfeld. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 514.
The names of tenants, &c. in Waldingfeld with the sums of money ... An. 1562. [Partly illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 515.

Anne Wyncoll of Little Waldingfeld remits and quit-claims to Robert Fenninge, clothworker of the same all her right in a messuage or tenement called Hammondes in Little Waldingfeld. Dated 15 November, 30 Q. Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 516.

Citation from Thomas, archbishop of Canterbury, to Thomas Carew, senior, of Little Waldingfeld, to take out or refuse letters of administration of George Carew of Richmond, co. Surrey, deceased at Dunkirk. Dated at London, 13 November, 1710. MS. Ch. Suffolk 517.

WALTON, St. FELIX (Priory of). William de Burnevilla grants to the St. Felix and the monks there, his man Eluric Pipin with his children, free of all service except xvd., which Fulk the prior and his successors will give annually to the said William, to be paid by the monks until the death of one of them; and for this grant 20s. are paid. (c. 1160-70.) [Chirograph.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 240.

Robert de Burnovill' grants to St. Felix, at Waletone and the monks there, his man Elfric Pipin with all his children, free of all service. For this donation the prior and monks gave to him l0s. (c. 1170-80.) Witn. Roger Bigod his lord. MS. Ch. Suffolk 239.

William, lord of Grimestune, grants to St. Felix and the monks there, in frankalmoigne, for the souls of his wife and of his successors 12d. from the land which was Eadnoth's, which Roger Cristemasse holds. (c. 1210-20.) [Done in the time of Robert, the prior.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 241.
Richard de Stampes grants to the priory of Walton St. Felix, in frankalmoigne, an annual rent of 6d. (c. 1210-30.) [Endorsed "Tempore Roberti prioris"] [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 242.
Isabella, the daughter of Hugh Joye, grants to the church of St. Felix 2d. annual rent in Walton. (c. 1250-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 243.

Commission from Thomas, the prior, and chapter of Rochester, to their bretheren John, keeper of the cell of St. Felix, Walton, Norwich diocese, William de Schotindon, sacrist of Rochester, Thomas de Hakyntone, John de Grenestrete, and John de Westham, for the elect a bishop of Rochester, the see being then vacant. Dated in their chapter of Rochester, 8 Id. June, 1291. [With small fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1384.

Thomas Wolsey, archbishop of York, remits and quit-claims to the duke of Norfolk, Thomas Wentworth, Philip Tylney, John Cornewales, Edmund Wyndham, and Edmund Knevet, all right, &c. to lands, advowsons, &c. belonging to the priory of Felixstowe, co. Suffolk. Dated 20 October, 21 Hen. VIII. Granted to them by Will. Capon, the master of the College of St. Mary at Gipewic of which he was the founder. MS. Ch. Suffolk 244.

WALSHAM. Helyas, son of Adam, the priest of Walesham, grants to Alice and Cecilia his sisters half a rood of land lying in the village of Walesham, in Millecroft, for six shillings, rendering annually one pence. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1383.
WANGFORD. The will of John Roo of Wangford, made 30 Dec., 1469. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1211.

WESTHALL. Indenture dated 5 June, 19 Charles II, by which the dean and chapter of Norwich demise to Samuel Spendlove of Norwich, woollen draper, their impropriate rectory of Westhall for 21 years at an annual rent of £4 and certain wheat and malt. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1212.

WESTLEY and FORNHAM. Anselm, the abbot of St. Edmund, grants to Leo and his heirs one toft in the town of St. Edmund, which Holdoger bought of the widow Godgiva and left at his death to Anselm, the land belonging to Hernegrida, etc., and land at Westley of the hall of Fornhame paying annually 4s. to the provost of Fornhem; land formerly wood at Leventune. (Anselm, abbot, 1121-48.) [A remarkably fine, perfect and long charter, with many particulars omitted above.] Witn. Talebot the prior with all the convent, and 35 others! MS. Ch. Suffolk 1.

WESTLEY. Isabella, relict of Robert de Westle, grants to William the prior and brethren of the hospital of St. Peter one rood of land, in exchange for another, in the fields of Westle. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 65.

Robert de Waunford, merchant, grants to the hospital of St. Peter without the gate of Risseby, in the suburb of St. Edmund, six acres of arable land lying in the fields of Westle in that field called 'Le Dune', paying yearly 6d. to the lord of Little Horniggesherthe. (c. 1260.) [With perfect seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 67.

John de Westle, chaplain, gives to William prior of the hospital of St. Peter one halfpenny of annual rent, which he was accustomed to receive of Isabella, relict of Robert de Westle. (c. 1270-80.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 69.

Walter, son of Adam of Westle, and Marsilia his wife grant to the hospital of St. Peter a piece of arable land in the fields of Westle. (c. 1270.) Witn. Geoffrey fitz-Robert Alderman, Nicholas fitz-Fulk and Gilb. de Porunre, bailiffs [With two seals.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 71.

Convention (indented) made between Robert de Baketon , clerk, then prior of the hospital of St. Peter, and convent of the same, of one part, and Robert de Waunford and Isabella his wife of the other, by which the said Robert and Isabella grant to the said hospital six acres of land in Westle, in the field called la Dune for which the said prior and convent will give them annually 4s. during their lives. (c. 1260-70.) [With seal, almost obliterated.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 76.

Convention, dated 1275, between William, son of Bartholomew of St. Edmund, of one part, and the brethren of the hospital of St. Peter of the other, witnesseth that the said William grants in exchange to the said hospital three roods of land in the fields of Westle, &c. [With seal.] Witn. Geoffrey fitz-Robert alderman, Luke fitz-John and Will. de Waldpole, bailiffs MS. Ch. Suffolk 77.

Roger de Multon grants to Hugh de Bakinghetch and Peter de Lausela , merchants of St. Edmund, for 6 marks one piece of arable land lying in the field of Westle, reckoned at six acres in the field called le Dune. (c. 1270-80.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1385.

Roger, son of Roger de Multone, sells and quit-claims to William, the prior, and hospital of St. Peter of St. Edmund all his right and claim in six acres of arable land lying in the field of Westle, in the field called le Dune. Dated 29 Ed. I. (Without date of day) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1386.

Roger de Multon, parson of Chetebere, remits and quit-claims to the hospital of St. Peter, all his right to six-pence annual rent from six acres of land in the fields of Westle. Dated at St. Edmund's the Friday next after the feast of St. Michael, 4 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Suffolk 97.

Robert Gyffard grants and confirms to John de Brom and three others eight acres of land lying in the fields of Westle near St. Edmund. Dated at Westle the Tuesday on the feast of St. Crispin and Crispinian, martyrs, 30 Ed. III. [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1387.

WESTON. Roger de Aph... of Weston remits and quit-claims to William son of Ralph 'le Ventrer' all his right in one halfpenny rent which he was accustomed to receive at Michaelmas of William, son of Margaret Helle of Weston, from a certain piece of land in Weston. Dated at Weston the Sunday next after the feast of St. James, apostle, 2(?) Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1388.

WESTROW (in Middenhale?) Illegible charter. Entirely effaced; but endowed in a 15th cent. hand as being "a dede of a messuage, a crofte and a meadow in Westgoldham" from John Baker, John Gregs, and Bartholomew ... [Temp. Ed. III.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1389.

WETHERINGSETT ... relict of Ralph [Aspall?] of Wetheringsett, grants to William her son all her right in a piece of land in the parish of Wetheringsete, in the meadow called Colingforthe medwe. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1390.

WEYBRIDGE. The will of Edward Curson late of Waybridge, co. Suffolk, gentleman, dated 26 May, 1651, to be buried at Burnham Overy, Norfolk. [On paper.] [English]
MS. Ch. Suffolk 1391.

WICKHAM. Lefseda, the daughter of Thorold de Wycham, widow, grants to Richard, son of Robert de Whatefelde, the whole of her land and one messuage which he held in Wycham, in relation for his guardianship of her during her life; rendeding the services [severally specified] due to the lords of the fee. (c. 1240.) [See MS. Ch. Essex 84 .] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1392.

John Gernun of Wycham quit-claims to Richard son of Robert de Watefeld the whole of the land which Lefseda, who was the daughter of Thorald de Wycham, gave to the said Richard in the village of Wycham, paying annually 6d. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1393.

John Gernun of Wicham grants to Richard de Hwatefeld, for his homage and for eight marks sterling, five-acres of land, more or less, in Wicham, paying annually for the same 17d. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1394.

Robert de Scheyt grants to John le Bover of the same, for the sum of 5s. one piece of land lying in Wycham in a field called 'Helle,' paying annually for the same 2d. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1395.
Thomas Pyteman of Wycham grants to Henry Costi for four shillings one piece of land in the field called 'Wylethenemere' (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1396.
Manser de Skeyth of Wycham grants to John, son of Gunnora de Gythgham, for 9s. one piece of arable land in Wycham in a field called 'Phuytemor.' (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1397.
Illegible charter, temp. Hen. III, to Margery de Rishangle. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1398.

Matilda, daughter of William Gernun of Pylecok, widow, grants for 20s. to Thomas Gernun, her brother, 12 acres of arable land in Wycham, with a messuage, etc. which her late father bought of Robert de Mendalesham, and gave to her in marriage dowry; paying annually three pence half penny. (c. 1270.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1399.

Martin Morcoc of Wyeham grants to Benedict Pellinario of Skeyth for 13s. 6d. one piece of arable land in Wychara in the field called Blakelond at an annual rent of 3d. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1400.

Walter, son of Manser de Wicham, grants to Adam, son of Thomas Orger, for his homage and service and one mark, the whole of the land which Thomas Orger, father of the said Adam, sometime held of him in the village of Wicham, excepting a fourth part which Roger Hose holds; paying annually 16d. (c. 1270.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1401.

Hugh de Lassandre grants to Richard de Bosco of Wicham, for his homage and service and for 10s. 4d. in hand paid, one acre and half a rood of wood in the wood called Hyda, paying yearly two pence. (c. 1250) [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1402.
Thomas Hose of Wycham grants to Adam, son of Thomas Hemming, for 16s. eight pieces of arable land in Wycham, paying yearly five pence. (c. 1240-50.) [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1403.
Manser de Skeyth grants to Roger le Reve of Wycham for two one piece of arable land in Wycham, lying in a field called 'Wylegenemere.' (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1404.

Richard de Watefeld grants to Manser de Holegate for ten shillings one piece of arable land in the village of Vicham, in the field called Gumsfeld; paying annually three halfpence. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1405.

Angnes, daughter of Roger de Berton, clerk, quit-claims to Richard Russel of Whatefeld all her right in the tenement in Wykham, which her father formerly bought of John Gernan and afterwards sold to the said Richard, for which quit-claim he gave her 2 marks. (c. 1250.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1406.

John, son of Anaund (sic) de Thweyt, quit-claims to Richard de Whatefeld for half a mark all right and claim in land and a tenement in the village of Wykham (sic), which the said Richard bought of Roger the clerck, and for one part of which the said John impleaded him by writ de recto in the court of Eye. (c. 1250.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1407.

Walter, son of the late Baldric the smith, of Wycham, grants to Margery, daughter of the late Philip le Porter of Eya, one piece of land in Wycham, paying annually for the same 3d. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1408.

John, son of Thomas Gernun, grants to Richard Russel of Vatefeld, for one mark the whole of the land and a tenement, with the homages and services, which Roger de Berton held of Thomas Gernun his father in Wyckham. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1409.

Emma, widow of Manser de Wicham (?), grants to Robert her brother, for 11s. one piece of land in Wicham in the field called 'Gumsfeld,' paying annually for the same 1½d. (c. 1270.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1410.
Grant from Symon de Rising' [endorsement] to the abbot and convent of St. John, Colchester of a piece of land in Wicham. [In most part illegible.] (c. 1270-80) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1411.
Walter, son of the late Baldric the smith, of Wycham, grants to Vincent, son of Robert Aylwy, for 18s., one piece of land in Wycham; paying annually three pence. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1412.

William Godenell, deacon, grants to Robert and John, sons of the late Jordan the carpenter, for their homage and service and for 29s., one piece of land lying in a field called 'Jolhege,' paying annually for the same 4d. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1413a.

Martin Morkac of Wicham grants to William, son of Turgis of
Rishangle, for his service and 11s., twelve pence of annual rent coming annually from John Gernun of Wicham for land in Wicham. (c. 1250-60.) [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1413b.

Robert Hune and [Berta his wife?], for 19s., grant to ... one piece of land in Wikham which Agnes, who was the wife of Odo ..., gave to him in marriage dowry with her daughter the said Berta. (c. 1240-50.) [One half effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1414.

Robert, son of Henry de Bosco of Wicham, quit-claims to Richard de Wicham, clerk, for ever, one penny annual rent, which he was accustomed to pay to him for a certain messuage in Wicham, which Benedicta the mother of Henry de Bosco, the grantors father, held as dowry. (c. 1290-1300.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1415.
Thomas Gernun grants to Roger de Berton, clerk, that he may be his attorney to make the service to the chief lords of the fees which he holds of him in Wicham. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1416.

Roger, son of the late William de Cotton, kt., grants to Robert, son of the late Roger de Wycham, for half a mark two pieces of land, one lying in a field called 'Dune' and the other in a field called 'Merys,' in Wycham, at an annual rent of one penny; releasing him from the dues of hens and work in autumn for the same. Dated 5 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1417.
Robert de Wyverdestun grants to Alexander, the 'pastor' of Wycham, for 11s. 4d. one piece of land above Sckeyth at an annual rent of 7d. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1418.

Martin del Grene of Wycham grants to Katherine his daughter and Nicholas le Goldsmit, in free marriage, one piece of his garden with buildings, &c., and 2 pieces of arable land in the field called 'Wlfryhtust,' and 8d. annual rent from Theobald, his brother, in Wycham; rendering annually 12d. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1419.

Brian, son of Odo de Colchester, grants to Nicholas de Bedefeld a piece of land in Vicham and the homage and service of William Bussop and his heirs, for a tenement held of the said Brian of the said fee. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1420.
Martin, son of Odo de Grene, grants to Nicholas de Bedefelde six acres of land in Wicham. (c. 1270-80.) [In part illegible.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1421.

Odo Morcoc grants to Godfrey Cordebof one acre of land in Wicham and also the third part of the land which he holds from sir Hubert Cordebof, father of the said Godfrey, at an annual rent of 8d. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Suffolk 1422.
Illegible charter, temp. Ed. I. [Almost entirely effaced.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1423.
Inventory (apparently) of farming stock held by Alice Dal(e) and John her son ... in de Wickham. [Illegible.] [cf. leasae to them 12 Edw. IV, MS. Ch. Essex 154.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1424.

Indenture dated 20 April, 33 Henry VIII, by which Richard Freeston of Mendham, esq., demises to Nicholas Godard of Wikhamskeyth, yeoman, a meadow, part of the manor of Wichamskeyth, for 42 years at an annual rent of 3s. 4d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1425.

Indenture dated 7 January, 35 Henry VIII, witnesseth that Richard Freston of Mendham, lord of the manor of Wicham Skeyth, in consideration of the payment of £12, grants to Nicholas Godard of Wikhamskeyth three acres of land in Wikhamskeyth for 300 years, at 3d annual rent. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1426.

Indenture made 14 May, 35 Hen. VIII, by which Richard Freston of Mendham, esq., demises to Thomas Bedwall and Elizabeth his wife and their sons, Symond, John the Elder, and John the Younger, the site of the manor of Wykham called Wykham Hall and lands, &c. for 99 years, at an annual rent of £10. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1427.

Indenture made 10 November, 35 Hen. VIII, by which Richard Freston of Mendham, esq., lord of the manor of Wyhamskeyth, in consideration of the receipt of .90, demises unto John Brame (or Branne) of Stokeasshe, yeoman, certain land in Wykhamskeyth for the term of three hundred years, at an annual rent of iiiid. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1428.

Indenture dated 7 December, 35 Hen. VIII, by which Richard Freston of Mendham, esq., lord of the manor of Wikhamskeyth, in consideration of the receipt of £6, demises to Edward Dove of Wickham Skeyth a small close of land in Wikhamskeyth for the term of 99 years, at an annual rent of iiiid. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1429.

Indenture dated 10 Decemb., 37 Hen. VIII, by which Richard Freston of Mendham in the co. of Suffolk, lord of Wykhamskeyth, demises to John Brame of Stokeasshe (The name is clearly Brame in the rental record), for £10 14s. 6d. in hand paid, one close called Grenecroft lying in Wykhamskeyth, for 1000 years, at an annual rent of 1d. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1430.

Indenture dated 21 April, 14 Q. Eliz., by which Richard Freston of London, gent. demises to John Bedwall his lands, pastures, &c. in Wykham, called Holgateland, for 3 years, at an annual rent of 30s. [English] MS. Ch. Suffolk 1431.
Rentell renued for a yeare due at St. Michaele, 1627,' for the manor of Wickham Skeyth. MS. Ch. Suffolk 1432.

WINGFIELD (College at). Indenture between master Robert Bude, master or provost of the collegiate church of Wingfield, and the brethren of the same house of the one part, who demise to Robert Warner of Wynferthyng of the other part, a certain inclosure in Wyngfeld for 60 years, at an annual rent of 8s. Dated at Wyngfeld, 1 Jan., 27 Hen. VIII. [With seal of the college, broken; and with signatures of five of the brethren.] MS. Ch. Suffolk 248.

WIRLINGHAM (Little). Symon, the prior and convent of Norwich confirm to the monastery of Buttley the church of Little Wirlingham St. Peter, appropriated to that monastery by Walter de Suffeld, bp. of Norwich, with 18 acres of land after the death of Hugh de Upton, the present paying annually to his successors. Dated at Norwich, 3 Id. Sept., 5 of his pontificate, i.e. 1249. MS. Ch. Suffolk 190.

WIRLINGWORTH. John, son of Robert de Wilryngworth, quit-claims to William, the abbot of St. Edmund, all his right in two acres and a half of land in 'Stannardiscrofts;' also certain meadow and pasture land. Dated at Wilryngworth the Saturday before the feast of St. Mark the evangelist, 13 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Suffolk 103.
